As waste is piling up at many points along the road, the number of birds in the region is high, increasing the risk of bird hits.

On Monday, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan convened a meeting to discuss the proposal.

Along with senior officials, representatives of Thiruvananthapuram Road Development Company Limited (TRDCL) - the concessionaire of City Roads Improvement Project - also attended the meeting.

As per the detailed project report (DPR) prepared by TRDCL, surveillance cameras will be installed at every 30 metres along the road. The fund for the same will be sourced from the public works department’s (PWD) budget allocation.

As per the plan, beautification work will be taken up along the stretch. Landscaping work will also be taken up. Flowering plants and small trees will be planted in the area.

Sculptures that will be mark the culture and heritage of Kerala will be installed in available spaces.

“Dumping of waste in the area is a major concern. The surveillance cameras will help to keep a check on this,” said an official from the Kerala road fund board.

The annual maintenance cost of the road is estimated around Rs 2.5 crore.

Once the beautification work of the road is completed, it is planned to raise the amount for maintenance through sponsors and advertising.

The meeting also reviewed the progress of restoration work of the Shanghumugham Road. A tender of Rs 5 crore has been invited for the restoration of the damaged area of Shangumugham Road.

A 200-metre stretch, along with the beach area, was damaged during soil erosion few months ago. The work will be started in February.

General administration principal secretary K R Jyothilal, local self-government department additional chief secretary T K Jose, PWD principal secretary R K Singh and principal secretary to CM V S Senthil attended the meeting.

Title: Frontline forest workers demand better facilities
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Dehradun: The members of Uttarakhand Van Beat and Van Aarakashi Union of Kumaon region have demanded better overall facilities for the frontline workers of forest department. The workers are frontline staff for protecting forests by conducting monitoring in dense areas amid life-threatening situations.

The members have demanded additional manpower and medical facilities saying that they are working in some of the densest forests in India.

Rakesh Shah, president of the union, said that it is important that they get additional manpower. “Also, medical facilities for the frontline workers need to be spruced-up as we work in an area that has leopards and tigers in abundance.”

General secretary of the union Bhupendera Singh Bisht said that forest chowkis and other accommodation of the beat workers should also be improved.

Title: Manic Monday: City marches to a halt
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

New Delhi: The arterial roads in central Delhi were choked on Monday afternoon owing to back-to-back roadshows, rallies and protest marches.

While southeast Delhi is already under siege due to the closure of Kalindi Kunj road, traffic being diverted through Noida Link Road and DND Flyway was also stalled during peak hours. The worst impacted was Vikas Marg between 11am and 1pm.

The snarls started around 1pm when supporters of Aam Aadmi Party gathered at Mandi House and Connaught Place Outer Circle for a protest march and a roadshow. Police shut one carriageway of Sikandra Road and a portion of Outer Circle from Minto Road for the rallies.

As a result, traffic jams started building up on Sikandra Road, DDU Marg and Minto Road. The ripple effect of the jam reached ITO within an hour. Soon, police shut Outer Ring Road and Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg for VIP movement from Talkatora Stadium to the BJP office on DDU Marg.

Since ITO crossing had to be closed for 15 minutes for the VIPs to pass, the snarl reached Vikas Marg and Noida Link Road even as police tried to clear the vehicles accumulated on the stretch. “I was stuck on Vikas Marg for nearly 40 minutes around 3pm before I could reach ITO for work,” said Devika Bhalla, a resident of Noida.

Commuters tweeted about the snarls tagging the traffic police. Police said they had to control the traffic signals manually.

A senior police officer said that the increase in volume of traffic from Noida added to the mess. According to an estimate, there has been a 20% increase in the number of vehicles that earlier used the south Delhi stretches to enter the city from Noida. As a result, nearly 40,000 vehicles are added to the existing volume at ITO, which is the busiest intersection in the city.

With the Kalindi Kunj road closed, motorists take Noida Link Road during peak hours to reach central and south Delhi to avoid the snarls on DND Flyway and Barapullah road.

Construction activities at crucial intersections like Ashram and Bhairon Marg add to the chaos.

Title: Death of elder sister of sex abuse survivors a mystery
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Malappuram: Mystery shrouds the death of the elder sister of four girls who were sexually abused by their father at Valanchery in the district.

On Saturday, Valanchery police had arrested the 47-year-old man for sexually abusing his four daughters aged 17, 15, 13 and 10. The children who have been sheltered in a child care institute informed counselors that their elder sister had died six years ago at the age of 15.

An official of social welfare department has revealed that they would discuss the issue with senior police officials at an official meeting on Tuesday and would ask the special police team conducting a probe into the sexual abuse case to also investigate the death.

Official sources said that a detailed probe into the death of the girl is needed as all other girls of the family were victims of abuse by the father. “During various counseling sessions, the survivors revealed that their elder sister died due to illness without giving details of the reason for death,” said the official.

District Child Protection Officer Geethanjali said that it was the police’s duty to conduct an investigation if there anything mysterious in the death of the elder sister of the victims of Valanchery sexual abuse case.

Meanwhile, Valanchery police inspector T Manoharan, who is leading the investigation team, said that they have no information on an elder sister of the girls.

Title: Osmania University prof Kaseem is first Dalit secretary of Virasam
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

HYDERABAD: The Viplava Rachayitala Sangham (Revolutionary Writers’ Association), popularly known as Virasam, was much in news following the arrest of its secretary and associate professor in Osmania University Ch Kaseem . Virasam has nearly 50 years of literary legacy, having engaged in the development of Telugu literature and carrying out literary activities in support of various people’s movements, including the Srikakulam Struggle in ’70s and the Telangana statehood agitation.

The journey of Virasam began in the port city of Visakhapatnam on July 4, 1970. The establishment of Virasam was one of the major events in Telugu literary world revolving around Sri Sri (Srirangam Srinivasa Rao), who is considered as the ‘poet of this century’ and ‘Mahakavi’ (greatest poet) in Telugu.

Resentment was brewing among many young poets as the most noted literature platform ‘Abhyudaya Rachiyitala Sangham’ (Arasam) was being seen by many as being status quoist and pro-state.

By then, many literature lovers, specially in poetry, were under the influence of developments in France and other European countries. In 1970, when Sri Sri was attending a felicitation event in Visakhapatnam, many young poets objected to him saying that he was not ‘pro-people’ when Srikakulam Struggle was at its peak. In July in the same year, Seven Stars Collective, a private organisation wanted to felicitate Sri Sri in Hyderabad, which again faced revolt from young poets.

It led to the birth of Virasam with poets and writers of different schools of thought like ‘digambara kavulu’ (naked poets), ‘tirugubatu kavulu’ (poets who revolt) and all those who were opposed to then literary establishment.

Sri Sri also joined Virasam and was made the first president of Virasam. C Narayana Reddy, who won the Jnanpith award for his poetry compilation ‘Viswambhara,’ was part of the organisation which wanted to facilitate Sri Sri in Hyderabad, but he did not join Virasam.

Critics of Virasam then said Sri Sri was kidnapped, to which Sri Sri famously responded: “No one kidnapped me, but revolution kidnapped me.” It was during this time, a poetry compilation of Virasam ‘Ipudu veestunna gaali’ (The wind of present times) was banned.

Virasam was very active during the Emergency. The organisation was banned for some time in the ’90s and some of its sympathisers were either killed by rivals and gunned down in police encounters. One among them was Paritala Sriramulu, father of slain Telugu Desam Party (TDP) leader Paritala Ravindra.

Virasam had a legion of stalwarts of Telugu literature like C Kutumba Rao and Raavi Shastri under its wings. However, many of them left Virasam alleging that it was not providing space and freedom to new thoughts of literary identity and to Dalits and women.

Virasam, on its part, refutes the allegations of police of allegiance to Maoist party and says it would continue to operate in the fields of art and literature.

Virasam publishes at least 20 books every year, including translation works from other languages. “Our stand on key issues has not changed. We will continue to focus on literature which inspires people,” Arasvilli Krishna, who is the new president-elect of Virasam, said.

In fact, after Sri Sri, Virasam never had a full-time president. P Varavara Rao , who is lodged in a Pune jail in a case relating to alleged conspiracy to assassinate Prime Minister Narendra Modi, continues to be the face of Virasam. Kaseem is the first Dalit secretary of the organisation.

Title: Haridwar: Cop booked for woman’s rape, murder
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representational Image

Title: SmartCity: Corp to seek state govt’s help
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Kochi: Kochi corporation council held on Monday failed to overcome the hurdles in front of many of the SmartCity projects . So, the special meeting of the council convened to discuss issues related to the implementation of component projects of SmartCity decided to rope in the state government.

Mayor Soumini Jain said the council will seek the intervention of local self-government minister A C Moideen to tackle the issues related to implementation of the projects. She also instructed Cochin Smart Mission Ltd (CSML) officials to send a report to the corporation regarding when the road renovation projects under SmartCity can be started and completed. “The CSML officials should send the report immediately so that it can be placed before the council when it meets next,” Jain said.

The corporation failed to sort out the issues related to identifying land for rehabilitating merchants from Ernakulam Market as part of its renovation. At a meeting convened by Hibi Eden, MP, in August 2019, a school near the market was identified for rehabilitating the merchants. Later, it came to the fore that the land of the school is entangled in a legal dispute over ownership. “We held discussion with the owners. They are ready to hand over the land provided we return it in good condition within the said period. Now, we are planning to move the court,” a CSML official said. “As part of the project, we have two works. One is the reconstruction of the market building. The second one is the construction of a temporary set up for rehabilitating the merchants. If there is no solution to get the land of the school, we will have to put the second work on hold,” he said.

According to the officials with CSML, work on 18 projects worth Rs 592 crore was started while nine projects totalling to Rs 38.56 crore are in the final stage of tendering. While other agencies would be entrusted with the implementation of five projects worth Rs 57.03 crore through nomination scheme, another five projects costing Rs 77.5 crore would be implemented in association with other departments and agencies. Five projects worth Rs 205.4 crore will be awarded in January itself.

The mayor has asked the CMSL officials to expedite implementation of the projects like installation of CCTV cameras and road signage in the city. “There won’t be much difficulties in implementing such projects. So, those projects should be implemented on a war footing,” she said.

K J Antony, the opposition leader of Kochi corporation, slammed the authorities for delaying the project.

Title: Cong, BJP exchange barbs over leaked audio clip of Cong leader
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Dehradun: A week after an audio clip surfaced on social media in which Congress leader Rajendra Bhandari can purportedly be heard making “anti-Brahmin” comments, Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) spokesperson Devendra Bhasin said that the clip has exposed the true face of the grand old party. “It is extremely unfortunate that a senior Congress leader made such loose statements. The audio clip has shown true colour of Congress and its leaders to the people,” alleged Bhasin.

Meanwhile, Congress spokesperson Garima Dasauni, while questioning the authenticity of the audio clip, said, “BJP must ponder on the leaked audio clips of their members before pointing a finger at us. Our party will decide on further action only after the authenticity of the clip is proved.” She added that such issues could be resolved easily after the appointment of a Lokayukta in the state and that the Congress has been demanding for the same for a long time now.

In the audio clip, a man can be heard asking an aspiring zila panchyat member to “teach a lesson to Brahmins for voting in favour of the BJP.” The clip is said to have been recorded around the recently-held panchayat polls.

When queried on the issue, Bhandari denied making any provocative statements. "The leaked audio clip is tampered and has been made viral to malign my image," the Congress leader alleged.

Title: Telangana: Surge in dengue numbers worries doctors
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Just when the state health authorities had written off dengue as a threat and a dip in number of cases were being seen, the dengue spreading Aedes mosquitoes seem to have become active again. In January, 180 new cases have been detected across the state.

Although January is not the dengue season and up till two years ago barely one or two stray cases were reported during this time of the year, dengue has clearly become an all season virus as indicated by experts. Last year, cases were reported throughout the year and the number increased substantially during monsoon season.

With dengue becoming a constant threat, experts say it’s time that government start investing in research related to dengue. “Several countries are carrying out research programmes to find ways to deal with the problem. For instance, Singapore is doing research on releasing dummy mosquitoes in the atmosphere to cut out the breeding of Aedes mosquitoes. We also need to look at the research aspect now. Moreover, despite such huge number of cases reported last year, not a single hoarding or flexi, creating awareness about the disease, was put up anywhere in the city. We need to create awareness and take drastic steps towards it,” said Dr M Karuna, paediatrician who had filed a PIL in the High Court over inaction of authorities to control dengue.

The need for focussing on preventive aspect becomes important as dengue is a costly disease. “Being a viral infection there is no specific treatment for dengue and only symptomatic treatment is given. In severe cases, several organs get affected and multi-organ failure is common, which requires ICU care. As a result the cost outcome is huge and yet there is only little chance of survival in severe cases,” said a senior official from state health department.

As per state health department, 13,417 dengue cases were recorded across Telangana in 2019. This is the highest number of cases reported in the state till date and has seen the highest jump in number of cases year-on-year (from 4,592 cases in 2018 to 13,417 in 2019).

Title: Rajasthan: 1 held for Chinkara poaching, 4 escape
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The arrested poacher

JAISALMER: Chinkara poaching cases are increasing in Mohangarh canal area of Jaisalmer district.

On Monday, police and the forest department arrested a poacher for killing a rare species of chinkara for a party a week ago in Ramdeora area. Sources said poaching of rare migratory was also on the rise.

Following a complaint by farmers, Mohangarh police and forest department conducted a joint raid in 24SBS, 85 RD Jawahar Nagar and arrested Narpatram, a resident of Digga. Hide of the chinkara, cooked meat, liver, head, burnt bones, gun and explosives were recovered from him.

Police also found a weighing machine and knives which proved that he was active in this area for very long time. While Narpatram was arrested, four others managed to give police a slip.

During inquiry he told police that some guests had come for which he had poached the chinkara. He identified the other poachers as Thakararam, Heeraram, Mehtabram and Manoharram Bheel.

Wildlife lover & Akhil Bhartiya Jeev Raksha Vishnoi Sabha secretary Radheyshyam Penani said winter and far spread desert gives best opportunity to poachers. In many areas of the district, people poach wildlife with guns.

Title: Pinarayi Vijayan releases Kerala Bank logo
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan releases Kerala Bank logo in Thiruvananthapuram on Monday

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said Kerala Bank is an alternative to those banks which are exploiting people with profit motives. He was speaking after releasing the logo of Kerala Bank here on Monday.

There is no doubt that Kerala Bank will become the premier banking institution in the state. At present SBI is the premier banking institution in the state with 1,216 branches and a total deposit of Rs 1,53,000 crore. Kerala Bank will have 825 branches and a total deposit of Rs 65,000 crore. Apart from this there will be cooperatives in the farming sector. This network will protect the interests of people and will be a lifeline for the poor. In the next three years the aim is to create a deposit worth Rs 3 lakh crore, said the chief minister.

He allayed the fears created from certain quarters that the cooperative behaviour of the cooperative banks will be lost once the Kerala Bank is formed. “The cooperative behaviour will be protected and people will be benefitted in the same way the cooperative banks have been catering to their needs,” he said.

The first general body meeting of the Kerala State Cooperative Bank has given the approval for the merger of 13 district cooperative banks for the formation of the Kerala Bank. The general body also gave nod for the mission document of the bank and for the business plan that has to be executed in the next three years.

Cooperative minister Kadakampally Surendran said the general body was attended by 987 representatives. He claimed that the boycott called by the UDF was disowned by their supporters and they attended the meeting.

Title: Docs can apply online as TCMC goes digital
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Travancore Cochin Medical Council ( TCMC ) has launched all its services in digital format . Now, all the applications can be filed online to the council. Besides, all statutory registers have been converted into digital format.

Smart identity cards will be provided to doctors registered with the council. Health minister K K Shailaja inaugurated the initiative on Monday by issuing the first such card.

With the completion of the first phase of the office automation, the no-objection certificates, provisional registration certificates, etc, can be obtained online. The pilot project had begun since October 2019 and it is a success, the minister said.

This online system will be a great help for doctors who want to register with TCMC. Presently, doctors have to be physically present and have to produce all the documents before the registrar for the registration. Soon, the online facility will be available for doctors qualifying from foreign universities too, the minister said .

The registration fees can be paid online. However, permanent registration certificates cannot be downloaded and they need to be collected from the council since it requires the signature of the doctor, hologram of the council, etc.

Title: Job racket: Two Army men among four arrested in Allahabad
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: Special Task Force (STF) arrested four men, including two servicemen, for their alleged involvement in an Army recruitment racket near Company Garden on Monday.

Police also seized three forged admit cards, applicants’ educational documents, financial records, eight mobile phones along with 229 odd WhatsApp screenshots and Rs 2.75 lakh cash from them. The accused were identified as Pradeep Singh Yadav from Ghazipur Sanjay Kumar Pandey from Kushinagar, Manish Singh Yadav from Kushinagar and Tripthinath Saroj from Jaunpur.

Of these Pradeep and Sanjay were Armymen. While Pradeep worked as a fire engine driver at COD Cheoki, Sanjay was posted as a nayak at 6 Mahar Regiment at Karu-Leh.

Additional SP (STF) Neeraj Kumar Pandey said, “The accused used to ensure appointment of candidates to Indian Army by forging medical records and other documents and helping them fraudulently clear the recruitment process.”

“During interrogation, Manish told police that his cousin and Kaushambi resident Mulayam Singh Yadav alias Ajay Yadav was the kingpin of the gang and is with the Indian Army. He is currently posted in Jodhpur,” Pandey said.

The ASP said the accused used to charge candidates Rs 60,000 to ensure that they clear the medical tests which are a part of the recruitment process. “If the candidate was successfully appointed, then they would charge an extra Rs 2-2.5 lakh.” STF claimed that kingpin of the racket Ajay Yadav had a close associate in zonal recruitment office (ZRO) in Lucknow who used to provide them official documents.

It was reported that two of the gang’s members – Pradeep Singh Yadav and Manish Yadav- had handed over Rs 25 lakh to a clerk posted at ZRO near Charbagh station in Lucknow last year.

The racketeers admittedmany military hospitals in Allahabad, Lucknow, Varanasi, Meerut and Army officials were a part of the nexus

A case has been lodged with Civil Lines police station under sections 419, and 420 of IPC and section 7\13 of the Corruption Eradication Act.

Title: Avoid provocative slogans at anti-CAA protests: Pasha
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

T’puram: Retired high court judge Justice B Kemal Pasha urged the anti-CAA protesters to abstain themselves from using provocative and religious slogans.

“It is true that Citizenship (Amendment) Act has been implemented against Muslims. But, before we protest against this unconstitutional Act, it is really important that we abstain from provocative and religious sloganeering. With CAA, they are attacking the secular nature of this country. We must form an alliance which is forged in friendship, we need the support of all the secular forces in our country to resist CAA and the implementation of NRC,” he said while inaugurating the Camaraderie Meet as part of the MahalFest held here on Monday.

Justice Pasha strongly condemned the provocative and offensive sloganeering in the protests and cautioned that religious extremists are making use of this opportunity to strengthen their hold.

“Many people may not like what I am about to say. But what is the relevance of speaking about the violence occurred in the communal riots in the past at the protest gatherings against CAA? It will only further divide the gap between our communities. The ruling party came unto power using communal polarization and they are very successful at doing so. We should not fall for that again and we must isolate extremists among ourselves. Extremism does not have a religion, be it Hindu or Muslim, extremists are extremists,” he added.

Justice Pasha also urged the people to seek the help of judiciary in the fight against CAA and NRC.

Palayam Imam V P Shuhaib Moulavi, state president of Jama-at Council Karamana Bayar and former director of minority department P Naseer also spoke at the function.

Title: Act against stage carriages with illegal fittings: Kerala high court
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: Fitness certificates of stage carriages fitted with high-intensity after-market headlights, thereby posing danger to other road users, should be cancelled, the high court has ordered. Similar action should be taken for vehicles with unauthorized crash guards or bull bars, the court directed.

Justice Anil K Narendran issued the order to the transport commissioner and motor vehicle department after considering two petitions on stage carriages violating the law. A stage carriage runs between two places without any prior contract and passengers can board or get down in between by paying only for the distance they travel. Thus, it would include KSRTC and private buses, and does not include tourist buses.

Making the transport commissioner a party in the cases, the court directed, “The Transport Commissioner, Kerala shall take necessary steps to ensure through the concerned officers in the Motor Vehicles Department that no stage carriage, including vehicles older than 20 years from the date of its registration, which are not installed with lighting and light-signalling devices and also retro-reflectors referred to in Para. 6.0 of AIS-008, conforming to the individual specifications for such lighting and light-signalling devices and also for retro-reflectors prescribed in Paras. 6.1 to 6.20, namely number, position, width, height, length, geometric visibility, orientation, etc; or which are installed with lighting and light-signalling devices or retro-reflectors other than those referred to in Para.6.0, which are likely to endanger the safety of other road users, are being permitted to be used in any public place.”

Such vehicles should not be issued fitness certificates and if any issued, should be cancelled, the court ordered. Proceedings should be initiated against the driver of such vehicle, including disqualification of licence for three months, and the owner of such vehicle should also be proceeded against, the order stated.

The court also ordered action against stage carriages fitted with after-market crash guards, bull bars and footsteps.

Action should also be taken against stage carriages not displaying the registration number’ without the illuminating lamp for rear registration plate; tampering with percentage of visual transmission of light of windscreen, rear and side windows by pasting stickers, tint films, etc; hanging various objects in front of the windscreen, thereby obstructing the driver’s clear vision, the court directed.

The court also ordered that action should be taken against use of graphical stickers on the body of stage carriages. “The body of every stage carriage shall be soundly constructed, as per the mandate of Rule 261 of Kerala Motor Vehicles Rules, and the paintwork or varnish shall be maintained in a clean and sound condition and in accordance with the specifications laid down by the State/Regional Transport Authority, as per the mandate of Rule 264 of the said Rules,” the order said.

Title: Rajasthan: 32-year-old woman stoned to death after robbery
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: Unidentified assailants on Monday early morning robbed a 32-year-old woman of her mangalsutra and earrings and when she resisted, they stoned her to death outside her house in Growth Centre area of Jhalrapatan . The deceased’s husband had left the house around 3.30am on Monday while her two children were asleep in the room at the time of crime.

Police have lodged a case of loot and murder under sections of IPC against unidentified accused. The body was handed over to family members after post-mortem. The deceased woman was identified as Sonabai Meghwal, wife of Radheshyam, said sub-inspector at Jhalrapatan police station Komal Pradas.

Prima facie, it seems that the unidentified accused entered the house between 3.30-4.30am after her husband left the house to collect cow dung. The children were asleep in the room, the SI said.

The deceased probably resisted the loot bid following which the accused attacked her with a heavy stone causing fatal injuries over her head, back and stomach, Pradas added. The deceased’s mangalsutra and earrings were missing.

Title: Smart City calendar launched by Doon mayor
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Dehradun: The Dehradun Smart City Limited (DSCL) in association with The Times of India launched a table-top calendar on Monday. The unveiling of the calendar was done by Doon mayor Sunil Uniyal Gama, who was accompanied by the Additional CEO of DSCL Ashish Bhatgai, and finance controller of the corporation Ganga Prasad amongst other officials and residents of the city.

The calendar has pictorial representation of important tourist destinations of Dehradun district and presents the vision that DSCL has for the city.

Speaking on the occasion, the mayor said, “Dehradun is a city of well-educated and aware citizens. All of us should work together to make it the No.1 Smart City of India.”

Title: Rajasthan tiger which played ‘mom’ to two orphan cubs dies in fight
Content:
Zalim with a cub. (Photo credit: Balendu Singh, former honorary wildlife warden, RNP)

Ranthambore tiger T-25 named Zalim, which came into limelight for its unusual behaviour of rearing two motherless cubs, died in a suspected territorial fight

The tiger was often spotted with the orphaned cubs, looking after them since they were four-months old

Second death of tiger in park in the last four months

JAIPUR: Ranthambore tiger T-25 named Zalim, which came into limelight for its unusual behaviour of rearing two motherless cubs, died in a suspected territorial fight on Monday.The carcass of the tiger was found near Jarkhala nalla in Sanwata area of Ranthambore Tiger Reserve (RTR). After the post-mortem, the forest department has concluded that the death occurred in a territorial fight.Mukesh Saini, divisional forest officer (DFO), Ranthambore National Park (RNP) said, “The tiger had two injuries on its head. It was found to have two canine marks above the eyes. It appears that the big cat died in the territorial fight with 10-year-old tiger T-66 whose movement was recorded with tigress T-54 in the same area.”“Tiger T-25’s behaviour of taking care and raising cubs to adulthood was unique and it has never been seen or filmed before this incident,” the official said.Rajasthan chief minister Ashok Gehlot expressed grief over the death of T-25, reportedly the first documented tiger to play “father figure”.“Sad news for wildlife that Ranthambore’s famous tiger T-25 is no more. It was a magnanimous tiger which took care of two orphan cubs, displaying fatherly instincts to raise and protect them to the surprise of conservationists. T-25 will be missed,” Gehlot tweeted.In 2012, the tiger took care of the twin orphan cubs of tigress T-5. This was one of the first instances when experts found a male tiger, known to abandon cubs after birth, playing the role of a ‘mother’, something unheard of about tigers.The tiger was often spotted with the orphaned cubs, looking after them since they were four-months old.In the past four months, this is the second death of a big cat in the park from territorial fights. Three- year-old T-109 named Veeru was found with 35 wounds in October last year.Cramped in an area of 392 sq km of core area with a 1,342 sq km buffer zone, it has been extremely difficult for big cats to find adequate space in the reserve, which is bursting at its seams due to increasing population.Pushed to the periphery of the reserve, it’s a tough choice for them to either fight with dominants, create space for themselves or stray into human habitation.Dinesh Verma Durani, founder and general secretary of Sariska Tiger Foundation and a member of the advisory committee, said, “The forest department claims that no new male tigers can be relocated to Sariska Tiger Reserve (STR) as the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) has refused to approve proposals of fresh relocation after a male tiger died in April. It was a natural death. Since then, two tigers have died in Ranthambore. The department should strongly present their case at NTCA to save tigers by moving them to Sariska.”

Title: Rajasthan flying school to get wings again after 11 years
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Now, those aspiring to be pilots need not go out of the state for training. The Rajasthan State Flying School in Jaipur, one-of-its-kind in the state, is being revived to train aspiring pilots after a gap of about 11 years.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot, who is also the president of the governing council of the flying school, has given his nod. Flying school has been in a limbo for over a decade after it was hit by various irregularities in issuing commercial pilot licence.

Kesari Singh, director, civil aviation said, “The chief minister has given his nod. We will shortly convene a governing council meeting to formally endorse the proposal.”

On being asked about the facilities available at the flying school, he said at present the flying school has two planes and a motor glider to train aspiring pilots. “We have a Cessna 172 four-seater plane and Cessna 152 two-seater plane. The school also plans two more planes soon.” He said according to the plan, a batch of 20 students has been decided upond initially.

The state government had earlier also made efforts to revive the school but did not succeed. Sources added that the state government will have to go for various licences before giving a nod to start the flying school.

The flying school hit headlines in 2008 when the anti-corruption bureau (ACB) exposed a scam when one of the trainees of the school, Nidhi Vashishtha, approached the bureau claiming that she was trained only for 22 hours but the chief flying officer Mahendra Chaudhary mentioned 169 hours of flying in the school record and sent it to DGCA.

During investigation, names of 14 pilots had come up who were issued flying certificates through dubious means by chief flying inspector of the school at the Sanganer airport. These certificates were used by the pilots to get commercial pilot licences (CPL) from DGCA. Similar arrests were made in Delhi and Haryana.

Title: Docu-fiction on women reformers to premiere today
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan will inaugurate the premiere of a docufiction on the role of women in the social reformation of the state at 7pm on Tuesday at the Tagore Theatre here.

‘Vimochanathinte Pattukar’ has been co-produced by the state department of women and children, Kerala State Women’s Development Corporation (KSWDC) and department of information & public relations.

The film, directed by Vidhu Vincent, was made as part of the state government’s ‘sadhairyam munnottu’ programme as part of its women’s empowerment efforts. Health and social justice minister KK Shailaja will preside over the function.

The film is narrated through the relationship between a girl and her grandmother. Through music, the girl learns about the history of social reforms in the state. Ahead of the screening, floral tributes will be paid at major memorials, such as Annie Mascrene square, Akkamma Cherian square, EMS park and Martyr’s square. Artists PK Medhini, Vidhu Vincent, Shruthi Nampoothiri and Divya Gopinath will lead the event.

A tribute led by Sayonara will be held at the main venue at 4pm. This will be followed by a cultural programme of students from various colleges. A discussion on ‘Kerala women: Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow’ will be held at 6pm. Screening of the docufiction will be held after the discussions. This will be followed by a performance of the music band ‘Chumadutangi’. The event will conclude with a night walk by women.

Title: Government interest crucial in Tamil Nadu’s biggest fest
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

During Thai Poosam, the six abodes of Murugan in Tamil Nadu records a combined footfall of more than 3 crore

(K K Ramchandran)

Pongal is more of a cultural event than a religious one, traditionally a harvest occasion celebrated by people across society. So, Thai Poosam , which is celebrated on the last day of the festivities and which has Lord Muruga, the Tamil god of youth, beauty and aggression Lord Muruga at its centre, should rightfully be accorded the tag of the biggest religious event of Tamils.

Though celebrated for 10 days with yatra, kavadi and milk pot (paal kudam) processions, the fervour peaks over the last three days and culminates when Tamil month of Thai blends with Poosam star. This year, it falls on January 21.

From Kandy in Sri Lanka to Batu caves of Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia, nothing unites the Tamil diaspora as passionately as Thai Poosam. Batu caves logged 1.6 million visitors on Thai Poosam day in 2019, and this year the number is expected to breach the two million mark. Every year, during this period, the six abodes of Lord Muruga in Tamil Nadu records a combined footfall of more than 3 crore. And, the pre-Christian era hill shrine of Palani alone accounts for more than a third of the crowd. The once-in-40-years spectacle of Athi Varadar in Kancheepuram drew 1 crore devotees in 48 days. The once-in 12-years Kumbakonam Mahamagam attracted 1.5 million people taking a holy dip. They are the biggest Hindu festivals in the state, but are hardly comparable to Thai Poosam in terms of size. "It is comparable only with mega religious congregations such as Ardh Kumbh Mela which drew more than 24 crore pilgrims in 2019. But Kumbh Melas take place once in three to 12 years," said S Velusamy, president of Federation of Thai Poosam Peravai, TN.

But, unlike the Uttar Pradesh government which has put in place a permanent statutory authority headed by a senior IAS officer to oversee arrangements for the festival even during non-Kumbh years, successive governments in Tamil Nadu have not made much of an effort to ensure accessibility and safety of the thronging devotees during Thai Poosam. As of now, the festival is handled by local temple committees or by individual philanthropists.

The Uttar Pradesh government set up Prayagraj Mela Authority and spent more than `4,000 crore in 2019 to create infrastructure to handle the sea of devotees. For Thai Poosam, there is no central authority either to make a budgetary outlay or to create infrastructure for devotees, leaving people to fend for themselves or banking on the district authority.

As a first step, the government must acknowledge Thai Poosam as the biggest religious event in the state and declare a holiday to mark it. It is time the government created an authority to manage Thai Poosam, headed by a senior bureaucrat and assisted by other departments. The authority should have adequate financial sanction to create infrastructure at the six abodes of Lord Muruga and to other important temples where Thai Poosam is celebrated in a big way. It should be followed up with steps like organising transport, regulating crowd and institutionalising the way the festival is celebrated across the state and in the diaspora.

The initiative to streamline the festival celebration will be a statement of an administration’s understanding of its people.

Title: Over 100 taken ill with quack’s potion, police intensify search
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

KOLLAM: Eroor police have registered a case against a quack from Telangana who dispensed fake medicine and swindled money. Over 100 people, including children, developed serious illnesses at Eroor Pathadi near Anchal in the district after consuming medicine from the quack. The quack is absconding after the police registered a case.

Lakshman Raj, a native of Telengana, had allegedly distributed medicine to over 100 houses here for various ailments, assuring that the medicine could cure their diseases. But it was later found that the medicine contained a high amount of mercury, causing illness related to kidney and liver.

Muhammed Ali (4) son of Ubaid of Rahim Manzil, Pathadi, who took the medicine later developed fever and rashes all over his body . The boy who was admitted to a private hospital at Anchal was later shifted to the Medical College Hospital, Thiruvananthapuram.

His father said the boy had to be kept on the ventilator for 10 days . “The medicine given to the boy by the quack was examined at the govt’s chemical laboratory and it was found to contain mercury twenty times more than the permissible limit” he said.

When contacted Eroor police said that they had intensified the probe to arrest the quack. “We have registered a case against the quack after we received complaint from the parents of a four-year-old boy whose health worsened after consuming the medicine. Based on the complaint we are trying to trace the location of the culprit. So far 15 people have come forward to report the fraud,” a police official said.

Local people said the quack had collected Rs 500 to 20,000 from each patient.

Title: Telangana: Leopard takes nap at Shadnagar house, tranquillized and sent to zoo
Content:
The leopard is suspected to have strayed into the town from Kammadanam reserve forest, located about six kilom... Read More

Leopard which had entered Ranga Reddy district’s Shadnagar area has been tranquilized and captured safely, being sh… https://t.co/FT15to7bCo — TOI Hyderabad (@TOIHyderabad) 1579506149000

SHADNAGAR: It was a regular Monday morning for people in Shadnagar in neighbouring Rangareddy district, but for Manne Vijay Kumar it was a terrifying start. He woke up to the news of a leopard resting on the terrace of his house on Patel Road. After a three-hour wait and 45-minute operation , the big cat was tranquillized and sent to Nehru Zoological Park in Hyderabad. In the melee, a constable suffered claw injuries.According to forest officials, the six-year-old male leopard, which was resting on the terrace beside a few flowerpots, was first sighted by Kumar’s children, who informed their parents about the animal and tried to approach it not knowing that it was a wild animal.The leopard is suspected to have strayed into the town from Kammadanam reserve forest, located about six kilometres away.“The children were lucky that their parents saw the leopard just in time and stopped them before they went close to the leopard. They took the children and rushed inside the house, locked the doors and dialled 100 for help,” Rangareddy district divisional forest officer Bheema Naik told TOI.Policemen, who reached the spot, confirmed the leopard’s presence after they spotted it from a neighbour’s terrace and informed the forest department. A team of forest officials and veterinary experts from Nehru Zoological Park reached the spot.“The leopard was resting at the same place till the rescue team from Hyderabad reached the spot. For about three hours, between 6am to 9am, it was just sitting there,” Naik said.At 9am, when the rescue team reached the spot and began the operation, the leopard went and hid behind the stairs.“It appears the leopard panicked because of the noise made by people gathered there. Police had to control the mob from coming close to the house before we could tranquillize it. The entire operation lasted about 45 minutes,” informed a zoo official.The leopard was tranquillized and shipped to Nehru Zoological Park, where it would be kept under observation for 48 hours before relocating it in the forest.When the tranquillizer was shot, the leopard leaped and ran for about 100 metres, injuring a police constable. The forest officials informed that it was a minor injury and the constable was in stable condition.

Title: Denied VP post, NCP fighting to head 2 ZP panels
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nagpur: Haggling is going on between local Congress and NCP leaders for important posts in Nagpur Zilla Parishad ( ZP ). The post of both president and vice-president has gone to Congress while its pre-poll ally NCP was left high and dry.

There are seven subject committees in the ZP — public works, finance, education, water supply and sanitation, agriculture and animal husbandry, social welfare and women and child welfare. Of these, the first three are considered more important.

Home minister Anil Deshmukh of NCP wants that the party should get two out of the three important committees — public works, finance and education. However, Congress is ready to concede only one.

During the previous BJP-Shiv Sena rule, the ZP president was head of the standing committee and one subject committee. The vice-president headed two subject committees. Congress wants to follow the same pattern, which leaves only four committees for others. This is the reason for the party’s reluctance to give more than one committee to the NCP.

Deshmukh’s problem is that Congress does not need NCP’s help in running the government in the ZP. Congress has 31 members in the house of 58 while NCP has 10.

The post of president was reserved for SC (woman). Deshmukh wanted the vice-president’s post, which was open, for his son Salil. However, dairy development minister Sunil Kedar of Congress refused to oblige.

Deshmukh was so upset that he publicly accused Congress of not honouring the alliance norms. He had told the media that NCP had given two proposals to Congress for consideration. As per one proposal, NCP wanted the post of vice-president and chairmanship of one of the subject committees. In another, NCP wanted chairmanship of two committees — one for a male and one for a woman member.

Senior NCP leader Praful Patel had come specially for the discussions and senior Congress leader Manikrao Thakre also was present apart from other leaders from both the parties. However, Congress rejected the first proposal.

Deshmukh had warned that if Congress did not take appropriate decision on the second proposal, repercussions would be felt across Maharashtra.

The relations had become so strained that district Congress president Rajendra Mulak had to publicly say that the Congress-NCP alliance was intact.

Title: IIT aspirant from UP hangs self in Kota
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: A 19-year-old boy from UP hanged himself from the ceiling fan of his hostel room in Mahavir Nagar –I under Jawahar Nagar police station area of Kota city on the intervening night of Saturday and Sunday for failing to qualify JEE-Mains.

When the boy did not come out of the room throughout the day on Sunday, the hostel warden knocked on his room door and when he got no response, he informed police, which rushed to the spot and broke the room’s door open only to find the boy hanging from the fan.

The deceased, identified as Vijay Kumar Singh (19) of Gorakhpur in Uttar Pradesh, had been preparing for IIT-JEE for admission in engineering college for the last three years, Jawahar Nagar ASI Awadhesh Singh, who is investigating the case, said. The boy had attended a coaching institute of the city for first two years to prepare for the entrance exam but had been doing self studies in the hostel room for the last one year, he added.

It is the second suicide by an NEET-IIT aspirant in the last four days. On Wednesday last week, a 23-year-old girl, Kanchan Bala from Himachal Pradesh, who was preparing to appear for NEET for admission in a medical college in the city for last two years, hanged herself from the ceiling fan of her PG room in Basant Vihar colony under Dadabari police station area.

Vijay reportedly obtained low percentile in the JEE-Mains, the results of which were declared late on Friday night and failed to secure admission in an engineering college went into depression, the ASI said.

The boy was reportedly seen last outside his hostel room on Saturday evening and did not come out of the room throughout Sunday.

No suicide note was recovered from his room, he added.

The family members of the boy were informed on Sunday night and they reached the city on Monday.

Prima facie, the boy was in depression after failing to qualify JEE-Mains entrance with 83 percentile and under the stress, he took the extreme step, the ASI said, adding investigation under 174 of CrPC was underway to ascertain the actual reason.

Title: Kochi: Attempt-to-murder charges against Cusat SFI leaders
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Students protest in front of Cusat administrative block on Monday

KOCHI: Kalamassery police have registered a case of attempt-to-murder against the unit president and secretary of Students’ Federation of India (SFI) after a complaint by a first year student of Cochin University of Science and Technology ( Cusat ) that they mowed down a bike in which he was travelling and assaulted him with iron rods.

Police sources said they have registered cases against Rahul Peralam and Prajith K Babu and some unidentified persons based on the complaint. Peralam and Babu are secretary and president, respectively, of the SFI unit in Cusat campus.

They have been charged under IPC Sections 308 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) besides 294 B and 506 (1) pertaining to use of abusive language and criminal intimidation.

The victim, Azil Aboobacker, a first-year BTech instrumentation student of the varsity has been admitted to Government Medical College at Kalamassery with head injuries.

According to Kalamassery police, the incident happened at Cusat Signal Junction at 11.30pm on Sunday following a fracas between students at Sanatana hostel where a ‘hostel fest’ was held. “There was an altercation between two sections of the students and this incident happened as a fallout of this. As per the complaint, Aboobacker’s bike was hit by the accused and when he fell down he was hit by iron rods,” said a police officer. A few days ago there was a dispute between two group of students on sports day and the incident on Sunday night was a continuation of this. Police said there was no political angle in the incident caused by personal issues between students. No arrests have been made yet.

Students staged a sit-in protest in front of the administrative block of the varsity on Monday demanding strict action against the accused. They ended their agitation after assurance from the vice-chancellor that strict action would be taken against those responsible for the assault.

Title: Delhi: Server room that controls CCTVs in buses gutted
Content:
All employees were evacuated in time

NEW DELHI: A fire at the Delhi Transport Corporation headquarters in north Delhi gutted the server room that controls the GPS and CCTV cameras of all buses, cabs and autorickshaws plying in the city. The fire spread to other rooms in the building and damaged important files pertaining to the RTO, employees claimed. Police are probing sabotage behind the fire.The fire department pressed 26 tenders into service to douse the flames. All employees were evacuated in time before the fire spread through the building.Fire officers said they received a call around 8.40am regarding the blaze on Rajpur Road in Civil Lines. Initially, eight fire tenders were rushed to the spot. It was found that the server room on the first floor was on fire. However, by the time the firemen could enter the building, the fire spread to the other rooms and the floor above. Subsequently, more fire tenders were called.“We had to break open the doors of a few rooms to gain access. The fire was brought under control shortly,” said a fire officer.In the fire, most of the systems connected to the server had damaged. However, senior transport officials said that the fire was not huge and affected only a portion of the first floor. “It will not affect the core and crucial work of the department,” claimed a senior official.The additional chief secretary has asked special commissioner (administration) to conduct an inquiry to find out the cause of the fire. A complete estimate of the loss of files and corrective steps for preventive action was also ordered by him.Fire officers said the blaze probably started from the diary and dispatch section of the transport department. “It appears that a short circuit caused the fire. However, the fire only affected routine sections of the department and no major branches,” said an officer.There were concerns about driving licences seized by the transport department having been burnt in the fire. However, a transport official clarified that the people didn’t have to worry as no records were destroyed and no public dealing branch was affected. “However, our state-of-the-art operation control and command centre, from where all public service vehicles are tracked through GPS, suffered damages,” the officer added. Work at the state transport authority, MLO headquarters, enforcement wing, etc resumed after lunch.

Title: Amul fumes over CII’s demand to import SMP
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Co-operative versus Corporate

Vadodara: A co-operative versus private players battle seems to be brewing in India’s dairy sector. Home-grown dairy giant – Amul – has objected strongly to a proposal mooted by industry body –Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) - to import skimmed milk powder (SMP) at zero duty.

Gujarat Co-operative Milk Marketing Federation (GCMMF) that markets brand Amul has approached Union government asking it not to surrender to a ‘motivated representation’ of CII.

CII has approached ministry of food processing industries asking the government to allow import of 50,000 metric tonnes of SMP through National Dairy Development Board at zero duty for specific end-use in dairy industry and food processing industry on the grounds that it will help secure supplies and stabilize prices for dairy and food processing sector.

“This will overcome current challenges arising out of depletion of SMP stock in the country and shortfall in production,” CII’s proposal states.

Terming the proposal as ‘anti-farmer’, GCMMF’s managing director R S Sodhi has shot off a letter to secretary Pushpa Subrahmanyam stating that the fear of shortage of milk in the country is being created by private players and ice-cream manufacturers who want cheap raw material and is not in the interest of either farmers or consumers.

Amul has argued that overall milk production is growing at a healthy rate of 6 %. Last year, due to lower price of commodities, all the private players had stopped milk procurement which had resulted in unprecedented growth in milk procurement for all co-operatives, Amul has argued.

“If we compare last two years data, you will realize that milk procurement is growing at a healthy CAGR of 7-8% (which is much higher than global CAGR of less than 2%) and as a result of which, there is no shortage of milk anywhere in the country,” Sodhi’s letter to the Union secretary states.

Amul has argued that since last year when SMP price was Rs150 per kg, private players were using SMP instead of buying milk because of which all milk was getting diverted to co-operatives resulting in growth at over 20 %.

This year, it says, the situation has reversed with SMP price nearing Rs300 due to which private players have started using milk instead of SMP.

“This clearly proves the selfish motive of these private players at the cost of farmers as well as consumers. Last year, when they got cheap SMP, none of them passed on any price benefit to consumers by reducing prices of ice-cream or dairy products and left the milk producers at the mercy of co-operatives,” Amul has alleged, stressing that government should not bother about commodity price of milk powder as the total SMP domestic consumption is not even equal to 10 days of country’s total milk production.

Title: Child porn: Nine held in Delhi after Facebook, Instagram file complaints
Content:
AFP file photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Nine people have been arrested from across the city for allegedly sharing child pornography on social media sites and applications. The arrests were made after 18 cases were registered over the past one month on complaints from Facebook and Instagram .Most of the users, in the age group of 25-35 years, were watching the videos and circulating them through mobile phones. More arrests are likely. Out of the 18 complaints, 14 were given by Facebook and four by Instagram. In November, six persons were arrested on the same charge.Facebook and Instagram alerted police after some of the videos were shared through their platforms. One of the arrested persons is from Jhajjar in Haryana while the others are from Vasant Kunj, Okhla, Kalkaji, Dilshad Colony, Rohini and Faridabad.An investigating official said some of the accused were senior, even in their 40s. The nine arrested include a driver, cook, financier, businessman, salesman, contractor, five-star hotel employee and a worker of an electronics company.One of the accused told the cops that he had received the video after joining a group on Facebook and passed it on through WhatsApp. “If all platforms alert us, we can track more people and take action,” said an official.National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) and National Center for Missing & Exploited Children, a non-profit organisation established in 1984 by the United States Congress, has a memorandum of understanding under which the American agency provides information to NCRB about sexually offensive content against children available on various social media platforms. The social media sites, too, have their own monitoring programme to identify those who are watching or sharing such videos.

Title: India had asked Pakistan to control locusts in December
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Jaipur: Though India had asked Pakistan to control hoppers (baby locusts withut wings) in December 2019, no steps were taken which ultimately turned into the voracious pink locusts, said Dr KL Gurjar, deputy director of Locust Control Organisation (LCO), Jodhpur, on Monday while visiting various locust-hit villages in Sriganganagar.

Officials said pink locusts are creating havoc in both the countries along the international border.

Gurjar told TOI over phone that a bilateral meeting took place between both the countries at Munabao in Barmer on December 4, 2019 in which he led the four-member delegation from the Indian side. “We had witnessed a large number of hoppers in the Pakistani side. In the meeting, Pakistani counterparts had crossed over and sat for the meeting at a place designated by the BSF at Munabao in Barmer. We had specifically told them to control the hoppers,” Gurjar said.

He added that these hoppers have now developed as pink locusts which are damaging crops in Sriganganagar and Bikaner districts. “Fresh movement of locusts was witnessed near Ramgarh area of Jaisalmer and in some parts of Raisinghnagar tehsil of Sriganganagar district,” he added.

Senior officials added that the movement of locusts was not only confined to India and its border districts especially Jaisalmer, Sriganganagar and Bikaner but were also seen flying in Pakistan territory.

On the ongoing presence of locusts in Rajasthan, Gurjar said, “Presently we are controlling them in Sriganganagar, Raisinghnagar, Ravla and Anoopgarh areas and our team is working at Ramgarh in Jaisalmer district.”

Senior LCO officials said they don’t believe to re-organise talks with Pakistan in this matter. “We are controlling locusts properly. There is no point in having more parleys in this regard as we don’t think they have enough wherewithals to control the menace,” said a senior officer.

Officials added that villages like Haroonabad, Dunga Banga and Gulab Ali of Bahawalpur district in Pakistan and some portions of Karachi are also affected with locusts as these are very close to Raisinghnagar of Sriganganagar district.

Title: Man bludgeons wife to death over suspected affair in Amber
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Ayaz Ahmad killed his wife over suspected affair

Title: Man arrested years after kidnapping and killing woman
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: Special Task Force (STF) arrested a man for allegedly abducting a woman and brutally murdering her on Monday, four years after her half-burnt body was found on Kaushambi-Varanasi highway.

The accused Salman (26) was arrested in Daraganj along with an accomplice Lucky Panda alias Lucky (27), while planning to escape from the city. Police also seized two SUVs, a motorcycle, three mobile phones and Rs 2,450 cash from their possession.

During interrogation, Salman told the police that he and the deceased Rachna Shukla had become close friends in 2015 and he had also gifted her a scooty. “As the two-wheeler was registered under my name, she had been insisting to get it registered under her name,” the accused told the police.

The dispute escalated leading to a fight between the two. A few days later, her family lodged a case against Salman at Daraganj police station. Salman alleged that Rachna, who was 19 then, often used to insult him at public places, said police. Fed up of Rachna’s behaviour, Salman decided to kill her. He claimed that Salman and his aides slit Rachna’s throat, disposed her body on the highway and fled.

Additional SP (STF) Neeraj Kumar Pandey said, “Rachna Shukla was allegedly abducted on April 16, 2016 from Daraganj. After she disappeared, her mother Uma Shukla had lodged a case under section 363 and 366 of the IPC against Salman and his accomplices.”

When police failed to get clues about the missing girl, the mother had also filed a petition in Allahabad high court . While working on the case, the STF team came to know that the accused had killed Rachna and thrown her body on the same day (April 16, 2016). They set the body afire at a location close to the Allahabad-Pratapgarh border.

On April 17, 2016, Pratapgarh police recovered a woman’s half-burnt body on the Kaushambi-Varanasi highway and registered a case under section 302 and 201 of IPC against unidentified persons.

On Monday, STF received a tip-off that the prime accused Salman and one of his accomplice were spotted near the Nagbasuki Temple Road. The team cordoned off the area and arrested Salman and Lucky from Daraganj.

Title: HCBA polls set to witness multi-cornered contests
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nagpur: Multi-pronged contests are on cards to elect various office-bearers of the High Court Bar Association ( HCBA ), polls for which are likely to be held next month.

Many groups and individuals have already started campaigning even though the HCBA is yet to issue a formal notification in this regard.

According to lawyers, prominent groups like the one supported by Manohar family and others are in the process of finalizing candidates and are leaving no stone unturned to woo the voters. This time, the focus of all contesting groups is on youngsters.

So far, only an unnamed group supported by Shreerang Bhandarkar has finalized names of president and secretary’s posts. Sameer Sohoni has been finalized for the president’s post by this group, mostly comprising young lawyers. On other hand, there are talks of all powerful group, led by senior counsel Vyankatesh (VR) Manohar, supporting Deven Chauhan, but he’s yet to confirm his participation.

Names of Atul Pandey and Shridhar Purohit are also doing rounds for the president’s post. Seasoned candidate VG Bhamburkar, who unsuccessfully fought all elections for prestigious post for last many years, is likely to try his luck again, say sources.

The lawyers though predict that unlike 2017 polls, this year wouldn’t be as exciting as none of the big names are keen to contest. Last time, the HCBA had witnessed one of the most interesting battles between top lawyers for the president’s post, which was billed as “clash of titans”. Noted lawyers Anil Kilor (now HC judge) and Bhandarkar had fought an intense battle where the former narrowly defeated the latter by a margin of 60 votes. It was one of most closely watched battles in the association’s history. Kilor had polled 687 votes and Bhandarkar 627.

Bhandarkar told TOI that he would be making all efforts to ensure Sohoni and other team members from a group supported by him emerge winner.

Reminding about District Bar Association (DBA) polls, he said nobody gave even an outside chance to presidential candidate Kamal Satuja, who was pitted against popular lawyer Uday Dable, believed to be close to former CM, and had influence over lawyers practising in Nagpur district and sessions court. “But Satuja emerged winner. Therefore, nothing can be said in the polls even if opposite camp is strong,” he said.

Commenting on Bhandarkar’s claims, other lawyers stated that if Sohoni wins, it would be for the first time since 1990s that candidates from powerful group backed by Manohar family wouldn’t be at the helm of affairs in the HCBA. Last time, it happened in 1993 when senior counsel Shrihari Aney won the polls, they informed.

Title: Insects play havoc again in Ramgarh
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Jaisalmer: Once again a huge number of locusts have attacked crops in Ramgarh area of Jaisalmer district. Revenue minister Harish Choudhary visited the Ramgarh canal area on Sunday after the locust attacked a huge area.

He visited Kheenya, Kheenvsar Navatala and other areas. The minister was accompanied by many officials. He met the farmers and assured them of all possible help. He also sought information about the loss. Agriculture department officials were directed to provide sufficient quantity of pesticides to farmers to control locusts. Farmers told the minister that throughout the night they sprayed pesticides.

The minister assured the farmers that girdawari would be conducted once again and no affected farmer shall be deprived of compensation.

Agriculture deputy director Radheyshyam Narwal said that nine vehicles of the department have controlled locust at Sonu, Narwar Singh ki Dhani, Ramgarh, Asutar Road, Kolhu, Satarwali, 16,17,18 Bhatia Miner etc.

District collector Namit Mehta has also directed locust control, agriculture department and other departments to control locust on priority basis.

Title: Aurangabad: MLA Sanjay Shirsath & deputy mayor booked for assaulting contractor
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Shiv Sena MLA Sanjay Shirsath, deputy mayor Rajendra Janjal and three others have booked by police on the charges of voluntarily causing hurt, criminal intimidation, unlawful assembly and rioting.

“Sena office-bearer, former corporator and contractor Sushil Khedkar was allegedly assaulted by the MLA and others at the MLA’s over the issue of tender for a road project on Saturday,” Vedantnagar police said while citing Khedkar’s complaint lodged on Sunday night.

When contacted by TOI, Shirsath refuted the allegations as baseless. “Khedkar came to my office in an inebriated condition and created a scene over awarding of the road contract to another party,” said the MLA from Aurangabad (west) assembly constituency.

As per the police station record, offences have been registered against the five under IPC sections 324, 323, 504, 506, 143, 147, 148, 149. Police source said that the sections are bailable in nature and that no one has been arrested yet.

Senior police inspector Rameshwar Rodge told TOI that technical evidence, like CCTV footage from in and around the spot of the alleged assault, is being collected to verify things before further action is taken.

According to the complaint, Khedkar, along with his friends Anup Mundada and Bhimrao Hegde, reached the MLA’s office on Saturday afternoon. The MLA allegedly told him to withdraw from the tendering of the said road work.

Khedkar has alleged that when he refused to withdraw the tender, the MLA allegedly slapped him. “Deputy mayor Janjal along with Raju Rajput, Anil Birare and Nilesh Narwade then assaulted him and his two friends,” he has alleged.

The MLA, however, said, “I had promised the people in Satara Deolai that I would get a road constructed soon after the elections and got special funds of Rs 10 crore from the CM. After the tenders were issued, bids were accepted and even work orders were released. Khedkar objected to it, resulting into delay of work by four months and re-tendering.”

Citing some of the previous works carried by Khedkar through his kin, the MLA said the complainant has a poor track record as far as quality and punctuality of work is concerned. “Unhappy over not getting the work order, he started creating hurdles in the work bagged by another contractor and created a ruckus at my office.”

Deputy mayor Janjal said, “The contractor has been misusing the Shiv Sena tag and pressuring different officials for getting his works done. He was drunk when he came to the MLA’s office and started abusing everyone. In fact, i tried to pacify him, but he has framed me in the case.”

Janjal said that Sena district president and MLC Ambadas Danve was also present at the spot when Khedkar created a scene.

Title: Drive against road rule violations from next week
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: After holding a week-long road safety awareness drive across the city, the motor vehicles department along with the squads of regional transport office (enforcement), Thiruvananthapuram , will begin checking at various locations in the city from next week to nab defaulters.

A drive to create awareness about MV Act Amendment and safety violations was conducted by the squad in association with NCC cadets at Manaveeyam road and Kowdiar last week, as part of road safety observance.

“The awareness drive was held to educate motorists. Since, most of the squads were sent on Sabarimala duty, the checking was conducted by two squads. After other squads return to the city, they will begin checking,” said Bijumon K, RTO, enforcement.

There are seven enforcement squads under Thiruvananthapuram RTO Enforcement that functions round-the-clock under different shifts. In the combined checking drive, the squads will be assigned specific locations in the city limits to conduct inspection simultaneously. In the previous combined drive held at seven routes in the city, the squads collected a penalty of Rs 2,13,500 from 214 check reports for various road safety violations.

Speaking about the need for strict checking, Bijumon added that motorists are reluctant to wear helmets. “Combined inspection at different locations will help spot defaulters more easily.”

“The helmet rule is not strictly followed by motorists. When compared to people in rural Kerala , city dwellers are more prone to checking and hence most of them obey rules. Irrespective of where they stay, people should understand the need for following rules,” he added.

Title: I-T dept raids hotelier Jyotsna Suri, brother
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representational photo.

NEW DELHI: The income tax department on Monday conducted raids at the premises of Bharat Hotels chairperson and managing director Jyotsna Suri and her associates in connection with an alleged tax evasion case. Bharat Hotels operates several five-star hotels and resorts across the country. Its flagship property is The Lalit in central Delhi.

The tax department also raided the premises of Jayant Nanda, managing director of Cargo Motors, the largest dealer of Tata Motors’ commercial vehicles in the country. It has dealership outlets in Delhi, Gujarat , Punjab and Rajasthan .

According to sources, eight locations were covered in the raids which continued late into the evening. The tax department did not share any details of the operation. However, sources said transactions of the two groups, which were being probed, were related.

Jyotsna Suri, a former chairman of industry body Ficci, has been associated with the Bharat Hotels group since 1989 and took over as CMD in 2006 after the death of her husband Lalit Suri .

Title: Cold wave kills thousands of hens, chicks in central Gujarat
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The temperature in Bhatpur village of Sankheda plummeted below the average resulting in high mortality among t... Read More

Vadodara: Non-vegetarians are delighted in winter as this season is considered best time to gorge on eggs and chicken. But poultry farms seem to have badly hit for an unusual reason- bitter cold - at a time when they were looking at brisk business.

Thousands of hens and chicks in poultry farms in Chhota Udepur and parts of Vadodara district had died due to cold in the last fortnight.

The average temperature in the region may have hovered around 12 degrees but in some parts, due to open farms, the mercury may have plummeted further, resulting in high mortality among the fowls.

At a poultry farm near Bhatpur village in Sankheda, around 1,100 hens and chicks died over the weekend. “The temperature has fallen due to which these sudden deaths have taken place. Every year few fowl die, but this year the number is unusually high, that too in a short span,” said the owner of the poultry farm Deep Patel. On Monday morning too, 26 deaths were reported at Patel’s farm.

In Vadodara’s Padra taluka, around 4,000 hens have died in a single poultry farm this season. Saddam Abbas Chauhan, who owns six farms, said that the caretaker of the particular farm did not take proper precaution. “I have let out the farm to a caretaker who did not take precautionary measures at all,” said Chauhan. He added that there has been no mortality at his other farms this year, but in the past fowls have died. “The figure has never been this huge,” he said.

In two other poultry farms near Malu and Bhatpur villages in Sankheda, 149 hens died over the weekend. The owners of these farms refused to coment, but cold is being blamed as the reason behind it.

Chauhan, who is in this business for around eight years, said that if it is a small poultry farm, the owner is going to face loss. “But if the farm is huge or the owner has several other farms then the loss can be covered,” Chauhan said. He further added that although deaths have been reported at many farms it is unlikely that meat prices are going to increase.

“I have heard about mortality at many poultry farms. But there are many players who will fill the supply gap,” he told TOI.

Deaths due to cold a common phenomenon

Deaths of hens and chicks due to low temperature is a common phenomenon, but this can be avoided if poultry farm owners take precautions. “Normal body temperatures of birds range from 104 oF to 109 oF. Their bodies cannot low temperature during winters as they feel stressed,” said Dr Divyesh Kelawala from Anand Agricultural University. “Poultry farm owners have to take utmost care so that the cold winds do not enter the cage,” he added. Kelawala, however, found the death figures humongous. He said that thousands of birds dying in certain number of farms is surprising. “It could be because the owner did not take proper care or because of some outbreak,” he said.

Title: Rajasthan goats to be tagged with QR code for quality
Content:
This will help buyers to check the last date of vaccination, diseases of goats and medicines given for it (Fil... Read More

JAIPUR: To ensure quality and provide safe-to-eat goat meat for consumers, the Rajasthan government has decided to tag goats meant for consumption with QR codes. This will help buyers to check the last date of vaccination, diseases of goats and medicines given for it. All information will be available online and customers can also order tagged goats online.The state has the largest population of goats in the country, with the Livestock Census 2019 recording over 20 million goats. The government has started a pilot project for the same in Pisangan gram panchayat in Ajmer.This initiative has been undertaken by the Rajasthan Agriculture Competitiveness Project (RACP) along with the Rajasthan Animal Husbandry Department. RACP has created the Pisangan Mahila Bakri Palak Producer Company Ltd (PMBPPCL) in Pisangan with a group of women shareholders who will run the project.At present, 350 women are shareholders in the company in Pisangan which has set a target of tagging 10,000 animals in the first phase.State agriculture commissioner and director of RACP Om Prakash said, “We have tagged more than 300 goats for the project and have set a target to cover 10,000 animals in the coming days.”“The lady link workers (LLW) will go door-to-door with a veterinarian to tag the goats and maintain their digital records. We are trying to make goat meat in the state safe as done in foreign countries,” Prakash said.In December 2019, the government launched the website www.rajasthangoat.com for consumers to order tagged goats online.Pritpal Singh Kalra, project coordinator of RACP, said that this project would give a good online marketing platform for goat farms. “Goats should be vaccinated 15 days before being taken to slaughter house. This project will ensure that and help goat farmers sell them online. We have launched a mobile app called ‘Rajasthan Goat’ though which customers can track their goats,” said Kalra.Currently, only the Sirohi breed of goats are tagged and sold under the project. Later, after the project is implemented in the entire state, other breeds will also be included. While the project is only meant for meat production now, it will later include milk as well.

Title: ‘Give us land to build Ram temple’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The model of the Bal Mandir

Allahabad: Ramjanmabhoomi Ramalaya Nyas secretary Swami Avimukteshwaranand Saraswati has said that “the construction of temple at Ayodhya could begin only after the government hands over land to the nyas (trust), which represents four Shankaracharyas, five Vaishnavacharyas and 13 akhadas.”

“Ramalaya Nyas is the apex body of dharmacharyas of Sanatan Hindu dharma (religion) and has informed the government of its commitment to build the temple. The work would begin once the land is handed over to the nyas. If it is overlooked, the move would be opposed and dissatisfied people could even approach courts,” Saraswati said here on Monday.

He said Jyotishpeethadishwar Jagatguru Shankaracharya Swami Swaroopanand Saraswatiji Maharaj had started the symbolic construction of a Ram temple by offering prayers to Sun God on the occasion of Makar Sankranti.

“According to shastras, a new temple cannot be constructed at a site which has once been demolished. Hence, we would a construct a ‘Bal Mandir’ of sandalwood first before starting with the actual. The temple’s dimensions would be 24x24x36 foot. The singhasan (throne) on which Ram Lalla would sit on would be made of gold and would be around 6x6x9 foot.
