The space in Nehru market in city, where they operated the advisory company was even not registered in name of company’s office. Dwivedi had registered 30 companies for this purpose, police said.

In these companies, Dwivedi’s wife Neha Dwivedi, brother Amit Dwivedi, Vijay Dwivedi, Rakesh Singh Tiwari, Piyush Sharma, Rahul Sharma were working as directors. These people were operating as an organized group for duping people, police said.

Police have also received information about preparing fake documents by chartered accountant, accountant and company secretary. Police will enquire them about details of the case.

Dwivedi was booked in several fraud cases earlier too. He has been on the run after being out on bail in one other fraud case, police said.

Police during raid recovered documents of eight companies registered in his name in Mumbai. Police is investigating it.

Title: Bamu starts online tracking system for official documents
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (Bamu) has started an online file tracking system on pilot basis to keep a check on inward and outward movement of official documents .

Last year in July, Bamu vice-chancellor Pramod Yeole had announced sweeping reforms in the functioning of the university, including the e-office system. The file-tracking system is considered as the backbone of the e-office.

Bamu public relations officer Sanjay Shinde said over 300 university staffers have been imparted with necessary training as a part of adopting the file tracking system.

“The file tracking system will enable tracing the journey of any file, document or note right from its inward at any of the university departments till logical action is taken in response to it. The system will by default produce a time-log showing the time taken for the necessary action at every section of the university. The online reform, thus, will give an exact account of official time spent in responding to every internal or external communication,” he said.

The file tracking system is basically a web-based application to monitor the official pendency and assist in their hassle-free tracking for speedy disposal. The system offers a range of benefits such as indexing the communications and files, updating its status, tracking the movement of the communications and online records management.

Bamu authorities said the high-tech measure would ensure necessary accountability and transparency in the university functioning.

“The new system will ensure decisions get implemented in the least possible time required. It will also speed up implementations of different official communications related to different stakeholders,” a Bamu official said.

Title: Govt-aided school in UP suspends teacher for being part of ‘violent protest’ during anti-CAA stir
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

BIJNOR: A government-aided school in UP’s Bijnor district has suspended a social science teacher after his name cropped up in an FIR filed by local police against those who indulged in arson and rioting during anti-CAA protest on December 20. Afzal Qureshi was booked in Bijnor’s Nahtaur town for taking part in the “violent protest”.

The protesters turned violent in eight cities of Bijnor. The worst-affected was Nahtaur where two persons-- Suleman and Anas-- were shot dead. Soon after the violence, police filed 34 cases against 3,900 protesters in the entire district and arrested 149 of them. In Nahtaur alone, 39 people were named while 2,200 unnamed were booked for the arson. Qureshi was among those named in the FIR and was missing since then, police said.

When contacted, Nahtaur station house officer (SHO) Satya Prakash claimed, “Afzal Qureshi, a teacher in HMI College Nahtaur, was one of the masterminds of the protest. Police had registered a case against him soon after the violence. Since then, he is on the run.”

The protesters have been booked under various sections of Indian Penal Code (IPC), including sections 147 (punishment for rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapon), 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 336 (act endangering life or personal safety of others), 427 (mischief causing damage), 436 (mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to destroy house, etc), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), and 120-B (criminal conspiracy). Some of them, who were seen indulging in violence, were also slapped with section 307 (attempt to murder) of IPC.

The decision to suspend Qureshi was taken by the school management. Talking to TOI, principal of the college, Sayyad Bilal Zaidi, confirmed the suspension. He said, “There was winter vacation on December 20, the day violence erupted here. Later, we were told by police that Qureshi was named in an FIR in connection with the violence. Since then, he was continuously absent. We have suspended him.”

When contacted, district inspector of school Rajesh Kumar said the school management has informed him about the suspension.

Title: NRI bizman linked to Robert Vadra arrested
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: C C Thampi, a Dubai-based NRI businessman, has been arrested by the Enforcement Directorate during the weekend in a money laundering case against Congress president Sonia Gandhi ’s son-in-law Robert Vadra . The latter has already had more than 13 interrogation sessions with the ED in the past two years in connection with acquiring undisclosed properties in Dubai, London and some other foreign countries.

Thampi, as he had admitted before the ED investigating officers earlier, was introduced to Vadra by Sonia Gandhi’s personal assistant P P Madhavan . Thampi was managing Vadra’s alleged front entities in Dubai, including Skylight Hospitality FZE and Skylight Investment FZE that later purchased London properties and a villa in Dubai.

After investigative agencies started trailing Vadra’s connection with Thampi, the latter transferred his 100% shareholding in Skylight Investment FZE, which consists of 1 share of Dirham 1,50,000, to the son of his stepsister, Vadakkethala Cheru Geever, who now owns through this shell company, the London flat at 12 Ellorton House, Bryanston Square, worth Rs 26 crore, and the Dubai villa (E-74, Jumeirah) worth over Rs 14 crore.

The agency suspects these are benami properties of Vadra held in the name of Geever. A multi-agency probe by the Indian government in the past two years revealed that Skylight Investment FZE, now May Fair Investment FZE, had no real business activity and yet huge cash deposits were made in its account just before the purchase of the London flat and the Dubai villa.

Skylight Investment was renamed May Fair Investment FZE on March 30, 2013 soon after the income tax department searched premises of defence dealer Sanjay Bhandari in Delhi-NCR to trail the transactions. Bhandari had first purchased the London flat at Bryanston Square with alleged payoffs from a South Korean multinational conglomerate that had benefited from an oil contract with ONGC. This flat was later transferred to Skylight.

The latest provocation was Thampi evading ED questioning related to some alleged financial transactions routed through Cyprus that the agency suspects have been conducted on behalf of the Congress chief’s son-in-law. Thampi has also claimed during his earlier interrogation that Vadra had stayed at the London flat at 12 Bryanston Square, a fact the latter has denied.

According to information received by the ED from UAE authorities, May Fair Investment had till December 2010 declared assets of Dirham 94,83,893 (Rs 12 crore); a villa in Dubai for Dirham 107,41,996 (Rs 14 crore) and a London flat worth Dirham 202,25,889 (Rs 26 crore). May Fair Investment does not have any business activity and its bank account was opened on March 31, 2009 with AED 1,50,000 (Rs 19 lakh). All the assets acquired were through cash deposits in its accounts, sources said.

Vadra’s Skylight Hospitality Pvt Ltd in India is facing multiple money laundering cases in which the agency has already attached his Sukhdev Vihar house besides other assets worth over Rs 4.62 crore. Vadra was questioned last February related to these transactions and his association with Thampi. However, he had denied any knowledge of these transactions.

Thampi is facing other cases of Foreign Exchange Management Act (Fema) violations in purchase of agricultural land in Delhi-NCR and Kerala . In 2017, he was issued summons by the ED for acquiring about 900 acres of land for Rs 288 crore in violation of Fema rules. Three of his companies involved in the case include Holiday City Centre Pvt Ltd, Holiday Properties Pvt Ltd and Holiday Bekal Resorts Pvt Ltd.

“Thampi had acquired huge agricultural land in Palwal, NCR, and Gautam Buddha Nagar, UP, through the above mentioned firms, which he otherwise would not have been able to purchase, being an NRI,” a senior ED official said.

Title: Locals demand water & proper sanitation
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hyderabad: All major parties including TRS, Congress, BJP are contesting municipal election in Adibatla . Party offices have surfaced in many parts ahead the polls.

Residents, however, want the public representatives to solve water and sanitation problems.

While apartments have surfaced in the area, there are a lot of open plots too, and the area sports a deserted look post 8pm.

“Some people throw garbage in open plots as most of them are private properties, and cleaning them is not on the priority list of the municipality,” said Naveen, a resident of Adibatla. People said that despite the area wearing a deserted look, there are no security concerns.

“We can see a patrolling car near outside the apartment regularly even in wee hours,” said a women from Yasvin Crescent Park near TCS.

Anil M, from Trans Elrte Apartment, said: “Whenever candidates visit us to seek votes we ask them for water.”

Title: Ahmedabad: Tennis academy damaged by spurned coach, fitness trainer
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

AHMEDABAD: High-tech instruments of a tennis academy in the Sola area of the city,which is claimed to have world-class facilities, were allegedly damaged by two men — a coach and a fitness trainer as they were sacked.

A police complaint filed in the case states that the academy incurred a loss of Rs 24 lakh and the two men including a fitness trainer and a Serbian national, Dusan Stevic and a senior tennis coach, Pavan Patel had also fled with a raptor machine worth Rs 2.50 lakh.

In his FIR with the Sola high court police, Chirag Patel, 43, a resident of Sola, said that he had installed high-tech tools to play tennis in his academy and had tied up with a renowned tennis coach, Alexander Vaske. He had also sent photographs of his tennis academy and instruments to Vaske as well, states the FIR.

On January 6, Chirag found that various instruments like body composition machine and quickboard machine having a total worth of Rs 4 lakh were damaged. The machines were kept in a room which was locked and its keys were with Stevic, states the FIR.

When Chirag checked another room, he found that a raptor machine was stolen by someone. Apart from that, six out of nine tennis court were damaged as someone had poured white oil paint on it. This caused a loss of around Rs 20 lakh to the academy, states the FIR.

Chirag said that Stevic and Pavan were working with the academy and were sacked in December 2019. After that, they had been approaching different players in their academy. Chirag has mentioned in the complaint that he suspects the duo behind the incident.

Sola police have registered a case of theft and damage to the property and started a probe.

Title: Sweet shop owners told to put up boards against used cooking oil
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Meerut: Sweet shops in the city have been asked to put up boards stating that they don’t reuse food oil, in the backdrop of the Repurpose Used Cooking Oil (RUCO) initiative through which the government has asked owners to collect reused cooking oil and send it for conversion to biodiesel. Also, the district authorities have asked officials to spread awareness about adulteration among government school students.

Archana Dheeran, FSDA designated officer of Meerut, said, “All the sweet shops in the city have been asked to put up display boards which read that they do not reuse cooking oil. The initiative is to promote the conversion of cooking oil to biodiesel. FSDA teams are now asking city shops to not reuse cooking oil more than three times – as the consumption of food items cooked with such oil can cause damage to the kidney, liver and even heart.”

Under the RUCO initiative, the collection and conversion of used cooking oil to biodiesel is being done by a Haryana-based company. According to sources, most of the shop owners either throw away used oil or sell it to rural areas.

FSDA authorities collected 517 samples during 2,783 inspections from April to December 2019, out of which reports for only 440 samples have been received. Out of these, 130 were found to be substandard, 44 unsafe and 73 misleading.

“Meanwhile, instructions have also been given to spread awareness among government school students about food adulteration. With this, they will be able to report such issues whenever they find anything amiss,” added Dheeran.

Title: Bargarh farmers fail to sell paddy, block road for 3 hours
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

SAMBALPUR: Farmers on Monday blocked Padampur-Saraipali road at Lakhmara College chowk in Padampur of Bargarh district for more than three hours after their paddy could not be procured as the online registration of the farmers under the Paddy Procurement Automation System (P-PAS) had not been done.

The farmers started the road blockade by placing paddy bags and paddy-laden vehicles on the road at 10am. Vehicular movement was disrupted due to the agitation by the farmers. Hundreds of vehicles remained stranded on either side of the road.

Farmer leader Hara Bania said, “The farmers had submitted all the documents with the Lakhmara primary agricultural cooperative society (PACS) for the online registration under P-PAS. However, due to official negligence, the registration of 308 farmers under the Lakhmara society had not been done. As a result, the farmers were barred from selling their paddy.”

He further said the farmers had several times drawn the attention of the authorities over the issue. However, their concern remained unheard and as a result the farmers were forced to resort to road blockade on Monday, he said.

“The farmers here earn their livelihood from paddy farming and it is the economic backbone but though we harvested paddy, we are now unable sell our produce. As the paddy is yet to be sold, the farmers are unable to pay their outstanding dues for tractor, pesticide and fertiliser, which they had borrowed for farming,” said an agitating farmer.

Police rushed to the spot to discuss with the agitating farmers. The farmers withdrew the road blockade at 1.30pm after the sub-divisional police officer (SDPO), Padampur, P K Sahu discussed with them and assured them that he would talk to the departments concerned to solve the problem.

Title: Corpn awaiting fund to restore Sanganur canal
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Coimbatore: Five years after late chief minister J Jayalalithaa made announcements to restore and rejuvenate the 11.5 kilometre-long Sanganur canal that flows across the city, the city corporation is still waiting for funds to implement the project.

The project was announcement during the Coimbatore corporation mayoral election in 2014. It was decided to strengthen the bunds of the canal and build roads on both the sides of the bunds for vehicles after relocating the families residing along it. The corporation had prepared a detailed project report (DPR) and submitted it to the State government for approval.

“We recently submitted a proposal to the state government to restore the canal and sought money from the infrastructure and amenities fund. Instead of submitting it as a single proposal, we divided the project into three stages based on the number of proposed stretches,” corporation commissioner J Sravan Kumar said.

The civic body proposes to develop the stretches connecting Mettupalayam Road, Sathy Road, Avinashi Road and Trichy Road. While the cost to develop the stretch connecting Mettupalayam Road and Sathy Road is estimated to be Rs 80 crore, the stretch connecting Sathy Road and Avinashi Road is estimated to be 30 crore and that connecting Avinashi Road and Trichy Road, Rs 20 crore.

“We are confident of obtaining approval at least for one stretch soon. The fund will be used for strengthening the bunds and other restoration activities,” the commissioner said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Man falls into gigolo gig trap, gets blackmailed
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 29-year-old Ayurveda teacher from Nikol fell into a trap set by a woman he met on Facebook , named Firoza Taili , who told him that she put women looking to buy sex in contact with men willing to provide service to them for a fee.

According to the FIR, about a month and a half ago, he got a friend request from a Facebook ID ‘Firoza All Gujarat’, with a profile picture of a good-looking woman.

The man then accepted the request. After five days, Firoza sent him a picture of another good-looking woman and told him of the gigolo gig.

“Firoza then told him that he would have to create an account and he would have to pay a fee of Rs 6,500 for it. She also told him that he would have to go through a medical test. She asked him to take off his clothes and show her his fully naked body,” a police source said.

Police sources said he showed her his body through a video call.

She then told him to pay Rs 6,500 into a bank account in the name of one Rushi Prajapati, which he did. After this, Firoza told him that she had a debt of Rs 20,00,000 and if he didn’t pay her Rs 30,000, she would publish his nude video on social media. She also said the demand will multiply if money was not paid immediately.

The FIR states that she finally demanded Rs 5 lakh. The mansaid he will commit suicide, to which she said that she doesn’t care.

The man then spoke to his friend who told him to go to police. Inspector H B Zala of Nikol police station said they have a suspects’ list but no arrest has been made.

Title: Safety pledge must before getting driver’s licence
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The applicants who are awaiting their driving licences and those seeking the renewal of their permanent licences will have to take the road safety pledge now. The office of Maharashtra Transport Commissioner has issued directives to this effect to all regional transport offices (RTOs) in the state.

The pledge which emphasises on the basic road safety rules such as wearing a helmet, avoid drinking and driving, and staying away from the road rage , has been framed by Mumbai-based advocacy group Public Concern for Governance Trust (PCGT).

Ana Saldanha, one of the trustees of PCGT on Monday said that the mandatory road safety pledge before issuing a driving license was expected to inculcate traffic sense among citizens.

“Traffic rules are easy to follow or break. Youths are particularly vulnerable to breaking them, which causes accidents. The mandatory pledge before getting a driving license will inform applicants of the basics road safety norms,” he said.

“We observed measurable outcomes of the initiative, following which the output of the project was shared with top authorities of the state transport department. The idea to administer a pledge was appealing by the officials, who later decided to make it a part of the process of issuing the driving license,” Saldanha said.

A senior RTO official said making the road safety pledge compulsory would bring down the road accidents.

Title: Republic Day alert: Report early at Kolkata airport for extra checks
Content:
A bomb disposal squad and sniffer dogs outside the terminal

KOLKATA: Ahead of Republic Day, security has been stepped up at the city airport, where flyers have to undergo a second round of frisking and detailed scanning of their footwear and hand bags. Given the additional checking, which is lengthening the queues, the airport authorities as well as airlines have asked passengers to report at least three hours in advance to ensure they don’t get late for boarding.For registered luggage, a second layer of manual checking has been introduced even after the bags have passed through x-ray. CISF officers said the tightened security measures were holding up flyers for at least an hour to 90 minutes before they could proceed towards security check-in. The enhanced frisking at the security check counters also led to long queues that almost reached the gates during the morning and evening peak hours.The safety measures have been tightened since Sunday after a red alert was issued to all “sensitive” airports in the country. The red alert will be in force till January 31, till any further order is given out. According to the protocol, the checking is starting right outside the airport gate, followed by manual frisking at multiple points inside the airport and a second round of scanning between the boarding gate and the aircraft in the airside area. “Strict security measures, including ladder point check, have been enforced at the airport. We request our esteemed passengers to report early & cooperate with the authorities. Any inconvenience caused is regretted,” tweeted the Kolkata airport authorities on Monday. “We have begun sending texts to flyers to report at least three hours early,” said an airline official.“We are organising intensive random checks in the city side of the airport, setting up check nakas at the approach to the premises. Any vehicle, seeming suspicious, are being stopped and checked thoroughly using under-view mirrors. The vehicles’ boot and interior are also being checked,” said a senior airport official. He added the bomb disposal squad and sniffer dogs have been posted outside the airport and two QRT vehicles stationed at two ends.The deployment of CISF has been double. Inside the terminal, over two dozen plainclothed personnel have been for random scanning of flyers on the go. Another checkpoint has been set up between the terminal boarding gate and the aircraft, where passengers are being stopped and their hand bags are being checked. “We have asked airline officials and CISF personnel to be courteous while asking passengers to cooperate. We have issued advisory to passengers, asking them to report early and be patient,” said airport director Kaushik Bhattacharjee.

Title: Andhra Pradesh assembly passes bills paving way for three capital cities
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Y S Jaganmohan Reddy

VIJAYAWADA: Amid uproarious scenes, the Andhra Pradesh assembly on Monday night passed two bills paving way for three capital cities in the state, signalling the end of the road for the much-touted greenfield capital in Amaravati.

With the passing of the two bills, the YSRC government led by Y S Jaganmohan Reddy scored a huge political victory over former chief minister and TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu.

Unfazed by the ongoing protests by farmers in the capital city region in Amaravati, the government introduced the two bills for trifurcation of the capital. After the day-long discussion on both bills, the assembly passed the bills with voice vote after Speaker Tammineni Sitaram suspended 17 TDP legislators. TDP is now planning to stall the bill in the legislative council where it enjoys majority.

On Monday morning, the cabinet met ahead of the assembly session and approved the bills which were then discussed in the assembly Business Advisory Committee (BAC) meeting. After the BAC meeting, the bills were introduced in the assembly paving the way for the trifurcation of the capital.

Finance minister Buggana Rajendranath introduced the Andhra Pradesh Decentralisation and Inclusive Development of All Regions (APDIDAR) Act 2020.

Minister for municipal administration Botcha Satyanarayana introduced the Andhra Pradesh Capital Region Development Authority Repeal Act 2020 that will replace the CRDA with Amaravati Metropolitan Region Development Authority (AMRDA).

The APDIDAR Act envisages three seats of governance in the state to be called as capitals. While the area under AMRDA will be called legislative capital, Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Area will be called the executive capital and Kurnool Urban Development Area will be deemed as the judicial capital.

The bill further proposed to locate the seat of legislature at Amaravati; Raj Bhavan, Secretariat and offices of heads of departments at Visakhapatnam; and to initiate steps to seek relocation of the principal seat of the high court at Kurnool and for the constitution of benches of the high court in accordance with the procedure prescribed under Andhra Pradesh Reorganisation Act, 2014.

According to the APCRDAR Act, the CRDA will cease to exist once it is passed. The areas under the APCRDA shall be deemed to be constituted as AMRDA. All the assets and liabilities both the current and contingent and bonds issued by the APCRDA with guarantee of the government shall stand transferred to and shall vest in AMRDA. The government will continue to be the guarantor for all loans availed by the APCRDA.

The government has made some key provisions in the bills to justify its policy of decentralised development. Apart from proposing three capitals for the state, the government has proposed to establish zonal planning and development boards. The government has also proposed a new package for farmers in the Amaravati capital region by extending payment of annuity for an additional five years at fixed amount per annum equivalent to the annuity of the 10th year. The government has also proposed to increase pension for farm labourers from Rs 2,500 to Rs 5,000 and equal package to farmers who hold assigned lands on par with regular farmers.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: AIMIM can dethrone any ruling party, says Akbaruddin Owaisi
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Akbaruddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: In a first such attack against its ally, MIM legislator Akbaruddin Owaisi , without naming TRS, said his party can place on throne or dethrone any party.

“Let it be Congress or Telugu Desam (TDP) or these motor car drivers, they all know who has ensured they sit on their throne,” said Akbaruddin Owaisi at a rally in Tandur ahead of the January 22 municipal poll. Car happens to be TRS symbol.

“If the strength of MIM ( All India Majlis-E-Ittehadul Muslimeen ) is behind their thrones, they should realise that Majlis knows how to dethrone them as well,” said Akbaruddin.

“Some TRS leaders are saying AIMIM is an Old City party. Arey TRS ke dewano (TRS supporters), don’t we have MLAs in Maharashtra and Bihar? Don’t we have an MP in Maharashtra? Arey TRS walo, does your party have an MLA outside Telangana?”

“In Andhra Pradesh they speak Telugu right? Then go there and win a seat,” he said. If Akbaruddin Owaisi starts speaking, your clothes will be torn, and tyres will turn upside,” he said.

On January 18, his elder brother Asaduddin Owaisi said the party could field candidates from TRS-held seats in Bodan and Nizamabad in the next assembly polls.

“AIMIM candidates might win from Bodan and Nizamabad, too. After municipal elections a plan will be rolled out,” Asaduddin had said. In 2018, Bodan, Nizamabad (urban) and Nizamabad (rural) was bagged by TRS.

In Tandur, addressing a large gathering, where MIM is locking horns with TRS and Congress for the January 22 polls, Akbaruddin said the MIM has the power to bend authorities while drawing a reference to the last Congress chief minister of undivided Andhra Pradesh, N Kiran Kumar Reddy.

“There used to be a chief minister of Andhra Pradesh, I don’t want to name him. In a public meeting, I said that he will be the Congress’s ‘akhri kiran’ (last ray). Wasn’t, he the last kiran? Where is he now, no one knows,” said the Chandrayangutta MLA.

“So please realise that the MIM has the power to bend anyone,” he said.

When Kiran Kumar Reddy was in power in 2013, Akbaruddin was jailed for 40 days for delivering a hate speech in Adilabad.

Later in his speech, Akbaruddin warned TRS directly and took pot-shots at animal husbandry minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav. “TRS khabardaar, apni zaban ko lagam doh, nahi to meri zaban chalne lageli (control your language or I will start speaking),” said Akbaruddin .

“KCR, KTR make them understand. There is a minister in Hyderabad, the Secunderabad MLA, who is saying MIM is an Old City party. Control your speech and talk according to your stature. If you have guts come and contest against me in Chandrayangutta,” said Akbaruddin.

Title: LIC directed to pay Rs 30,000 for failure to pay insurance money
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

KORAPUT: The district consumer disputes and redressal forum has pulled up the Koraput branch of the Life Insurance Corporation ( LIC ) of India for failing to pay the insured amount of Rs 30,000 to the nominee of a dead policy holder.

The forum, in its order pronounced on Monday, asked the LIC to pay the assured sum of Rs 30,000 with an interest of 6% per annum from April 6, 2016 within 30 days of the communication of the order.

The complainant Budra Pradhani is a resident of Pradhaniguda of Boipariguda block in Koraput district .

He said his father Baida Pradhani had bought an LIC policy bearing number 571394617 on July 22, 2006 and died on November 28, 2007 while the policy was in force.

However, Budra came to know of the policy in 2016 and applied for the assured amount on March 29, 2016. But the LIC authorities contended that any death intimation received after three years is barred by limitation and is not payable.

“As I was working as a labourer in Andhra Pradesh for 10 years from 2006 to 2016, I was unaware of the policy bought by my father. I came to know of it after returning to the village in 2016,” said Budra. “I had also produced a certificate obtained from the sarpanch of Chandrapada before the LIC authorities to substantiate my absence from the village,” he added.

Budra further said as he failed to get the assured amount from LIC, he approached the consumer forum to direct the opposition party to pay the sum with an interest of 9% and a compensation of Rs 50 per day from November 28, 2007.

After examining the case, verifying the documents and recording statements, the forum comprising its president Nibedita Rath and member Jyoti Ranjan Pujari, found the LIC guilty and directed it to pay the assured sum with an interest of 6% per annum.

“The complainant being the nominee is entitled to get the sum assured with interest. However, observing the peculiarity of the case, the forum is not inclined to grant interest from the date of the death of the policy holder but from the date of the filing of the case,” Rath said.

She added that the forum was not inclined to grant any compensation and cost in favour of the complainant as prayed for.

Title: Teacher wanted for killing wife held from Anand
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: The teacher from Anand , who had allegedly murdered his wife in Chhota Udepur on January 18, was arrested on Monday.

The accused, Mukesh Zala , was held from his home in Anand where he had fled to with his two kids after killing his wife Alpa.

Police said that the couple had heated arguments over dinner which escalated to murder. “The couple had been going through a rough phase as Mukesh used to remain suspicious over Alpa’s behaviour and other issues,” said a police official.

On the night of January 18, Mukesh picked up an iron griddle to slit Alpa’s throat and also hit it on her head. After she collapsed, Mukesh fled from there with their two sons. “He was hiding in Anand from where our team arrested him and also found the couple’s children,” the police official added. The two sons aged six and eight years are now with Mukesh’s father, who also lives in Anand.

Mukesh and Alpa were going through tension as he used to get angry over petty issues like why she would not answer his phone calls and not cook food. Alpa had moved to Gadh Boriyad village in Naswadi taluka seven months back as she had been teaching at a primary school in nearby Khareda village. Earlier, she used to commute daily between Anand and Khareda.

Title: GN Mills Flyover: Load test to be reconducted
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Coimbatore: The national highway wing of the state highways department has revised the project proposal for the GN Mills Flyover after the load test conducted to determine the bearing capacity of soil failed.

The department had launched work to construct the 670-metre flyover at GN Mills junction at a cost of Rs 41 crore in March. Months after the test piles were constructed, the department conducted load test by placing sand bags over them.

The work was stopped a couple of months ago after the load test failed, a senior official said. “We were planning to lay 10-metre deep foundation. Now that the test has failed, we have decided to increase the depth to 15 metres,” he told TOI.

Even as they continue to wait for the Centre’s nod for the revised proposal, the department constructed test piles about a week ago. “We will test the piles once again in another 20 days. Construction work will continue only if the test results are satisfying,” the official said. “Even though the work to increase the depth for laying foundation would incur additional cost, we are confident of managing the additional cost. The additional cost is expected to be close to Rs 30 lakh,” the official said.

K Kathirmathiyon, a member of the road safety committee, flayed the department for the fiasco. “Ideally, the bearing capacity should have been found out during the soil test itself. But, it is surprising that the department missed it. It is a rare incident,” he said.

“Project estimate is prepared based on the soil test result. Making changes at the implementation stage will escalate the cost and cause delay,” Kathirmathiyon added.

Title: Dolphin number 146, up from 113 last year in Chilika
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Only 113 dolphins were sighted in the lagoon last year against 162 dolphins in 2018

BHUBANESWAR: As many as 146 dolphins were sighted in the Chilika during the annual dolphin census by the forest department on Sunday. “The exact number of adults and calves will be provided by the wildlife wing in a few days after a detailed analysis,” said Susanta Nanda, chief executive of Chilika Development Authority (CDA), here on Monday.

Only 113 dolphins were sighted in the lagoon last year against 162 dolphins in 2018.

Motorised boats were prohibited on the day of census work. Eighteen teams were deployed. Binoculars with GPS tracking systems were used for the first time in counting dolphins, forest official sources said. Result of dolphin census indicated population of 150+ for the first time in the Chilika. “Clear colonisation of newer areas gives hope for the future, Nanda tweeted. He said “This is only a vet estimate of CDA done round the year by using hydrophone. CDAs estimated population range was 133 to 172,” he added.

During their estimation through hydrophone, the CDA found these aquatic mammals at Magarmukh, Jahnikuda, Mahisa, Rajhans, Nalabana, Kalijugeswar, Malatikuda, Pathara, Samal Island, Kalijai Island, INS Chilika, Krishnaprasad Gada Jetty and Satapada Jetty.

The fresh census revealed that mammals are moving towards new areas in central and southern sectors near Kalijai island and Rambha areas. These areas were made free from prawn gheries, official sources said. Nanda said all pen cultures inside the lake have been removed. “CDA has reclaimed 160+ sq km of encroached area in the last two years. Thats almost 15% of the lake. Increased bird and dolphin population is mainly attributed to that,” he said, adding, “We can say the population is likely to increase in the next couple of years.

Title: Nagpur: School records mistakes hound many ahead of NPR, NRC
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Schools in the city are flooded with requests for modifications in leaving certificate

NAGPUR: Beside the civic body, schools in the city are flooded with requests for modifications in leaving certificate, the next most important document after birth certificate to prove place and date of birth in view of government implementing National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

With principals and Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) officials themselves confused, citizens, mainly Muslims, are in a fix. The main problem is a mismatch in records of NMC birth and death registration department and leaving certificate issued by schools.

Modification seekers are people who were admitted in schools based on verbal submissions regarding their date of birth (DoB) and those who passed out from Urdu and Hindi-medium or those run by gram panchyats and zilla parishad schools. These have their proof of address and identity as per NMC record.

At a time when most people did not have civic birth certificates, schools would record ‘1/7’ (July 1) as the day and month of birth for children while admitting them. Now this is not tallying with NMC records that are being referred to issue birth certificates as a measure to establish citizenship.

While DoB remains an issue, spelling, addition of a parent’s name and place of birth too are posing challenges for those having leaving certicates in Hindi.

“Over 90% students enrolled with us are seeking corrections,” said Ayaz Syed, principal of Gandhibagh’s Shivaji Night School set up in 1978. He added the first mismatch happens in leaving certificate and the board marksheet as formats are different.

Syed said, “Main reason for this panic is people never thought they would one day have to prove citizenship and went on to include names in school records as per their whim.” Right now, Syed said, the school was asking people to first get correction published in government gazette or bring a JMFC court order.

Even after getting this done, schools are not sure what kind of changes they are authorized to make.

At Mominpura, principal of Taj Baba Night School Sayyed Muzammil is in a dilemma when people come to him with a gazette notification. “We need clarity from the education department on this. We are getting 10 to 12 requests for including place of birth in TCs everyday. If it is not in school records, we can’t do it,” he said.

Deputy director (Education) Satish Mendhe told TOI no change can be made in the general admission register. “It amounts to forgery unless the government issues any guidelines. We have not received any request from schools,” he said. Mendhe defended school records saying parents submit undertaking at the time of admission and details are not accepted on verbal submissions.

Mahal’s Anjuman High School principal Nazra Patel said cases pertaining to surname, caste of father or grandfather and a different first name have been routine affair at her school. “We don’t want to harass parents but can’t go against norms,” she said.

NMC medical officer and sub-registrar Ateequr Raheman Khan said schools must permit certain changes as per his department’s records. “In some cases there is difference in month of birth. We have original records. Based on this, schools must let people change them,” he said. Similarly, Khan said married women were facing probem of name change. “In such cases, an alias is allowed,” he said.
