Title: Poll campaign ends, SEC bans meetings
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hyderabad: The high-voltage campaign in 120 municipalities and nine municipal corporations in the last two weeks ended on Monday. The polling will be held on January 22 and the results declared on January 25.

Campaigning in Karimnagar municipal corporation will, however, end on January 22, as notification for polls in KMC was issued after it was released for other urban local bodies. KMC will go for polls on January 25 and results will be out on January 27.

The polls are going to be a litmus test for both Congress and BJP in proving their mettle in urban areas of Telangana, while TRS is exuding confidence of winning a lion’s share of municipalities and corporations.

The State Election Commission (SEC) said that since the campaigning had ended, no candidate should convene or hold or attend any public meeting or take out a procession. It also barred display of symbols and use of election paraphernalia by means of cinematography, television or any other modes.

SEC secretary Ashok Kumar said use of mobile phones and social media 48 hours prior to polling is also banned. “If any person deviates and campaigns, it is punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years or with a fine or both,” the secretary warned.

Title: Three lives lost in road accidents in two days
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representtaive imae

COIMBATORE: Three people were killed in three road accidents in rural areas in the last two days.

In the first incident, 25-year-old K Sivaraj of Manikandan Nagar at Perur Pachapalayam was killed after he lost control over his motorcycle and fell between the second and third hairpin bends of the Pollachi - Valparai Road on Sunday evening. “He was working as an administrative officer of an IT firm in Chennai and had come to celebrate the Pongal festival with his family. A few days ago, he had left for Periyakallar near Valparai to spent time with his cousins there. On Sunday evening, he returned to Pollachi along with his relative A Saranraj, 26, of Periyakallar, who was riding pillion,” a police officer said.

Sivaraj, who suffered serious injuries, was rushed to the Pollachi Government Hospital, where he died without responding to treatment. Saranraj suffered minor injuries.

The second victim, 56-year-old P Sundaram of Poochiyur near Narasimmanaickenpalayam, was also on a motorcycle when he met with the accident on Sunday evening. “The deceased was working as a driver. On Sunday evening, Sundaram and his wife S Chandramani were travelling on a motorcycle. When they reached Therkupalayam, he lost control over the vehicle and crashed into the median on the Mettupalayam – Coimbatore Road. He died on the spot. Chandramani suffered serious injuries and was admitted in the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital,” a police officer said.

In the third incident, a 53-year-old S Ramamurthy of Senkaliappapuram near Sulur was killed after a speeding TNSTC bus rammed his moped on the Coimbatore-Trichy Road near Sulur on Saturday evening. “He was working as a labourer and was heading towards Sulur from Coimbatore,” a police officer said.

Title: Kolkata: Five-year-old dies as old lamp post collapses in Ekbalpore
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The snapped lamp post at Ekbalpore that collapsed on the child

KOLKATA: A five-year-old boy died after an old KMC lamp post snapped in two and collapsed on him in Ekbalpore on Monday morning.

Hours before, Amit Das , along with his parents, had reached Kolkata from their home in Bihar’s Jamui to attend his cousin’s wedding . The child, who was admitted to CMRI Hospital with a fractured skull, brain injury and multiple wounds, died at night.

According to Amit’s cousin, Samir Das, the family reached their home in Ekbalpore around 7 am on Monday. The family said Amit’s father, Asoke, was a poor farmer in Jamui. Around 12.40pm, the child stepped out to play, when the lamp post fell on him, injuring him severely on the right side and back of his head. Police said he also suffered injuries on his chest and abdomen.

According to doctors at the hospital, the child was admitted to ICU and put on ventilation and kept under observation for his multiple injuries in his brain. Later at night, the hospital informed police that the child had died.

A KMC team from Borough IX visited the spot. An electrical department official working at the KMC headquarters said the lamp post had become vulnerable and was supposed to be replaced. “The lamp post was past its expiry date and plans were on to replace it. We never thought the post would collapse , leading to the unfortunate death of a child,” the official said. He added the department was asked to conduct a health survey of other such lamp posts in the area and submit a report at the earliest. “We will soon replace posts, which have become weak,” he said.

“From locals, we learnt the boy was playing in front of his reltive’s home, when the KMC street lamp post snapped into two and fell on him,” said an investigating officer, adding a case of death due to negligence had been lodged at the Ekbalpore police station.

A local said, “The lamp post is a single-light long beam post. This could have happened to anyone.”

Title: Coimbatore: Man sentenced to life imprisonment for raping minor
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

Title: Hardik Patel seeks bail after his arrest for absence in court
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hardik Patel

AHMEDABAD: The Congress party leader, Hardik Patel , filed a bail application in the city sessions court on Monday after he was arrested on Saturday evening on a warrant issued by the court for not attending the trial in sedition case here.

The court is likely to hear the bail application on Tuesday.

After his arrest from near his native Viramgam, Patel was sent to judicial custody by additional sessions judge B J Ganatra till January 24.

In his bail plea, Patel has proposed to give an undertaking that now onwards, he will take utmost care and will regularly attend the court proceedings without fail. He will never tender any adjournment application to delay the trial. Patel has claimed that he honours court proceedings and that he has never tried to protract the trial.

Patel has also said that he undertakes to examine the witness whenever the court calls him, and that no witness would go back the way a government undersecretary, Vijay Badheka, returned on Saturday without being cross-examined. He expressed regret that the witness had to return from the court without he being cross-examined. Patel has proposed to pay for the witness’s travel charges.

On Saturday, the court issued an arrest warrant against Patel on a request by public prosecutor Sudhir Brahmbhatt for Patel’s continued absence in courtroom during the trial of the 2015 sedition case. Patel had sought exemption from appearance during the proceedings on the ground that he had to attend a social function, but the court rejected his application.

Patel, the former convenor of the Patidar Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS), is facing the trial along with two others on sedition charges for inciting violence during the Patidar quota agitation in August 2015.

Title: Nagpur: Property worth Rs 3.5 crore gutted in Chandrapur supermarket
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Chandrapur Municipal Corporation fire department personnel had to battle for nearly five hours with the help o... Read More

CHANDRAPUR: A massive fire broke out in the popular departmental store Zee Bazar, located in the heart of the city, during the wee hours of Monday. No casualty was reported.

Chandrapur Municipal Corporation (CMC) fire department personnel had to battle for nearly five hours with the help of four fire engines and 25 water tankers to douse the fire. The store owner has claimed loss of Rs3.5 crore in the inferno.

Surprisingly, the supermarket building, spread in more than 3,000sqft area, lacked requisite fire safety arrangements mandated by the municipal corporation, official sources informed.

According to sources, security guard raised alarm at 3am after he saw smoke rising from the building. Chandrapur Municipal Corporation dispatched its three fire engines, while one was summoned from Chandrapur Super Thermal Power Station . Firemen had to break a wall of the building to start the dousing operations that continued for nearly five hours.

Police inspector Chandrashekhar Bahadure said Zee Bazar owners have claimed loss of daily needs goods and property to the tune of Rs3.5 crore. The police have started investigations to ascertain the cause of fire and would also check whether the establishment had fire safety clearance from the CMC.

NB- Photos sent to the Whatsapp group

Title: Blaming Manjeshwar for Mangaluru riots
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

CAA FAllout: A copy of the summons sent by Mangaluru cops

Kasaragod: Hundreds of people in Kasaragod district have received summons from Manguluru police asking them to appear before officials in Mangaluru and assist the probe into the violent anti-CAA protests that rocked the city on December 19, which left two persons dead in police firing. The notices, sent by assistant commissioner of police of Mangaluru city crime record bureau, have specified the date and time of their appearance, and warns the Kasaragod residents that failure to appear would be construed as “evading the investigation” and invite “further legal procedure”.

Thousands of people, including traders, fisherfolk, students and bank employees travel to and fro daily to Mangaluru from several towns like Manjeshwar in Kasaragod district. Manguluru is the biggest city in the vicinity and caters to their medial and commercial needs.

The majority of those who received the summons belong to a particular community and they seem to have been chosen based on their cell phone location on the day of the riots in Mangaluru. Several of these people contacted by TOI were incredulous on being implicated in the violence. “I run a crusher unit here and I was in Mangaluru on that day as part of some lathe work of the machinery; I knew there was some protests going on the city but I returned to Kasaragod soon after my work got over,” said Chengala resident Ahammed Ashif. He has been asked to appear before Mangaluru police officials on January 21. When he called another friend, from another community, who was also in Mangaluru on December 19, he discovered that his friend hasn’t got the notice.

Muhammed Kunhi, a fish trader from Manjeshwar, said many people from the fish-selling fraternity have got the notice. “We depend on Mangaluru to procure fish and earn our livelihood, but now we are being termed rioters just because we were there in the city on that day, that too many hours before the violence broke out,” he said.

As reported by TOI in its December 28 edition, a Karnataka government circular issued during the riots asking colleges in Dakshina Kannada district to keep a tab on students in Kerala had kicked up a storm. “They are falsely implicating innocent people; worse, they are insinuating that people from Kerala were behind the riots in Mangaluru. This is dangerous and questions the right of free movement of people even to neighbouring places,” said Kasaragod district panchayat member Ali Harshad Vorkady, who has taken up the issue with the authorities here. Vorkady said, in his estimate, around 1,800 people in Kasaragod district have got the notice from Manguluru police so far.

Incidentally, Rameela Moyyaddi from Hosabettu in Manjeshwar too has got a notice, though she was nowhere near Mangaluru on that fateful day. On Dec 19, Rameela’s husband Bawa Moyyaddi, a fish seller, had gone to procure fish from the city and had taken her cell phone, as he often does. “On getting the notice I was shocked, but later I came to know that many people like me have been served notice, even though we did not cross the state border that day,” she said.#

Title: If you can’t save Hyderabad lakes, resign: Telangana HC CJ to GHMC chief
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hussain Sagar lake

HYDERABAD: Upset with the affidavit filed by Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) that raised more questions than it answered, a division bench of Telangana high court headed by Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan on Monday asked GHMC commissioner Lokesh Kumar to resign if he could not protect city lakes .

The bench was furious as the GHMC — in its counter in a PIL based on media reports about miserable condition of Kukatpally lake and its adjacent pond — contended that it had no power to appoint employees at lakes to prevent dumping of garbage. The bench then referred to TOI reports highlighting how several lakes were being encroached and the CJ told officials to go through the newspaper if they were not aware of what was happening under their watch.

“Lakes are the lifeblood of humans and if they are destroyed, Hyderabad will become a Jaisalmer in the next 20 years,” the CJ warned. “This Rajasthan city faces such water shortage that officials have asked people to take bath only once in 15 days. If you want to convert Hyderabad into Jaisalmer, then you are welcome,” the CJ said.

The CJ also spoke about lakes in Hyderabad and in neighbouring Bangalore where effluents clandestinely released into them were turning into foam, making it dangerous for people.

The bench was also irked as GHMC counter claimed that lakes were regularly cleaned but no evidence was attached to substantiate it. Asking the GHMC commissioner to file a fresh counter, it posted the case to February 7.

Title: New law fails to deter harassment by loan sharks
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Loan sharks have been spreading their fins in the city. In the past one month, seven harried borrowers have lodged complaints with police, alleging harassment by moneylenders. Recently, there has also been a spike in cases of borrowers taking their lives, frustrated with their inability to repay hefty loan and interests.According to police sources, the loan sharks active in the city have been demanding up to 40% monthly interest from the borrowers. “The lenders can go to any extent to extort the hefty interest amount. From abduction to torture before family members, they resort to all illegal methods to terrorize the borrowers,” said a senior police officer.“Fed up with constant torture, people have been coming to us to file complaints. Though we have limited options, cases are being filed under sections of extortion and the money lending act, and in cases where the victim has committed suicide, under Section 306 (abetment to suicide),” the officer added.A furniture showroom owner in Chandkheda had paid double the amount he had borrowed, but got caught in the vicious circle of high interest rate. Unable to cope with the pressure and constant harassment by the lenders, he decided to end his life by jumping into the Narmada canal. In his suicide note, he had named the moneylenders threatening him.Several such cases have been registered in Ranip, Vastrapur, Nikol, Ramol and Krishnanagar police stations in city.

Title: ‘Bomb in bag’: Irritated flyer throws luggage at staffer at Kolkata airport, held
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Angered by the multi-level checking going on at the Kolkata airport , owing to red alert issued ahead of Republic Day, a 28-year-old youth threw his bag at a security officer on Sunday, saying “the bag contained bomb”.

Pradipta Bandopadhyay was about to board a flight to Bangalore, where he works at a private firm, around 5.30pm on Sunday, when he was stopped by a security officer of SpiceJet before entering the aircraft SG658. The officer told him to open his hand bag and asked him if there was any hazardous or dangerous bag. “The passenger had already undergone multiple screening. At being told to open his bag yet again, he possibly lost his cool and threw his bag at the officer, saying it contained a bomb. The officer isolated him, prevented him from boarding the flight and called the CISF officers,” said a senior airport official.

A SpiceJet spokesperson said when the flyer told the staff member that his hand bag had a bomb in it, the security staff lerted the CISF and local police and handed him over to them. Officers at Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International police station arrested him under sections of IPC and Safety of Civil Aviation Act for spreading panic. He was later released on bail. “No restricted item was found in his luggage. But going by the protocol, we had to seize the luggage and detain the man before handing him over to police,” an airport official said.

This was not the first time a passenger had been pulled out of a flight for making “threatening” remarks. On January 11, a Mumbai-bound Air Asia flight from Kolkata had to return after a 25-year-old drunk woman claimed she was carrying a bomb. She was later arrested though nothing dangerous was found on her. On November 2018, a 21-year-old youth on a Mumbai-bound flight was arrested after he posted a photograph of himself with his face covered with a handkerchief. A snooping fellow passenger spotted the words, ‘terrorist’ and ‘destroy’, in the photo caption and alerted the cabin crew, following which the youth was handed over to police.

Title: ‘My Stamp’ counter opens at Isha centre
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Coimbatore: The postal department opened a My Stamp counter at Ishana Vihar Post Office at Isha Yoga Center on Monday. The counter aims to create awareness on philately products among foreigners and people from across the country, who visit the spiritual centre .

My Stamp counters are usually set up only in headquarter post offices. The initiative could be be the first in the region.

My Stamp is the brand name of personalized sheets of India Post. Introduced in 2011, it allows people to print Rs 5 stamps with their picture or that of a loved one. One can choose for it to be scented also.

A statement from the department said that on the first day itself, about 50 My Stamp sheets were issued. The post office sees many foreigners using the international speed post service.

Postmaster general Sheuli Burman inaugurated the facility. TNN

Title: Wild elephant tramples man to death
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Coimbatore: A wild elephant trampled a 42-year-old man to death near Thoonimodi estate in Valparai on Sunday night.

The deceased was identified as P Suresh, a labourer who was working in the estate. “He was returning from a temple where arrangements were made for celebrating the Pongal festival when the elephant targeted him around 10pm. He was just 200 metres away from his house when he saw the animal. Though he tried to run back to the temple, it chased him and trampled him to death. He died on the spot,” a police officer said.

The family of the victim, along with villagers, stopped police and forest department officials, who arrived at the place to recover the body. They staged a protest seeking protection from wild animals. Subsequently, senior revenue, forest and police department officials held talks with the villagers and pacified them.

The body was sent to the Valparai Government Hospital for postmortem.

Title: Leaving Congress biggest blunder on my part: Dharmapuri Srinivas
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Senior politician and TRS Rajya Sabha member Dharmapuri Srinivas , popularly known as DS, said on Monday that leaving Congress was the biggest blunder of his 40-year long political career. The 71-year-old three-time MLA and former minister quit Congress on July 2, 2015, a year after Telangana was granted statehood by the then UPA government at the Centre in June 2014.

Days later, Srinivas joined TRS to realise the goal of what he termed a “bangaru (golden) Telangana.” However, his honeymoon with the ruling TRS did not last long. In the last couple of years, his relationship with TRS leadership strained further as he developed differences especially with former Nizamabad MP and chief minister’s daughter Kalvakuntla Kavitha. His younger son Dharmapuri Arvind is a BJP leader and represents Nizamabad in the Lok Sabha after defeating Kavitha in the 2019 elections.

Srinivas said he resigned from Congress owing to differences he had with the then Congress incharge of Telangana affairs Digvijaya Singh who, he said, had insulted him. Srinivas had served as the state Congress president twice and also as a minister in undivided Andhra Pradesh. He was the president of Andhra Pradesh Congress Committee when the party assumed power under the leadership of late YS Rajasekhara Reddy in 2004.

Ahead of the municipal elections, Srinivas dared the TRS leadership to take action against him. Speaking to newsmen in Nizamabad, he also took an indirect dig at chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao saying “father, son and daughter have become golden” in the name of achievign a golden Telangana.

He lambasted district TRS leaders for talking against him. He was reacting to the comments of minister Vemula Prashanth Reddy who, earlier in the day, said Srinivas did not do anything for Nizamabad despite serving as a minister, PCC chief and being in political life for 40 years. “Some people are asking me as to what I have done in the last 40 years. First, they should tell what they have done all these years.”

Srinivas said he allocated his entire MLA fund for a railway project in Nizamabad and also allocated funds for a sewer network. “I am ready to donate my house for a medical college building.” The former Congress chief said he did not speak on various issues earlier as he did not deem it right on his part to rake up controversies unnecessarily.

He appealed tothe people to vote for those who strive for development of Nizamabad.

Title: It’s back to camp politics ahead of civic poll results
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

HYDERABAD: Amid speculations of a close fight and horse-trading to grab chairperson and mayor posts in some municipalities and municipal corporations after the counting on January 25, major political parties are bracing up to shift elected councillors and corporators to ‘safer’ locations.

Sources said the parties are arranging high-end buses to places like Goa, Bengaluru and Kerala to shift the elected members to stop poaching by their rivals.

Though the election of municipal chairpersons and mayors is indirect, a close fight is on cards in about 30 municipalities in the erstwhile districts of Mahbubnagar, Adilabad, Nalgonda , Khammam and Nizamabad. TRS, Congress and BJP are seized of this.

The three major parties are not only wary of poaching in some of municipalities, but are also guarded about groups which could hamper their candidates’ prospects. In such cases, independent candidates and parties like All-India Forward Bloc are likely to play a key role in securing chairperson and mayor posts, sources said.

While TRS administered an oath to its candidates while issuing form-B that they would abide by the leadership’s decision on chairperson and vice-chairperson posts, Congress extracted affidavits from its candidates that they would be loyal to the party after getting elected. “We have been asked to not plan any programme or function till the end of January as we may have to attend camps if required,” a TRS contestant from Mancherial told TOI.

Before and during nominations, there were instances where TRS and Congress traded charges that their leaders were being poached. In areas like Peerzadiguda and Gajwel, leaders of TRS and Congress switched sides and came back to their parent parties.

Title: Gujarat: RTE admissions to begin in March
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Gujarat education department is likely to begin enrolling students under the Right To Education (RTE) Act at private schools in the state by March, said sources. The department will soon start preparing a database of the number of seats available at such schools in Class I, sources added.

The locations of schools will be mapped for students and parents to access online. The RTE Act defines the limits of a neighbourhood school, which can be at a maximum distance of 6km from the student’s habitation. “Only schools which within this limit will be shown while applying online,” said an official privy to the development. He said that only after gathering details of the total number of seats for Class I, will details about the seats under the RTE quota be announced. The RTE Act reserves 25% of seats at self-financed schools for students from economically disadvantaged groups.

In Ahmedabad, the district education officer (DEO) has set up a team to gather school details such as location, fees and number of seats, among others, according to sources.

Last year, more than two lakh RTE admission forms were received at 10,000 schools and government centres confirmed accepting 1.5 lakh of them after scrutiny. About 1.17 lakh seats were available under the RTE Act quota for the 2019-20 academic year. After the first round, admission was given to 98,859 students. tnn

Title: Kishan ridicules KTR’s devpt claims
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hyderabad: Union minister of state for home G Kishan Reddy on Monday took a dig at TRS working president KT Rama Rao for talking loud on development “though TRS government has done little for municipalities”. Addressing a campaign rally at Choutuppal in Yadadri district, Kishan alleged the state government had diverted central funds meant for municipalities to other programmes. tnn

Title: DTC misses bus, but Delhi Metro keeps transport going
Content:
File photo of DTC bus at a bus stand

NEW DELHI: At the bus shelter adjacent to Pearey Lal Bhawan on Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg, Sanjay Kumar, an office assistant in a private firm, strains his eyes to read the route number on the approaching Delhi Transport Corporation bus. He sighs as he notices that it is not running on route 502, which would have taken him home to Mehrauli. Kumar settles back on the steel seat, rubbing his hands for warmth on the chilly January evening. “The bus might come 10 minutes or in 50 minutes, there is no way of knowing,” he shrugs.“I prefer travelling by buses because the stops are close to my home and office, but their frequency has been worsening each year,” Kumar said. “I do travel by Delhi Metro , but only in a hurry. My bus fare is Rs 15, while I have to shell out Rs 36 for the metro, something I can’t afford on regular basis.”While Delhi Metro ferries approximately 30 lakh passengers a day, the combined DTC and Cluster scheme buses carry 42 lakh. Many, like Kumar, opt for bus travel, but the dwindling fleet strength is affecting their commute time. While Delhi needs around 11,000 buses, it has 5,789 on the ground.When the Aam Aadmi Party assumed power in February 2015, the DTC fleet numbered 4,712 and the Cluster scheme had 1,402. The number of DTC buses fell to 3,781 with ageing vehicles being scrapped, and despite floating and re-floating tenders, the company has been unable to induct new buses.AAP had promised before the last assembly polls that it would add ‘at least 5,000 new buses in five years’. The notable addition has instead been in the Cluster fleet, where the strength has gone up from 1,402 to 2,208, the new vehicles being part of the 1,000 standard-floor buses scheduled for induction from August 2019.In this discouraging scene for bus riders, the only silver lining has been the free rides provided by the state government for women. “There has been a dip in our family’s transport expenses,” iterated Jamaluddin in Mustafabad. “The government is bringing more buses and with their arrival travelling should become more comfortable.”Ambedkar Nagar resident Santosh Kumari similarly reported, “I’m saving at least Rs 500 a month thanks to the free bus rides. My daughter prefers to travel by Delhi Metro even though it is costlier. We hope train rides also become free for women.” This polls, AAP has promised 11,000 buses and total 500km metro network, apart from free travel for students and senior citizen, an assurance mirrored by Congress. BJP has committed to inducting 5,000 electric buses for public transport if it comes to power.With the bus system hobbled, Delhi Metro has taken on the daily onus of moving Delhiites. It has grown from a network of 193km to 349km and from 147 stations to 253 stations in the last five years, adding three new corridors — the Pink, Magenta and Grey Lines. At 2019-end, the Phase IV of its network expansion was also cleared.The extended connectivity has been particularly welcomed in Najafgarh and Matiala constituencies. The Grey Line, slated to touch the Dhansa border, is functional up to Najafgarh. Neeraj Singh, who lives in Jaffarpur Kalan in Najafgarh, was quick to credit the local MLA and Delhi transport minister Kailash Gahlot for ‘fulfilling his promise’ of delivering Delhi Metro to Najafgarh. “Once it reaches Dhansa border, things will become even better for us,” Singh said. “Many people who otherwise have to take buses and autos to exit the area can now ride a train.”While Delhi Metro has reached almost all parts of the city now, last mile connectivity is still elusive. Before the 2015 polls, AAP had promised effective connectivity to reduce the number of crimes against women through a combination of shared autos, metro feeder services and e-rickshaws. Delhi Metro is yet to induct new feeder buses due to a fund crunch, while lack of regulation has turned the profusion of e-rickshaws into a traffic problem.“There should be multiple facilities, such as two-wheeler services or e-cycles depending on the need of the area,” suggested Atul Goyal, president of United Residents Joint Action (URJA), an umbrella body of RWAs. Goyal added that with proper norms, e-rickshaws can be incorporated into the local area plans. URJA has prepared a ‘People’s Green Manifesto 2020 for Delhi’, where one item is the people’s demand for better public transport to reduce pollution.The e-rickshaw is not the only mode that is both a necessity and a nuisance. “Entering Kalkaji every evening is a major hassle due to Gramin Sewa vehicles idling on the road near the Nehru Enclave metro station. These are always overloaded and dangerous for both the passengers and other vehicles,” said Kamal Sharma, a Kalkaji resident.Amid these transport blips, CM Arvind Kejriwal has an election promise. The roads of Delhi, he says, will resemble those in London and Tokyo — if his party is re-elected.

Title: It’s official: Kerala will have own census but no NPR
Content:
pinarayi vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state cabinet has decided to inform the registrar general of census, who comes under the Union home ministry, that Kerala will not implement the National Population Register ( NPR ), a move that is bound to set the LDF government, which has been in the forefront of the anti-CAA movement , on a collision course with the Centre.“The decision has been taken to clear public apprehensions and to maintain law and order in the state. The state government has the Constitutional responsibility to ensure these two,” said a statement issued by the cabinet.However, the state government clarified it will fully cooperate with normal census procedures. “We will inform the census directorate that certain questions which will go with the census will not be asked here. The state government will ask enumerators to exclude two questions: date of birth of respondents and details of their parents from the census questionnaire,” said AC Moideen, minister for local self-government.The state government is of the view that NPR is a prelude to National Register of Citizens (NRC). “People fear the aim of creating such a register. We believe that this would create severe unrest among people. Already the states, where this has been implemented, are witnessing severe law and order issues,” the statement said.The intelligence wing of state police has reportedly warned that the implementation of NPR or NRC would create severe tension in Kerala. District collectors have also reported that census process will be severely affected if we go ahead with NPR, the statement explained.The Kerala government has already filed a suit gone against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in the Supreme Court, while the state assembly passed a unanimous resolution urging the Centre to withdraw CAA.

Title: Back to classroom: Delhi cops counsel rioters on CAA
Content:
File photo of a Delhi Police barricade

NEW DELHI: The Special Investigation Team of Delhi Police has started a counselling programme for the rioters arrested during the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protests. Following a court order, they are being made to attend classes where they are told about the provisions of the new law. On Sunday, the ‘teacher’ also fielded questions from the ‘students’ in a two-hour session.The main query of the 15 bailed men was whether they would be deported if they failed to provide proof of their citizenship. Police sources said the men mostly claimed to be daily wage labourers, here in Delhi to earn a livelihood in the factories in north-east Delhi.According to an officer, one of the men admitted that he had not known about CAA at the time of the violent protests, but had learnt about it from peers after his arrest. Like others, his concern was about being deported or sent to a detention camp.The cops had hired a legal expert to explain the provisions of the Act to the men to clear any misunderstanding they might have. They were also encouraged to bring their family members or anyone else to learn more about what the amendment to the Citizenship Act entailed.An officer said, “We also handed the men copies of the Act so they could read about its provisions themselves. The language was simplified to enable them to understand it.” Some religious leaders were also roped in advise the rioters to avoid violence while protesting.The men who were arrested after the violent demonstrations in Seelampur and Daryaganj in December last year were asked to clear the doubts people known to them might have about the provisions.Delhi Police has arrested 100 people in connection with the violence, and efforts are being made to identify others who had gone on a rampage. Most were nabbed from Seelampur and Jafrabad. Police will conduct counselling sessions for all the others arrested when they are bailed by the courts.

Title: Telangana: Netas show cops in poor light, play out phone conversations
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The campaign ended on Monday, but on a bitter note with the opposition parties projecting police as “mere tools” in the hands of the ruling TRS. Some netas even went to the extent of playing out their phone conversations with police higher-ups.

Nizamabad MP Arvind Dharmapuri of BJP and Sangareddy legislator T Jagga Reddy were notable in playing out their phone conversations much to the joy of crowds at their rallies.

Arvind made the crowds listen to his conversation with the ‘commissioner of police’ wherein he was arguing as to why BJP was being asked to change the rally route map of its MLA Raja Singh in Nizamabad where he had gone to campaign. Arvind charged police with giving preference to AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi . The Hyderabad MP during his campaign in Armoor urged people to defeat BJP and also said he was sad that his ‘sister’ (referring to former Nizamabad MP Kavitha Kalvakuntla) had lost the Lok Sabha polls.

In Sangareddy, Jagga Reddy played out his phone conversation apparently with a police official. “You targeted me and I am ready for anything,” he told the police official whom he did not name. IT minister KT Rama Rao charged BJP with stirring communal passions. Arvind, however, clarified: “I am not against Muslim brothers and sisters. I am against AIMIM.”

Title: MLA Ashish Jaiswal moots bamboo as farm fence to fight wild boar menace
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

MLA Ashish Jaiswal

NAGPUR: To deal with wild boar menace which threatens farms on periphery of forests in Ramtek, MLA Ashish Jaiswal is finalizing a plan to find a sustainable solution. Speaking exclusively to TOI, Jaiswal shared his plan to start bamboo plantations on a large scale on affected farms. He says this will serve both economic and farming interest of the ryots.

Jaiswal says the sturdy bamboo plantations can withstand the marauding wild boars if grown as a fence. Later, the bamboo can be sold which will bring additional income for the farmer.

“I will be ready with a detailed plan soon which will be presented to the government. Wild boars are a big menace for farmers and the damage caused is a serious issue,” he said.

Last week, a pack of wild boars attacked a farmer family in Chargaon village of Ramtek when they were working on their field. Their 20 year-old daughter lost her life after she jumped into an open well while trying to escape from the rampaging beasts. This incident led to an outrage among locals who have seen their crops regularly damaged by the boars.

Though the state government allows culling under certain circumstances, Jaiswal’s draft plan is looking for a more sustainable and permanent solution.

State government funds will be sought for the project said Jaiswal. “It could be part of the employment guarantee scheme. Farmers will be engaged in planting bamboo and EGS will ensure that they don’t loose out on their livelihood,” said Jaiswal.

The fact that Jaiswal is close to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray is viewed as an added advantage. Jaiswal contested the assembly polls in October as an independent candidate after the Ramtek seat went to BJP, courtesy a pre-poll deal with his party Shiv Sena. Though Jaiswal was technically a “rebel” candidate, he has always shared good relations with Thackeray.

Title: Badminton set for major changes with synthetic shuttles
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hyderabad: In a move that is likely to lead to major changes in badminton, the Badminton World Federation (BWF) has approved the use of synthetic feather shuttlecocks at its sanctioned international tournaments at all levels from 2021. At present, feathers from goose and duck are used to manufacture shuttles around the world.

In a statement, BWF said that various prototypes, developed with technological cooperation of Yonex, were tested at three tournaments last year. It added that the synthetic variety is more durable and economical compared to the traditional shuttle and that it has similar flight and performance.

It will, however, not be mandatory to use only this variety once it’s introduced next year. Initially, hosts of tournaments will be given a choice between the synthetic and traditional variety. The federation is hoping that synthetic shuttles will become popular with time.

In an official statement, BWF secretary general Thomas Lund called it a positive step for the sport. “The vision is to ensure long term sustainability of badminton and become less dependent on natural feathers for shuttlecocks,” he said. “We heard from some elite players involved in the testing that they were able to adjust to slight variances between synthetic and traditional shuttlecocks quite quickly.”

Surprisingly, chief coach of the Indian badminton team, Pullela Gopichand, said he was unaware about the development. “Without testing it, I cannot comment on how it behaves,” he told TOI. “But I feel the skill aspect of the game may be lost. We may not have the soft touch, cuts or drops. It will be a different shift in the sport. The game may be more power reliant. We need to adapt to it, there is no other way.”

The name ‘shuttlecock’ originated in the 1570s in England. The one in use now is made from 16 overlapping feathers. In China, goose feathers are used while in India white duck feathers are used. In every shuttle, feathers from only one of the wing (left or right) are used.

Former India international Chetan Anand, who runs his own academy, said, “I think too many changes are bad for the game. Badminton may change entirely because of this introduction. If there is not much difference between the feather and synthetic variants, I don't have a problem.”

Title: Centre can take over Unitech Limited, retired IAS officer to be CMD
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Monday accepted the Centre’s proposal to take control of embattled real estate giant Unitech Limited and paved the way for a new board of directors, headed by retired IAS officer Yudvir Singh Malik, to take over the management and initiate steps to complete the housing projects in which over 30,000 people have invested.

A bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and M R Shah also approved the names of ex-CMD of NBCC Anoop Kumar Mittal, chairman of HDFC Credila Financial Services Pvt Ltd Renu Sud Karnad, CMD of property developer Embassy Group Jitu Virwani, MD of Mumbai-based Hiranandani Group Niranjan Hiranandani, chartered accountant Girish Kumar Ahuja and former MD and CEO of IDBI Bank B Sriram for appointment as directors of the company.

The court, however, turned down the plea of the present management headed by the Chandra family that one of the family members be also made part of the board to facilitate management of the company. It directed the newly constituted board of directors to prepare the resolution framework of the company within two months and place it before the court.

Responding to the Centre’s stand that it will not infuse any money in Unitech, advocate Pawanshree Agrawal, who is assisting the court as amicus curiae, and homebuyers’ lawyer M L Lahoty pleaded the court to direct the finance ministry to provide some funds to complete the projects. Agrawal told the court that the new management should also be directed to dispose of encumbered properties of Unitech to raise funds.

The bench asked why the government cannot release money for its newly set up stress fund for real estate sector but the attorney general responded that funds cannot be released for projects under litigation. The court said it would take that aspect later after the new management took charge of the company.

The court also agreed with all conditions put by the Centre to take over the management, which includes appointment of a retired SC judge to supervise the resolution framework finalised by the proposed board of directors and that the board be empowered to take steps to raise money for completion of projects.

The other conditions said the board be allowed to raise funds due from homebuyers and to sell unsold inventory of stocks and make unclaimed inventory available for re-selling. But the court said homebuyers could be asked to pay money only when after construction.

The court also stayed all proceedings against Unitech in tribunals and various courts for two months but made it clear that construction work going on in various projects would not be stopped due to change in management. The court also said it will not keep monitoring the functioning of the company under new management saying, “We will leave it to the commercial wisdom of the board of directors to take a decision.”

Title: Delhi: Youths march, invoke Mahatma Gandhi’s call for support to Muslims
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The demonstrators urged people to fight against all kinds of discrimination

NEW DELHI: Different student groups from across the country held a protest march under the banner of ‘ Young India ’ from Mandi House to Jantar Mantar on Monday. They raised slogans against Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Addressing the participants, activist Harsh Mander said that it was exactly 73 years ago on January 18, 1948, that on the call of Mahatma Gandhi , lakhs had come out on the streets to show their support for Muslims in the country. A similar development is taking place again to ensure that nobody faces discrimination, he added.

“Love is the soul of the Constitution. Protesters are soldiers of love and Constitution and they have succeeded in stopping those whose attempt was to divide the nation,” he added.

“Students’ groups and unions associated with us have already held protests against CAA and NRC at Mallapuram, Mumbai, Hyderabad, Delhi, Pune, Ahmedabad and other places. We have also conducted Preamble reading sessions in several colleges,” the Young India collective stated.

“Young India campaign unites the students and is aimed at protecting the Constitution,” said N Sai Balaji, AISA national president.

Members of Jamia Coordination Committee, ANHAD, JNU Students’ Union, Shaheen Bagh Protest Committee (United Youth Brigade) and others also joined the forum in its appeal to the Supreme Court of India to strike down the CAA when it comes for hearing on January 22.

Dipankar Bhattacharya of CPIML said: “No one has a problem in giving citizenship to refugees. But today they are dividing on the basis of religion, and tomorrow they’ll do it on the basis of caste and gender.”

Former JNU student and activist Umar Khalid took a jibe at the government and said that “despite bad economy the factory of lies was doing good in the country.”

Stating that protesters “have learnt equality from Ambedkar and harmony from Gandhi,” Khalid asked them to come out on January 30 and form a human chain at Connaught Place to mark the death anniversary of Gandhi.

Title: CM Arvind Kejriwal nomination: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal misses 3pm cutoff, will file nomination on Tuesday
Content:
CM Arvind Kejriwal waves towards people during a road show in Delhi.

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal must have been heartened by the big crowds that turned out on Monday to see him go to Jamnagar House to file his nomination papers as a contestant in the assembly poll from the New Delhi constituency. But their presence on the streets meant his roadshow could not make it to the returning officer’s chambers by 3pm, the cutoff for acceptance of the documents. Kejriwal will now return to Jamnagar House on Tuesday, this time without a roadshow.Kejriwal, his wife, children and parents arrived at Valmiki Mandir near Gole Market in the morning. It was here that he had offered prayers in 2013 and 2015 before filing his nomination. Accompanied by senior AAP functionaries Manish Sisodia and Sanjay Singh, the family then got into an open jeep and started out half an hour after noon. They were escorted by a fleet of vehicles and surrounded by dancing AAP supporters.People wearing party caps, Kejriwal masks and carrying the AAP convener’s cut-outs had arrived from different constituencies like Najafgarh and Sangam Vihar for the roadshow. Mindful of the physical attacks on the CM in the past during roadshows of this kind, a multi-layer security ringed his jeep. The yellow vehicle drove Kejriwal, clad in the familiar blue sweater, a navy blue muffler around his neck and an AAP cap on his head, from Valmiki Mandir towards Connaught Place via Panchkuian Marg.Supporters danced to the party’s election song, Lage raho Kejriwal, while large groups of people joined the roadshow at various points. People in the crowd raised slogans in favour of their sitting MLAs who were fielded again this year. Flash mobs attracted the attention of road users before Kejriwal’s vehicle appeared on the scene.People on either side of the road lined up to see their chief minister and wave at him. When the procession arrived at any particular point, the people ran to shake hands with the AAP leader. The roadshow attracted the attention of many foreigners too. AAP volunteers made some of them wear the party caps and they appeared to enjoy the attention. At one place along the route, supporters were seen dancing to the popular Bhojpuri song Rinkiya ke papa, originally sung by Bhojpuri actor Manoj Tiwari, who is currently the Delhi BJP chief.The cavalcade proceeded at glacial pace to CP’s Inner Circle before hitting Baba Kharak Singh Marg. There it halted at Hanuman Mandir, by which time it was already past 3pm. “I prayed to Lord Shiva early in the morning, sought the blessings of Lord Valmiki at his temple and visited Hanuman Mandir to pray to Lord Hanuman that the next five years should be equally fulfilling like the five years gone by,” Kejriwal, sporting a large tilak, told the crowd at Baba Kharak Singh Marg. “I hope that you will bless us in the same way as you blessed us five years ago."Kejriwal added that he was advised en route to leave the roadshow and drive to the nomination office. “How could I do that? I could not ignore the love and support of my people. We are ending the roadshow now and I will go with my family to file my nomination on Tuesday,” the CM said.Seeking a third term from the New Delhi seat, Kejriwal thanked the hundreds who joined him on the roadshow. “Only 20 days are left for the elections. I want you all to go from door-to-door to urge people to vote for AAP,” he appealed.

Title: Telangana municipal elections: Postal ballot gets cold response from officials
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Lack of response to postal ballot from officials drafted for election duty has come as a rude shock to the State Election Commission. Only 8,000 odd employees of the over 44,000 employees deployed on poll duty have applied for postal ballot.

Officials said that while it is up to the government employees to decide whether they will cast their vote or not, SEC secretary M Ashok Kumar has appealed to ‘on poll duty’ employees and police personnel to utilise the ‘Te-Poll’ software to fill application form VII, which needs to be submitted in person or through online to get the postal ballot.

Ashok Kumar told TOI that during these elections, over 44,000 employees had been drafted for election duty. “But, only 8,000 have applied for the postal ballot. It has been observed that response from the polling officials is lukewarm,” he said.

Officials also did not rule out the possibility of a majority of on-poll duty employees not being the voters of urban local bodies, which are going to polls on January 22.

Many of these could be voters of Greater Hyderabad, Khammam and Greater Warangal urban local bodies which are not going to polls on January 22.

“Of course, there could be employees who have not bothered to apply for postal ballot. But, there is still time and we hope that the postal ballot numbers will increase,” an official said.

People, who find their votes already been cast, can demand and cast a tender vote. If the percentage of tender votes is more than 0.1% of the total votes polled, SEC would take a call on conducting a fresh poll in that particular polling booth, officials said.
