Bhopal: Supporters and relatives of JP Nadda in Madhya Pradesh are jubilant after his elevation as the national president of BJP. Chief minister Kamal Nath has also congratulated Nadda for becoming the chief of the largest political party in the country.

“Many congratulations to the state’s son-in-law JP Nadda ji on being elected the national president of the BJP. I wish him a bright future and I hope that he will give his contribution in the development and progress of the country and public interest,” tweeted Nath on Monday.

In Jabalpur, relatives and family members of JP Nadda hailed his election to the post of BJP president. Nadda married to Mallika Nadda, is son-in-law of BJP veteran and former cabinet minister, Jayshree Banerjee.

“I am happy that he has been elevated to the post of BJP chief. He deserved the coveted position. He has always performed his responsibility and I am hopeful that he would prove himself here too. I would advise him to promote the youth and the society and eliminate the conservatism,” said Banerjee.

BJP state president Rakesh Singh, former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan, LoP Gopal Bhargava and chief whip in state assembly Narottam Mishra have also congratulated Nadda for become the party chief.

The leaders were also present during the ceremony at BJP headquarters in New Delhi, on Monday. Singh said Nadda had served various positions in the party and the state unit will get benefit of his vast experience.

Title: UP: Scolded for not studying, 12-year-old boy hangs self
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: Reprimanded by his mother for not studying properly, a 12-year-old boy allegedly hanged himself in Mirzapur block of Shahjahanpur district on Sunday. He had gone missing on Sunday and his body was later found hanging in a field. This is the third case of suicide by a minor in the district since November 2019.

On January 3, a 14-year old schoolboy had committed suicide after his mother had refused to come back home following a tiff with his father. His father was an alcoholic and used to often beat his mother. Before that, a 13-year-old schoolboy had committed suicide due to unknown reasons in Mirzapur in November.

Shobhit Mishra, a resident of Bahariya village, used to study in class VI. Not keen to continue with his studies, he used to often bunk his school. On Sunday evening, Shobhit was allegedly scolded by his mother, following which, he walked out of the house. A few hours later, when he didn’t return home, his father started looking for him but couldn’t find him.

At 10.30 pm, Shobhit was found hanging with a rope from a mango tree on their farm.

According to his parents, Shobhit used to spend hours sitting under his favourite mango tree whenever he was upset.

Mirzapur station house officer Dilip Yadav told TOI, “Prima facie, it is a case of suicide as there were no injuries on the body. We have sent the body for autopsy to ensure that there is no foul play. We have recorded the statement of family and neighbours and it was evident that the boy was scolded by his parents. We are trying to check if there is any other reason behind the incident.”

Dr Sandesh Gupta, who conducted the autopsy, said, “The reason of death was hanging and there were no injuries on the body of the victim.”

Title: Amaravati had potential to be country’s best city: N Chandrababu Naidu
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

N Chandrababu Naidu

VIJAYAWADA: Former chief minister and leader of opposition N Chandrababu Naidu appealed to chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy not to shift the state capital from Amaravati.

He urged the government to make use of the existing facilities and infrastructure in Amaravati and develop other cities and regions.

Naidu spoke in the House after the bill for repealing APCRDA Act was moved on Monday and said Amaravati is the dream capital of people of Andhra Pradesh. He said the city has enough land bank for the government and thus the city would be treated as self-finance city. He cited the statement of Prime Minister Narendra Modi at the time of laying the foundation stone for the city, who visualized Amaravati as one of the 14 best cities of the nation.

The TDP chief said that he had developed Visakhapatnam as financial capital of the state during the last five years. He brushed aside allegations on suitability of the soil for construction and the claims on multi-crop agriculture land. He said that the National Green Tribunal too had admitted that Amaravati was not a flood-prone area and not a multi-crop zone.

He cited that the Sivaramakrishanan Committee had favoured Vijayawada-Guntur as the most suitable place for the capital in terms of connectivity and infrastructure. He said the Sivaramakrishnan Committee had one objection on shortage of land for Vijayawada. Naidu added that his government had acquired 33,000 acres from farmers.

“With 33,000 acres at the disposal of the government and with the positive points given by the Sivaramakrishnan committee, Amaravati is the most suitable place for the capital,” Naidu said.

He also brushed aside allegations about the location of the capital and said Delhi had been the capital for the undivided India which included Pakistan and Bangladesh. Similarly, Chennai had been the capital of combined Kerala, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh and Odisha and thus the cities were fixed as capitals in centrally-located place. Amaravati, too, was thus fixed as the capital for the residuary state after the division.

Naidu reminded Jaganmohan Reddy that the late Y S Rajasekhara Reddy continued some of the development initiatives of his government in the undivided state and requested the chief minister to continue Amaravati as the capital. “There is enough space for assembly, Secretariat and the high court. There is no need for the government to spend money, if there is no money. Run the show from the existing facilities and go for new city or additional infrastructure when there is money,” Naidu told the chief minister.

Title: Bengaluru: Soon, non-Metro users can access facilities at stations
Content:
Allowing non-Metro users will also help increase footfall at stations, which will enable BMRCL to tap non-fare... Read More

TimesView Allowing pedestrians to use facilities like elevators and escalators is a welcome initiative, especially since many Metro stations are located near roads with high-traffic density, often with dividers and few crossing locations. Given that most of the foot overbridges built by BBMP are not of much use — either because of their location or the manner of their construction — this seems to be a sensible alternative with additional footfall benefits for BMRCL.

BENGALURU: In order to provide safe passage to pedestrians near Metro stations — who often put their lives at risk by crossing busy roads — Bangalore Metro Rail Corporation Limited is planning to allow non-Metro commuters to use its facilities for free.This means the general public can also use the stairs, escalators and elevators at Metro stations to go from one point to another during operational hours. Structural modifications to make this a reality are in the pipeline.“The goal is to provide road crossover connectivity to non-Metro users through unpaid areas at all existing Phase 1 Metro stations,” said BMRCL managing director Ajay Seth.“Phase 2 station layout is being done to provide such connectivity from the beginning itself. Also, wherever there’s a Metro station on one side of the road (for example Hosur Road), a foot overbridge will be constructed by BMRCL,” he added.Allowing non-Metro users will also help increase footfall at stations, which will enable BMRCL to tap non-fare revenue (from shops etc).“Several stations require changes in location of entry/exit fare gates and security check. Some need civil work too. MG Road Metro station doesn’t have such a facility. Similarly, even Nagasandra and Dasarahalli don’t have FOB connectivity to other side of the road. It will take six to 10 months to set up the facilities,” said Seth.BMRCL had earlier proposed an FOB across MG Road from Navrathan Jewellers side to the boulevard which houses Rangoli Metro Art Centre. In 2018, Hyderabad Metro Rail Corporation allowed pedestrians to use some stations. “It’s a good idea. BBMP is unnecessarily building FOBs in core city areas, even in places where the facility is not needed, just to shore up ad revenues,” said Aiswaraya Kumar, a passenger on MG Road.

Title: Pune: Vandals damage cars, steal cash & valuables
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Thieves stole cash and valuables totally worth Rs 66,500 from three cars parked in front of the district and sessions court in Shivajinagar last week.

One of the car owners, Prashant Ghodke (45) of Wakad , lodged a complaint with the Shivajinagar police on Saturday night. According to the FIR, the three cars parked near the court premises were unattended between 5pm and 7.20pm.

When the car owners returned, they found the windows of their vehicles damaged. On checking inside the car, the vehicles’ owners found valuables kept on the rear seats missing.

According to police, the suspects stole Rs16,000, purse containing debit cards and some US dollars from Ghodke’s car. The suspects later withdrew Rs21,000 from his account using the debit card, the police said.

The suspects used iron rods or blunt objects to damage the glass windows of the cars, the police added.

Title: ‘Suspect knew about CCTV cameras at Mangaluru airport’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The IED was taken to a field at Kenjar in a Threat Containment Vehicle and detonated on Monday.

Title: Leaving Congress biggest blunder on my part: DS
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hyderabad: Senior politician and TRS Rajya Sabha MP Dharmapuri Srinivas , popularly known as DS, said on Monday that leaving Congress was the biggest blunder of his 40-year long political career.

The 71-year-old three-time MLA and former minister quit Congress on July 2, 2015, a year after Telangana was granted statehood by the then UPA government at the Centre in June 2014.

Days later, Srinivas joined TRS to realise the goal of what he termed a “bangaru (golden) Telangana.” However, his honeymoon with the ruling TRS did not last long. In the last couple of years, his relationship with TRS leadership strained further as he developed differences especially with former Nizamabad MP and chief minister’s daughter Kalvakuntla Kavitha. His younger son Dharmapuri Arvind is a BJP leader and represents Nizamabad in the Lok Sabha after defeating Kavitha in the 2019 elections.

Srinivas said he resigned from Congress owing to differences he had with the then Congress incharge of Telangana affairs Digvijaya Singh who, he said, had insulted him. Srinivas had served as the state Congress president twice and also as a minister in undivided Andhra Pradesh. He was the president of Andhra Pradesh Congress Committee when the party assumed power under the leadership of late YS Rajasekhara Reddy in 2004.

Ahead of the municipal elections, Srinivas dared the TRS leadership to take action against him. Speaking to newsmen in Nizamabad, he also took an indirect dig at chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao saying “father, son and daughter have become golden” in the name of achieving a golden Telangana.

Title: Gujarat government says no to imported onions
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

GANDHINAGAR: The Gujarat government , in a letter to the Union government, has refused to purchase imported onions for sale in the state. The government of India had earlier asked the state to purchase imported onions so that increased onion prices could be stabilized.

While refusing to purchase imported onions, the state government has contended that Gujarat’s onion farmers will be adversely affected if imported onions are sold in the state. Besides, the taste of imported onions falls short of the taste of locally grown onions, the state government letter says.

A senior state government official said that CM Vijay Rupani decided to write to the central government refusing to purchase imported onions after consultation with various stakeholders and seeking feedback of senior officials. “The CM has also already informed the Centre in writing that, Gujarat is one of the key onion producing states and our farmers are likely to be adversely impacted if we purchase imported onions. Moreover, people have not liked the taste of imported onions. Even if Gujarat purchases imported onions, there will be problem of demand. Moreover, the price of locally produced onions has come down,” the official said.

The Centre had written to all states, asking them to purchase imported onions and distribute these so that skyrocketing prices of onions could be brought down. However, the government received feedback from consumers that the imported onions did not taste as good as the locally produced varieties.

Prices of onions have stabilized at around Rs 60 per kg after selling for over Rs 100 per kg recently.

The central government, in December last year, approved import of 36,090 metric tonnes of onions amid the supply crunch. These onions were mainly imported from Turkey and Egypt. The country had last imported 1,987 tonnes of onion in 2015-16.

Title: HC to hear capital petitions on January 22
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh high court , on Monday, posted the hearing on a batch of petitions challenging the imposition of Section 144 in the capital region and police action on women protesters to Wednesday.

The bench headed by Chief Justice JK Maheswari and Justice AV Seshasai told the petitioners and respondents that the court will take up the matter on Wednesday and hear it along with other petitions connected with capital matters.

Advocate general S Sriram sought time to file a detailed counter on the action initiated against police officials for allegedly manhandling women. The advocate general told the court that a few incident took place in the process of maintaining law and order. The bench directed the advocate general to file a report on all such incidents that took place in the capital region.

On the other hand, the high court extended the time limit for farmers to submit grievances to the AP Capital Region Development Authority (APCRDA) by two more days.

The petitioners argued that the notices given to farmers did not mention anything other than to submit grievances. They said that the notices are incomplete and should specifically mention the matters on which the farmers have to give their opinion or air their grievances.

The bench observed that it will set aside the notices or any consequential action if the notices are found to be faulty and incomplete and posted the matter for hearing on Wednesday.

Title: KV student from Bengaluru anchors PM Modi’s Pariksha pe Charcha
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hridya S Nair

BENGALURU: For Bengaluru girl Hridya S Nair , January 20, 2020, will always be special. The 16-year-old got a chance to moderate Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Pariksha pe Charcha event at Talkatora Stadium in New Delhi.

Hridya, a class 11 student of Kendriya Vidyalaya , DRDO and one of the three student-moderators at the third edition of the event where 2,000 students participated, said the thought of sharing the stage with the PM had made her extremely nervous.

“The pressure was immense. But once I started speaking, I looked at PM Modi, who was also looking at me and listening very carefully. At that moment, I felt like I was talking to a friend. He indirectly helped me do better and shed my nervousness, because when someone listens to you, you just want to do better,” Hridya gleamed.

She asked 10 of the 20 questions students from across the country posed to the PM.

“I was left spellbound at the end of the event when Modi extended his hand towards me and said ‘aayiye (please come).’ I was supposed to thank him in Hindi, but forgot what I had to say as I was completely star-struck by his warm and friendly gesture,” she said.

Hridya, who stood first at the national-level elocution competition held by Kendriya Vidyalaya Sangathan (KVS) as part of its Ek Bharat Shreshtha Bharat event in October 2019, underwent intense training (from 8am to 6pm)s every day from January 15 to 19.

“We were also trained to be ready for anything out of the script,” she said, adding that they had to start by introducing the students and inviting them to ask questions.

“Next step was summarising their question for Modi and after he answered it, we had to thank him and summarise his answer,” Hridya said, explaining that while the PM answered the questions, they were backstage taking notes with their teachers.

Hridya’s aim is to join Indian Foreign Service .

Her English teacher at KV DRDO and mentor Jinu Pavithran told TOI Hridya topped the school in class 10 and scored 98%. Her father CN Satheesh works at Aeronautical Development Agency and mother Smitha Satheesh is a pharmacist. She is thankful to her parents for allowing her to skip continuous assessment exam that was scheduled for Monday. “My five-year-old sister, Dheera, had asked me to tell the PM that she is his big fan. But I couldn’t,” said Hridya.

KV DRDO teacher Shivani Ranjan said excitement soared on campus, where the event was screened live. “Nearly 1,050 students watched their schoolmate without blinking,” she said.

Thirty-two students from Karnataka attended the event in New Delhi.

Title: Kolkata: Spurt in truck accidents as closed routes take toll
Content:
A truck plies on CIT road at night to reach Strand Road

KOLKATA: Multiple fatal truck accidents reported across the city since the beginning of the New Year have led the police to brainstorm for solutions.A 63-year-old man was run over by a truck near Garia in the wee hours of Monday when he was on the way to his office in Raniganj. This is the 14th major accident in the city in a span of 20 days this year. The victim, Rajat Dutta Roy, a resident of Garia’s Purbapara, was waiting for his daughter at a bus stop, according to the police.Most accidents involving trucks are taking place after the “traffic hours” — 10pm when traffic cops are discharged from duty for the day. However, cops are thinking whether the abrupt change in routes with the closure of several bridges and more focus on bikes and buses are triggering a spurt in truck accidents in the city. The morning fog also makes it difficult for those at the wheels of trucks, said the police. “The local police officers can guide the truck drivers and take action against them if they resort to reckless driving,” said a Lalbazar officer.Most accidents were reported from three zones like Hastings, Bypass connectors and Canal Road. Unlike this year, the number of truck accidents came down to 313 in 2019 from 373 in 2018.“The closure of several bridges, especially Tallah Bridge and Kidderpore Bridge has disturbed the movement of trucks. We need to fix certain specific routes to ensure that trucks can use the Strand Road or EM Bypass at night from the north. They should not take Beniapukur and Entally where three accidents were reported this month,” said the police.Ever since the Majerhat Bridge collapse and closure of Tallah Bridge, it is not possible for cops to check all intersections, though night checks have been strengthened. “With managing the trucks crossing DH Road, Karunamoyee Bridge, RG Kar Road and Chitpore Lock Gate, most of our night forces are getting stuck there,” added the police.

Title: Telangana: 70-year-old charred inside abandoned car
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 70-year-old beggar was burnt to death while sleeping inside an abandoned car in Vikarabad ’s Tandur on Sunday night. Police suspect that a smouldering cigarette-end inside the car may have caused the fire.

The deceased, Veeranna, is said to have consumed alcohol inside the car before the incident. “Veeranna generally keeps his cotton bed on top of the car, whenever he sleeps inside it...After he consumed alcohol, his cigarette might had have fallen on the bed which spread (the fire) across the car. Later, the fire spread to a nearby tent which too was burnt,’’ Vikarabad police said.

Police are also investigating the possibility of the fire having started from the tent. “On Sunday, there was a jatara (festival) at a local temple. Some persons had set up a tent and cooked food using sticks close to the abandoned car. They may have left without putting out the fire completely which then spread from the tent to the care,” police said.

The persons who had arranged the tent told police that the fire had been put out before they left.

Title: Telangana did not get even ‘an ana’ from Centre, says roads and buildings minister
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Vemula Prashanth Reddy (File photo)

HYDERABAD: Pooh-poohing BJP’s claims that the Centre was granting liberal financial assistance to Telangana to implement schemes like Aasara pensions and Kalyana Lakshmi, roads and buildings minister Vemula Prashanth Reddy on Monday said the Centre has not given even an ‘ana’ to the state.

Ana is a currency unit formerly used in India, which was equal to 1/16 of a rupee. Taking aim at BJP, the minister said: “Nizamabad MP Arvind Dharmapuri makes tall claims that Centre is doling out ‘barana’ (75 paise) support to Telangana for schemes like Aasara when not even one ana is given.” He said the Centre is releasing only such funds that are part of mandatory devolution. “Telangana govenrment has spent Rs 300 crore on municipalities. We released Rs 100 crore alone to take up various works in Nizamabad municipal corporation in the last five years,” Prashanth said.

Addressing media in Nizamabad, the minister said he is ready for a debate on funds being released by Centre and on development works taken up in Nizamabad.

Title: China virus scare: Screening of flyers begins at KIA
Content:
Representative image

Novel coronavirus & its symptoms

‘Segregation has to start at airport’

BENGALURU: With the deadly novel coronavirus (nCoV) infection affecting more than 200 people and claiming three lives in China, doctors in Bengaluru are as concerned as their counterparts elsewhere in the world.While medical professionals feel growing passenger traffic between Bengaluru and China is enough cause for worry, authorities at Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) on Monday sounded the first alert as a precautionary step.“Bengaluru airport has no direct flight to the affected cities in China. However, BIAL has taken precautionary measures to manage novel coronavirus cases. Based on the guidelines received from the Union ministry of health and family welfare, BIAL has set up a helpdesk at international arrivals. Thermal screening of passengers from Singapore, Hong Kong and Kuala Lumpur started on Monday,” said a BIAL spokesperson. Thermal imaging scanners used at airports can potentially detect if a person has fever.Coronavirus is a large family of viruses that cause illness ranging from the common cold to more severe ones like Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV). However, nCoV is a new strain that has not been previously identified in humans, according to the World Health Organisation.Meanwhile, the state health and family welfare department has deputed health assistants from Bengaluru Rural district to Airport Health Organisation, KIA, for passive surveillance of self-reporting passengers seeking medical assistance.The department on Friday held an orientation programme for district surveillance officers on nCoV infections. Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Health Sciences in Bengaluru and Wenlock Hospital in Mangaluru have been identified for treatment of any suspected case.“Till now, no suspected cases have been reported in Karnataka or India. However, if symptoms suggestive of respiratory illness are experienced during or after travel, passengers are encouraged to seek medical attention and share their travel history with healthcare providers,” said Dr Prakash Kumar, joint director, communicable diseases, health and family welfare department.Novel coronavirus can be mistaken for common cold, cough and respiratory infections, given the similar symptoms.nCoV is a new variant of coronavirus not previously identified in humans. Symptoms include fever, cough, shortness of breath and breathing difficulty.According to Dr Satyanarayana Mysore, HoD, consultant pulmonology, respiratory and sleep medicine, Manipal Hospitals, coronavirus belongs to the same family as the SARS virus. “Though there’s no immediate threat in Bengaluru, there are concerns as Wuhan, the worst affected city in China, is a transit hub. Asking for the travel history of a suspected person is essential. But we must also note that infection-control mechanism is strong worldwide, especially as countries have experience in handling SARS. Patient segregation has to begin at the airport itself,” he said.Dr Mysore added that respiratory infections see a spike from October to January, suggesting those with asthma, upper respiratory infections and underlying lung conditions get vaccinated for influenza. However, the influenza vaccine doesn’t provide blanket coverage and only shields one from influenza virus.

Title: Close steel flyover complaint against Siddaramaiah: Lokayukta
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Former Karnataka chief minister Siddaramaiah

BENGALURU: The Lokayukta recommended closure of BJP Rajya Sabha member Rajeev Chandrasekhar’s complaint against former chief minister Siddaramaiah over alleged corruption in the now-scrapped steel flyover project.

On Saturday, Siddaramaiah tweeted a copy of the Lokayukta order, saying: “Hon. Lokayukta has recommended to close the complaint filed by @rajeev_mp alleging mala fide practices in steel flyover project. It is a great win for us to show our people that we had no corrupt intention in initiating the project.” He said the Lokayukta also observed that “allegations are often made easily, than proved”.

“SteelBridge case is one of (the) many allegations made by @BJP4Karnataka leaders aimed at influencing electoral mandate. We are open to investigation in other allegations as well. The outcome will be (the) same,” the former CM tweeted.

Rajeev Chandrasekhar tweeted in reply, “Dear @siddaramaiah avare - ur (your) crooked #SteelFlyover project was shut down by NGT ’n’ courts. Lokayukta has closed complaint bcoz - (because) it doesn’t hv (have) evidence n (and) can’t investigate it. WHY? Bcoz YOU deliberately took away ACB (Anti-Corruption Bureau) (and) investigative powers from Lokayukta n made it toothless.”

Title: Pune News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Army’s statement: A statement issued by the PRO, Defence, stated that the incident as reported in The Times of India’s January 19, 2020, edition was false. At approximately 1215hours on January 13, 2020, the school bus while returning from the Army Public School crossed the Sopan Baug red light and was gradually traversing through the traffic to take a right turn towards general Parade Ground Road. The scooterist was on the Kacha track and tried to climb up the road, which is 3 to 4 inches high, and lost balance. He fell onto the left and the pillion rider fell to his right. The pillion rider was not wearing helmet and sustained head injury owing to impact of falling down. The co-driver of the school bus saw the pillion rider falling on the ground and halted the vehicle. He got down and assisted both the injured, thereafter, he took help of a passerby to get hold of an auto and dispatched them to the nearest hospital. There was no involvement of the Army School bus in the reported incident. In fact, the co-driver as a good Samaritan helped the injured.

TOI correspondent replies: The report was based on the FIR in which the complainant stated that “a green-coloured military school bus” dashed his moped from the rear, resulting in injuries to him and death of his wife, riding pillion. The complainant stated in the FIR that the co-driver of the bus got down from the heavy vehicle and there was a crowd of other vehicles following the accident. The complainant further stated in the FIR that “an autorickshaw driver then requested the co-driver of the bus to take both the victims to the hospital, but the co-driver got back into the bus, which drove away without lending any helping hand to the victims”. Later, the autorickshaw driver, with the help of some other people, shifted the complainant and his wife to a private hospital, the FIR stated.

Title: Man swipes card at Karnataka's Kormangala pub, loses Rs 4 lakh in New York
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: An hour after a 34-year-old software engineer swiped his debit card at a restaurant here on January 9, Rs 4.1 lakh was siphoned off from his account in 10 transactions in New York.

Varun Gupta of Singasandra said he visited a pub in Koramangala VI Block on the night of January 9. After having food, Gupta paid Rs 4,181 by swiping his Axis Bank debit card using his PIN.

The same night, miscreants siphoned off Rs 4,10,036 in 10 instalments in a span of 10 minutes from his account. All the transactions were through point-of-sale machines, implying that a debit card had been used.

“The transactions happened via my Axis Bank debit card in New York, while I was in Bengaluru,” Gupta said, regretting that the bank couldn’t detect the fraud.

Police issued a notice to the pub in Koramangala, seeking details about the machine they used to swipe Gupta’s card and details of the staff who handled the device. “This is a clear case of skimming. We are checking with other places where Gupta had used the card,” a police officer said.

Title: Making Renaissance Man relevant for 21st century
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Ahmedabad: An entire generation of Gujarati medium students know him for his poem ‘Unt kahe aa sabha ma...’ included in textbooks and those studying sociology by his Gyati Nibandh (an essay on caste) on evils of casteism written 17 years before Mahatma Gandhi’s birth. But Kavi Dalpatram (1820-1898) was not just a poet or social reformer.

His works as a pioneer of Gujarat Vernacular Society — later Gujarat Vidya Sabha — influenced the city with establishment of Ahmedabad’s first public library, first newspaper, first periodical, first school for girls and first literary society to name a few. Today his old residence is a prominent part of city’s heritage walk with a chowk dedicated to him with a statue at Lambeshwar ni Pol.

As the poet’s 200th birthday will be celebrated on Tuesday in a major event in the city, his descendants are planning a revival of his works. Kunal Kavi, great great grandson of the poet, said that they are marking the occasion by bringing the poet to the digital era.

“We are launching a website dedicated to his works along with accounts on prominent social networking sites. All his works will now be available online. The primary motive behind the move is to communicate that apart from a poet, his oeuvre was much larger,” he said.

Professor Ramji Savaliya, former director of BJ Institute of Learning & Research, said that unfortunately Dalpatram was seen with a specific lens by later era critics due to his views on British rule and religious leanings.

“One should remember that he talked about girl child education, remarriage of widows, condition of cottage industry in the face of machine era and social evils in the 19th century society and also worked tirelessly to promote Gujarati — his incident at the Gaekwad court is a legend now,” he said.

Creator of wordplay

Experts point at Dalpatram’s penchant for creating designs with words which could be read in non-linear fashion. In some of the examples found in ‘Dalpat Kavya’ collection, he has written the poem imagined as spokes of a wheel, serpent, bow and arrow and even as move of the knight in game of chess. Experts said that only a few such examples are seen in his contemporary Gujarati — the activity considered by him to be a ‘mental exercise.’

Title: Pariksha Pe Charcha: Are results the only criteria for success in life, U’khand boy asks PM
Content: Dehradun: Kotdwar resident Mayank Negi, a Class X student of a private school in the city, asked Prime Minister Narendra Modi “if results are the only criteria for success in life and how much focus is needed for exams” during the annual ‘Pariksha Pe Charcha’ event held at New Delhi’s Talkatora stadium on Monday.To this, the PM replied saying that students must focus on exams and results but only marks cannot be the criteria for success in life. He also urged parents to not pressurise their wards during board exams and allow them to engage in extra-curricular activities.While interacting with PM Modi via video conferencing, Mayank asked, “People like Bill Gates, Thomas Edison, and even Mark Zuckerberg failed during early years of their life. Hence, a person cannot be judged on the basis of the marks that he/she gets in exams. I want to know that what is the amount of focus one should have to score good marks in exams?”Responding to the question, PM Modi said that “we must rise above exams.” “Today, the world has changed a lot. The opportunities have developed immensely. Marks are not everything anymore. Neither is any examination. These are just steps… an environment is created where students are told that marks precede everything. I urge parents to not tell their children that exams are everything,” the PM said.Interacting with students, the Prime Minister urged them to be confident of their own preparation and avoid stress as much as they can. He added that “not pursuing a co-curricular activity can turn a person into a robot.” He also stressed on the importance of time management for students. “Today, I am interacting with students who would play a key role in India’s development in 2047, when we mark hundred years of our country’s independence. I hope this generation takes it upon themselves to act on some of the fundamental duties enshrined in our Constitution.”He further said that students should make best possible use of technology but shouldn’t get distracted because of it. “Four family members sitting together but each one involved in his/her phone — this has become a common sight these days. Can we think of a technology-free hour? Perhaps, we can mark a space where no technology is permitted. This way, we won’t get distracted by technology,” the PM said.Notably, 11 students from various schools of Uttarakhand took part in the ‘Pariksha Pe Charcha’ programme with PM Modi in New Delhi. Meanwhile, live telecast of the programme was arranged in over 2,000 government and private schools across Uttarakhand. In several schools, teachers also interacted with students and answered their exam-related queries. In some schools, counsellors were arranged to answer the exam stress-related queries of students.

Title: Babaria to head party state co-ordination panel
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Newly appointed AICC General Secretary and State in-charge Deepak Babaria along with party's State President A... Read More

Bhopal: Congress president Sonia Gandhi on Monday appointed a seven-member coordination committee for Madhya Pradesh to ensure ‘better coordination’ between party and the government. AICC general secretary Deepak Babaria, who is also in-charge of state affairs, has been appointed chairman of the committee.

The members are chief minister Kamal Nath, former CM Digvijaya Singh, AICC general secretary Jyotiraditya Scindia, former state Congress president Arun Yadav, minister for higher education Jeetu Patwari and former MP Meenakshi Natarajan.

State PCC office-bearers said that the appointment is not just for Madhya Pradesh, but other states where the Congress is in power, including Chhattisgarh, Puducherry and Rajasthan. “These leaders will be the bridge between the organization and the government. They will monitor manifesto promises and policy implementation, besides listening to the grievances of party workers,” a senior state Congress leader said.

Since the formation of government in December 2018, Congress workers have been repeatedly complaining that ministers do not meet them. In many internal party meetings, Deepak Babaria has warned ministers that they need to give time to grassroots workers and receive their calls. There have also been disagreements in the top leadership regarding the appointment of chairpersons for independent boards and corporations. Most of these appointments have not been made for lack of coordination between leaders.

In the state government, leaders have often expressed their grievances on Twitter and shot letters to Kamal Nath, instead of speaking directly to him on telephone.

Title: Pune: Drunk driver hits 2 scooters, businessman, his wife & sons hurt
Content:
The injured victims from Mangalwar Peth are being treated in a private hospital

PUNE: A drunk car driver first rammed a businessman, his wife and their two sons riding on two scooters and injured them before crashing into an electric pole outside the B J Medical College boys’ hostel near the police commissioner's office around 7.45pm on Sunday.The electric pole that was uprooted on impact bent and keeled over. The front portion of the car was mangled.The injured victims, Mukund Pardeshi (55), his wife Prathiba (44), and sons Nikhil (22) and Nihal (25) from Mangalwar Peth are being treated in a private hospital. Nikhil’s condition is reported to be serious while the others are stable.The police said the car driver, Shrikant Pawle (35) from Yerawada, was under the influence of alcohol at the time of the accident . He has been arrested for attempt to commit culpable homicide, among other charges of the Indian Penal Code and Motor Vehicle Act. The offence under section 308 (attempt to commit culpable homicide) attracts punishment up to seven years or a fine or both.A court on Monday sent Pawale to the Yerawada Central Prison after he was remanded in magisterial custody for 14 days.Pardeshi, a businessman who sells chicken, in his FIR, said, “I, my wife and two sons were travelling on two scooters and were on our way to attend the reception of a relative in Koregaon Park. We took a left turn from the State Bank of India, Treasury Branch when a speeding car hit my vehicle from behind. We fell down and my wife raised an alarm but the car driver did not stop.”The FIR read, “My sons, on hearing a loud sound, stopped and signalled for the car driver to stop too but he lost control over the vehicle and hit their scooter. The impact of the accident was such that the car stopped after it crashed into the MSEDCL electric pole.”Pardeshi told TOI that the car overturned after hitting the pole and passersby righted the vehicle and rescued the driver. “I called the police control room. A sizeable crowd assembled at the spot and a person, who turned out to be my relative, rushed us to the hospital,” he added.He said he had sustained a minor injury on his left knee, his wife Pratibha and son Nihal escaped with internal injuries. “My other son Nihal was injured on his waist. The driver was heavily drunk. The accident happened because of his negligence,” Pardeshi added.Senior inspector Shrikant Shinde in-charge of the Bundgarden police station said, "The driver had consumed alcohol more than the prescribed limit. His blood test confirmed that he was drunk. A detailed report is awaited."Assistant inspector Jaywant Patil from the Bundgarden police told TOI,“ We have invoked section 308 of the IPC because Pawale did not stop after hitting the Pardeshis and his sons’ vehicles though they called for help and signalled to him to stop. The car stopped only after crashing into a pole.”Pawale was brought to the police station where he told the police the accident was his mistake as he was drunk, Patil added.The legal limit of blood alcohol content (BAC) is 0.03% or 30mg per 100ml of blood. If a person driving a car has a higher BAC level, he or she can be booked under Section 184 and 185 of the Motor Vehicles Act, which consists of imprisonment up to six months or a fine up to Rs 2,000 or both.Pawale’s friends at the police station told TOI, “He panicked after hitting the first vehicle. He accidentally pressed the accelerator and the car picked up speed and hit the second vehicle. He has internal injuries on his face. He could not recollect the accident after he regained consciousness. Pawale has a tourist vehicle licence and has rented the car to an IT company but he drives the vehicle.”

Title: Chennai man found murdered near Salem
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

SALEM: A 62-year-old man from Chennai was found murdered in Salem on Monday.

The victim, Balasubramaniam, from Kambar Street in East Tambaram, was working in a trust in Salem. Police are yet to narrow down on the suspects or arrive at the motive for the murder. “But we are interrogating various people. Right now we are questioning two men,’’ said a police officer.

According to police, Balasubramanian was running a small manufacturing unit in Salem 10 years ago. After incurring losses, his family moved to Tambaram. He returned to Salem a few days ago and started working in the trust as a manager. He was staying in a rented house at Sathapadi for the past 10 days.

On Monday morning, his body was found with strangulation marks on Kamaneri to Kovilur road. Villagers spotted the body and informed the village administrative officer Govindan, who lodged a complaint with the Mecheri police. His motorcycle was also found near the spot. Police said there were injuries on his face and body due to stabbing. The body was sent to the Salem government hospital for postmortem.

Title: Court directs public notice over attachment of 463 DS Kulkarni properties
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Special judge Jayant Raje on Monday directed that a public notice be issued inviting objections and claims over the impending confirmation of attachment of 463 movable and immovable properties belonging to jailed developer DS Kulkarni, alias DSK, and his relatives in connection with the alleged multi-crore rupees economic fraud by the DSK group .

Special public prosecutor Pravin Chavan said the total worth of these properties is over Rs1,500 crore. “The court will pass a common order after examining and hearing the objections and claims. Confirmation of attachment will pave the way for raising money via auction of all these properties and clearing dues payable to banks and depositors, among others.”

“Banks alone have loan recovery claims worth Rs1, 550 crore, while the depositors have a claim of Rs1,283 crore. Amount relating to debentures is Rs135 crore. Barring Kolhapur and Mumbai (where separate cases have been registered), the fraud probed by the Pune police has affected 35,000 investors, mostly from Pune,” Chavan said.

He said the recovery claims of banks will get a precedence over that of the depositors.

Activists, however, said the interest of poor investors should be protected first. “The law should be changed to safeguard the interest of poor investors,” RTI activist Vijay Kumbhar said.

Another activist said, “An autorickshaw driver, one of the investors in DSK firms, ended his life two days ago. The authorities concerned must take appropriate steps to ensure protection of the investors.”

Last Friday, the Pune police’s economic offences wing (EOW) wrote to the district and session’s court and the revenue authorities for expediting the property attachment process after autorickshaw driver Tanaji Korake (61) committed suicide. Korake had left two suicide notes, one of which blamed DSK for his woes.

Assistant commissioner of police (EOW) Shivaji Pawar said, “After the court confirms the attachment, the local revenue officials (district collector is the competent authority under the MPID Act) will do the valuation and auction the properties.”

DSK’s proposal

DSK’s lawyer Dhiraj Ghadge said the developer had made an oral representation to the court seeking appointment of a new builder and an architect for completion of the stalled ‘Dream City’ project on Pune-Solapur Road, which can yield Rs10,000 crore. “The court has asked us to submit a formal written proposal by next date on February 3,” Ghadge said.

Brother moves bail plea

Makarand Sakharam Kulkarni, DSK’s brother and co-accused in the case, moved a bail application through his lawyer Rohan Nahar. The court directed the state to make a written submission on Makarand’s plea by January 24 . The court will hear on February 3 the matters related to the public notice.

(With inputs from Gitesh Shelke)

Title: Court directs public notice over attachment of 463 DS Kulkarni properties
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Special judge Jayant Raje on Monday directed that a public notice be issued inviting objections and claims over the impending confirmation of attachment of 463 movable and immovable properties belonging to jailed developer DS Kulkarni, alias DSK, and his relatives in connection with the alleged multi-crore rupees economic fraud by the DSK group .

Special public prosecutor Pravin Chavan said the total worth of these properties is over Rs1,500 crore. “The court will pass a common order after examining and hearing the objections and claims. Confirmation of attachment will pave the way for raising money via auction of all these properties and clearing dues payable to banks and depositors, among others.”

“Banks alone have loan recovery claims worth Rs1, 550 crore, while the depositors have a claim of Rs1,283 crore. Amount relating to debentures is Rs135 crore. Barring Kolhapur and Mumbai (where separate cases have been registered), the fraud probed by the Pune police has affected 35,000 investors, mostly from Pune,” Chavan said.

He said the recovery claims of banks will get a precedence over that of the depositors.

Activists, however, said the interest of poor investors should be protected first. “The law should be changed to safeguard the interest of poor investors,” RTI activist Vijay Kumbhar said.

Title: Four duped of Rs 2.10 lakh in online Dubai tour fraud
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Four friends, who planned to take their families on a Dubai tour , were duped of Rs2.10 lakh by two tricksters on the pretext of offering them a cheap tour package between January 1 and October 29 last year.

Though the victims have named Ajay Rathod and Abhishek Fasin as the culprits, Tehsil police say they are yet to ascertain the identity of the accused.

According to police, Hitesh Rajkotiya, 37, was present at his garments shop in Gandhibagh on January 1 when his friend Bhavik Puranik visited him to discuss an advertisement by Trip Zolo Tours and Travels on Facebook offering an attractive Dubai tour package. Puranik filled up the details to get the quotation for the tour.

Later, he was contacted by one Ajay Rathod claiming to be from Trip Zolo. A few days later, Puranik received a mail claiming that a ‘six days, seven nights’ tour to Dubai will cost around Rs55,000 per person. On finding the deal cheap, Puranik along with Hitesh and two others decided to avail the offer.

As instructed, the four deposited Rs2.10 lakh in an account in the name of Abhishek Fasin as advance and received 14 tickets of a flight from Nagpur to Sharjah . However, later it turned out that the tickets had been cancelled.

On further enquiries it was revealed that the accused had ‘booked’ the tickets without paying money. A few airlines offer to block the tickets for a short period and the same get cancelled automatically if the fare is not paid within some hours.

When the four tried to contact Ajay, his mobile was switched off. After realizing that they have been duped, the four friends approached Tehsil police and lodged a complaint.

The police have tracked the travel agency to Haryana and have registered a case of fraud against the accused under sections of IPC and IT Act.

Title: EOW to send gutka samples for test after food safety clearance
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bhopal: The Madhya Pradesh economic offences wing (EOW) has decided that samples of gutka and other raw materials that the food safety department had received following purity tests, would be sent for separate testing.

Incidentally, the EOW had recently raided a factory in Govindpura and seized samples of gutka and other raw materials. On Monday, the food safety department received reports of 40 samples sent for purity test, which included 12 samples of gutka. Out of the total 40, 15 have failed the test while remaining 25 cleared the Food Safety & Standards Act (FSSA) standards.

Among the 12 gutka samples, six samples of known gutka companies were found substandard while none of them were found unsafe for consumption.

The EOW, however, has decided to send samples of the gutka and raw materials for investigations to examine whether it contains hazardous substances, sources said.

“EOW has received some complaints about the samples so they want to verify at their own level,” said an officer in the local administration. Role of some top officials of the food department are also under scanner.

Meanwhile, sample of a brand of gutka, produced in Uttar Pradesh’s Noida, taken during a drive in MP were found to have magnesium carbonate content more than permissible limit, and has, therefore, been classified unsafe for consumption. Sample of betel leaves taken from New Market was declared ‘unsafe’ because it contained tobacco as well.

Besides, four milk samples taken from two establishment in the city were found substandard because they did not have the requisite fat content.

Producers/suppliers of all the samples found substandard or unsafe are being served notices under the provision of FSSA, said DK Verma, senior food safety officer based at Bhopal.

Meanwhile, mobile food lab, which is going to various localities in Bhopal to display how purity of edibles is checked can be checked at homes itself, on Monday went to Indrapuri, Anand Nagar, Gulmohar, Piplani and Bawadia Kalan areas and interacted with residents there. The sample brought by residents were put to test before them by the technicians accompanying the mobile lab and report were submitted on the spot. They were also given tips on how they can themselves check purity of goods by simple techniques. In all, 32 samples were tested in the drive against adulteration, now christened as ‘Shudh Ke Liye Yudh’.

Incidentally, it was the final day of mobile food lab on the roads of Bhopal. During past 10 days, while operating in different areas of Bhopal, the lab tested more than 300 samples brought by residents.

Title: Delay in shifting cattle market irks farmers
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Tirupur: The delay in shifting the weekly cattle market at Thennampalayam to a convenient place in the city has frustrated farmers.

Despite promising to shift the cattle market to Koyilvazhi or other convenient place a few months ago, the city corporation is yet to take a concrete decision on it, a farmer alleged.

With cattle from across the district and neighbouring districts being brought to the Monday market, the need for a bigger space is imminent. “The cattle market could have been convenient during the early days but now the city has grown and become more congested. Moreover, the cattle market’s space was divided to accommodate daily vegetable market, fish market, and Ulavar Santhai. So, the farmers who bring the cattle were put into hardship,” said M Eesan, a farmer from Pollikalipalayam.

“The vehicles which bring the cattle should wait in long queues on Palladam Road and ABT Road for several hours to enter the market. The cattle struggle to stand under the sun,” Eesan said.

P Mahesh Kumar of Poomalur, another farmer, said, “There were works undertaken under the Smart City scheme in the market area, and it has further shrunk the space. The cattle market does not have basic amenities to provide drinking water to either cattle or farmers. There is lack of toilet facility too.”

Corporation commissioner K Sivakumar said, “We have written to the district administration to provide a land at Koyilvazhi two months ago. If the farmers wanted to shift them immediately, we will take action soon.”

Title: Kolkata: New step to put buses under lens
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Traffic cops are consulting with the detective department to develop a standard operating procedure, by which all drink driving and rash driving cases lead to temporary suspension of licences.

The local traffic control room (TCR) and Lalbazar control room will also use modern technology to identify the buses breaking rules like overtaking and blocking bus channels. Local guards will be asked to take stringent actions against them. This move comes for the areas where traffic sergeants are not stationed.

On Monday, cops from 25 traffic guards and senior officers at Lalbazar discussed to find ways to curb fatal accidents, especially those involving buses. “Commissioner Anuj Sharma asked us to take steps to control accidents. We discussed all possible steps that can be taken,” said a police officer.

In addition, police have identified certain black spots at Shyambazar, BT Road, Ultadanga and several other stretches under the South guard, where introducing road furniture is a must to stop bus accidents. “This will include setting up bumble strips.

In several cases, roles of the bus conductor and the pedestrian are as questionable as that of the driver, said the police, adding that the black spots are among the city’s worst performing zones.

“Maximum accidents happen when motorists try to overtake the buses blocking or stopping in the middle of the road,” said a police officer. However, cops will urge Kolkata Municipal Corporation to block open spaces that will channelize pedestrian flow at the crossings.

Cops have cited certain examples to substantiate their point. There have been several accidents in the past on either side of Howrah Bridge’s approach road where the victims had tried to board a bus with luggage and fell down after losing balance.

At Maniktala, Bagmari and Ultadanga, pedestrians block roads to board buses and meet with accidents.

Title: Shivneri bus hits bike, runs over woman riding pillion near Wakad bridge
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Pune: A 25-year-old woman pillion rider died and her husband sustained injuries after their motorcycle was hit by a Shivneri bus near Wakad bridge on Sunday afternoon.

The Hinjewadi police identified the deceased woman as Ashwini Tanaji Murudkar of Bhosari. Her husband Tanaji (28) has lodged an FIR against the bus driver with the Hinjewadi police.

“We have confiscated the vehicle and ascertained the identity of the driver who will soon be arrested,” A B Hingole, sub-inspector of the Hinjewadi police, said.

Hingole said the accident happened around 12.30pm on Sunday when both vehicles were travelling towards Chandni Chowk. When they reached the bridge over the river, in an attempt to overtake Murudkar’s motorcycle, the bus dashed it. “Due to the impact, Ashwini, who was riding pillion fell off the motorcycle and came under the wheels of the bus,” Hingole said.

The driver fled after the accident. “We have booked the driver under section 304 A (causing death due to negligence), 279 (rash driving), 337, 338 (causing grievous hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) of the Indian Penal Code,” Hingole said.

Title: BJP, AAP want apology from SWR manager
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: BJP and AAP have demanded immediate action against the general manager of South Western Railways for referring to MLA Alina Saldanha and the people of Cortalim as ‘Portuguese’.

Bringing the issue to the attention of the Union railways minister and the Prime Minister’s office, BJP spokesperson and former MP Narendra Sawaikar tweeted, “We are Indians firstly & lastly. @PMOIndia @PiyushGoyal @PiyushGoyalOffc@RailMinIndia”. He demanded an apology from the general manager.

Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) convener Elvis Gomes also asked that the official be sacked and launched an attack on the official’s arrogance in insulting Goans by calling them non-Indians in the presence of BJP MLA Alina Saldanha.

The remarks by Ajay Singh directed at Alina are “audacious” and showed that the BJP MLA was found wanting in giving an adequate response. “I call upon Goans to boycott BJP which is engaged in spreading communal poison through mindless laws such as CAA,” said Pradeep Padgaonkar, AAP general secretary.

Title: Pune: IMD hints at second cold spell around Republic Day
Content:
Minimum temperatures might be short-lived and replaced by another cold spell in Maharashtra

PUNE: Citizens planning to celebrate this year’s Republic Day outdoors may have to ensure multiple layers of warmers, as the city is expected to record the second and longest spell of cold conditions this season from January 25 to 26.India Meteorological Department (IMD) officials on Monday said the current rise in minimum temperatures might be short-lived and replaced by another cold spell in Maharashtra , during which the minimum temperature could fall to around 8 degrees Celsius, or even less, in Pune. If this happens, the city could have one of its lowest night temperatures for the season so far. Till now, the lowest minimum temperature in Pune has been 8.2 degrees C.Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD, Pune, told TOI that the cold conditions would peak across Maharashtra around January 26-27, when night temperatures in many locations could plunge below 10 degrees Celsius. “The upcoming cold spell in Maharashtra, including Pune, may also be the first for the state that would continue for a few days,” he said.After January 28, Kashyapi said, the northerly wind component over Maharashtra would partially reduce, but moderate cold flow would still continue till around January 29-30 in the lower atmospheric level at a 900m height from the mean sea level. “From January 26, we may expect cold wave conditions over isolated parts of Maharashtra for a couple of days. Chances of ground frost in one or two pockets can also not be ruled out during this period, especially for the northern parts of the state, including Pune district. The upcoming cold spell can also be stronger than the last one experienced on January 17-18,” he said.“Cold northerly winds would begin penetrating the state around January 24 noon or evening onwards. One of the reasons for the resettling of northerly winds in the state would be the shifting of the anticyclone, which currently lies over south of Orissa, adjacent Chattisgarh, and eastern parts of Vidarbha. This anticyclone will begin moving southwards from January 24-25 and slowly disappear. It is the location of the anticyclone that has been blocking the northerly winds from entering the state from time to time. Once it moves away, the path of northerly winds to enter Maharashtra could clear up,” Kashyapi said.Citizens may have to take extra precautions to keep the cold at bay if they are planning to go out to celebrate Republic Day. Harshad Limaye, a biker participating in a biking event ‘Republic Day Ride 2020’ on January 26 morning, said, “Apart from the riding jackets, helmets and mufflers we wear during the biking events in winter, we would wear an extra pair of clothes to keep the chill at bay.”

Title: Personal hurdles do not stop this Tirupur girl from winning laurels in kabaddi
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Tirupur: A Class XII girl from the city, who was part of the state kabaddi team that won the silver medal in Khelo India Games, says she wants to represent India in international competitions and bring glory to the country.

G Yalini of Jaivabai Corporation Girls’ Higher Secondary School and her team were runnerup in the under-17 category in Khelo India Games 2020 held in Guwahati.

The 16-year-old girl was living with her grandmother after her parents got divorced when she was 2. “My grandma used to work in a knitwear unit and raised me with her meagre income. After she stopped working, I moved to a hostel. The Tirupur district Kabaddi association helped me to get a sponsor for my education,” Yalini said.

She says she is more passionate about kabaddi than academics. “For almost six years, I have been training in APJ Abdul Kalam Sports Academy at Thirumuruganpoondi. Though I was good in both kabaddi and athletics, I chose kabaddi when I got a seat in the sports hostel of Sports Development Authority of Tamil Nadu in Namakkal. I was trained in the sport for two years there,” she said.

Later, Yalini moved to Tirupur and joined APJ Abdul Kalam Sports Academy. “I improved my skill and got selected to the Tamil Nadu team. Unfortunately, we lost to Haryana in the finals by 25-20 score.”

I want to play kabaddi till I feel it is enough and represent India and win laurels for her, she says.

Yalini’s coach M Chinnappa Das at the academy says Yalini is one of the best players there. “We have 40 girls currently. It is an honour to us that she is from our academy,” he said. Though we face financial and other constraints, we try to give our best to the girls, he added.

Title: How to balance studies & co-curricular activities, Jabalpur girl asks PM Modi
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bhopal: A class 9 girl from Kendriya Vidyalaya in Garha, Jabalpur, got a chance to ask Prime Minister Narendra Modi a question related to extra-curricular activities during ‘Pariksha Pe Charcha’ 2020, held at the Talkatora indoor stadium in New Delhi. A team of 50 students from Madhya Pradesh had also been selected to participate in the event.

Prajakta Atankar, the student from Jabalpur asked the PM, about how to balance studies and extra-curricular activities. She said it was difficult for her to strike a balance between studies and extra-curriculars as they created a distraction for her.

Answering her question, the PM said, “If you do not participate in extra-curricular activities and only keep doing the same thing – going to school and coming back home, as if you have been programmed, you will turn into a robot, which will not be beneficial to you, nor the country.”

“It is important to manage time so that you can participate in other activities and also give proper time to your studies. Don’t consider extra-curricular activities a waste of time,” added the PM.

On the same subject, he addressed the parents and asked them not to make co-curricular activities a burden on children by pressuring them to go to different classes and asking them to excel in every activity.

“Today, it has become a fashion-statement for parents to send their children for all kinds of classes before and after school. They then brag to their friends that their child is learning so many things and at the same time pressurize the children to learn things they do not even have an interest in. Parents should understand that these glamour-driven extra-curricular activities build unnecessary pressure on children, so they should refrain from such attitudes,” said PM Modi.

The 50 students, who went to attend the event from MP, were given souvenirs. They all got a chance to be a part of the interaction with Narendra Modi, even if they did not get a chance to ask their questions at the event.

“I had prepared a question about dealing with exam stress, but as another student asked the same, I got my answer even though I did not get a chance to ask the question myself. It was a wonderful experience to be there and I will remember it for years to come,” said Kritika Sen, a student of Class 11 of Deepak Memorial Academy, Sagar.

Title: Bodies of 3 missing boys from Nizamabad found in trench
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hyderabad: Three minor boys, who went missing on Sunday from Neela village in Nizamabad district, were found drowned in a trench in the village. The bodies of the three boys — Siddharth, Deepak and Mukheed —were fished out on Monday after they were spotted in a trench.

Police said the three boys, all aged between 7 and 8 years, left their house on Sunday to play with motorcycle tyres.

While they were playing with tyres, they accidentally fell into a trench. Though police were not sure how the three fell into the trench, they suspect that the boys might have fallen at once into the trench, which was very deep.

The bodies were recovered by district authorities after swimmers were pressed into action. The bodies of the boys were sent to the area hospital for post-mortem examination.

Title: Police deny nod for rally against CAA on Avinashi Road
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police have denied permission to Coimbatore District All Jamaath and Federation of Islamic Organisations to conduct a rally against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) from the VOC Park ground to the Codissia ground.

Representatives from the federation petitioned the police officials on January 17, seeking permission to conduct the rally on February 2 on Avinashi Road.

As Avinashi Road is a key arterial road that leads to hospitals, educational institutions and the international airport and as already construction works are slowing down vehicular movements on the road, police had denied permission for the rally, a police officer said.

Earlier on Monday, deputy commissioner of police (law&order) L Balaji Saravanan met a group of representatives from the organisations at his chamber. The DCP told them that already Tamil Nadu Muslim Munnetra Kazhagam (KMMK), PFI, SDPI and all the jamaaths had conducted more than 50 protests against CAA in the city.

Title: Students ‘reap’ what they ‘sow’ in midday meals
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

NAGPUR: A photo showing school students tending to their mini-farm on campus seems to have gone viral on WhatsApp groups, with people appreciating their efforts to grow vegetables for midday meals . The photos are from a zilla parishad (ZP) school located in a remote village of Bhamragad taluka of Gadchiroli district, where tribal students take pride in growing their own food for midday meals.

The Koyanguda ZP primary school is a small unit with just 32 students on rolls, but that does not deter them from trying to make a difference. This concept of growing vegetables on campus, popularly known as kitchen garden, is practised in quite a few government schools of Nagpur division after it was first mooted by the education department in 2012.

Koyanguda’s case is made unique by the fact that the land they are tilling does not belong to the school. Villager Vasudeo Ramsu Habka owns a piece of land adjoining the school and ‘donated’ a part of his holding, so that children could get ‘real life lessons’ and become stronger stakeholders in the midday meals scheme.

Principal Vinit Padmawar said, “We started this mini-farm last year and since then, have been able to generate a steady supply of fresh vegetables and fulfil daily requirements of green chillies, coriander etc. This has brought an immense change of attitude among children, who now see themselves as equal partners in the midday meals scheme.” Daily duties like watering the plants, plucking the daily kitchen requirements for tomatoes, chillies and identifying problems with the plants have been properly divided.

Nagesh Habka, whose father owns the mini-farm, says there’s something different about produce coming from that patch of land. “We all find it to be tastier than vegetables which come from the market or other farms,” he said over the phone. Padmawar believes that the ‘tasty’ part comes from their involvement in seeing their hard work pay off.

As of now, Koyanguda’s mini-farm produces ample weekly stock of brinjals, with students planning to diversify their stock. Padmawar said, “I hope that every school in the country does this as it will help create self reliance, and also teach children about how much hard work is required to bring food to our tables.”

Title: Advt for Guj RERA appellate tribunal posts challenged
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Ahmedabad: The state government’s advertisement for the posts of the Gujarat RERA appellate tribunal’s chairman and member was challenged in the Gujarat high court on Monday.

The state government published an advertisement on January 4 inviting applications from qualified persons for the post of chairman and member of the Gujarat Real Estate Regulatory Authority (RERA) appellate tribunal. The advertisement was issued after the high court gave notice to the state government in response to a PIL demanding the appointments.

The PIL filed by advocate Nipun Singhvi objected to the present functioning of the appellate tribunal, which is being run by the presiding officer of the Gujarat State Food Safety Tribunal.

After the government came up with the advertisement, petitioner Singhvi objected to the mode of recruitment. He submitted before the HC that the law mandates that the chairman of Guj RERA appellate tribunal has to be appointed by the government in consultation with the chief justice of the high court. Inviting applications cannot be the method to fill the post.

Similarly, the petitioner has taken exception to the eligibility criteria laid down for the post of the tribunal’s member. The petitioner requested the high court to allow him to make changes in his PIL and to incorporate the challenge to the advertisement. The high court has granted the permission, said petitioner’s advocate Vishal Dave.

The petitioner has sought HC directions to the government to appoint people for the post of chairperson and members in the tribunal by following the procedure laid down in Section 46 of the RERA act.

The HC is to hear the issue further two weeks later.

Title: NMC inspects MK Shah Medical College
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

AHMEDABAD: The surprise inspection at MK Shah Medical College has raised questions about the facilities at the college. Officials of the National Medical Commission (NMC) found that several staffers were on leave and there were no patients in the outpatient department.

Sources said that on Monday a three-member team of the NMC reached the college and carried out a surprise check and found no doctors and staff present. On inquiring, they found that the staff was on leave because of the wedding season.

The team which carried out the raid continued its checking in the institute till late at night. Officials said that usually such surprise inspections are never carried out by the NMC. In the case of the MK Shah College, this was a surprise raid. Usually, the NMC sends a detailed report about discrepancies at colleges. Officials said no such report pointing out discrepancies was submitted by the NMC to the government or to the institute.

Officials that after this surprise visit, there is a possibility that the college might see a cut in the number of seats or face a heavy penalty. The college has 150 medical seats. The team also inspected facilities at Himmatnagar Government Medical College. The college is managed by ther Gujarat Medical Education Research Society and has 150 seats.

Title: Call to allocate funds for northern Andhra
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Former member of the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) KS Chalam demanded the government allot Rs 50,000 crore for the development of north Andhra districts and not shift the executive capital in future. An Act should be introduced to ensure this, he said.

Addressing a debate on ‘What north Andhra needs’, Chalam welcomed the Bill to notify Visakhapatnam as the executive capital and demanded the government provide jobs to 85 per cent of those eligible for employment in the region. “North Andhra is more backward than Anantapur . Though it has 16 rivers, agriculture s not developed here,” he said.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Of havans, poll promises and barbs
Content:
Vijender Gupta

NEW DELHI: Leader of Opposition in the outgoing Delhi assembly and BJP candidate from Rohini, Vijender Gupta , on Monday conducted a havan at Shiv Mandir in his colony before taking out a procession to submit his nomination . Gupta, who is confident of getting re-elected, claimed AAP government hadn’t done any productive work in the city.Apart from Gupta, several other prominent candidates filed their papers for the February 8 election. Among them were cabinet minister Satyendar Jain, BJP MLA OP Sharma and senior functionary RP Singh, three-time Congress MLA Arvinder Singh Lovely and Alka Lamba.Self-assured about getting re-elected, Gupta said: “BJP will form the government this time. Delhi will support Prime Minister Modi. Baaje gaaje ke saath, we are going to file the nomination. We are talking about Delhi ka vikas. Modi chale Delhi ke saath. Prachand bahumat se BJP will form a government.”On whether the twin issues of CAA and NRC were factors, he said the people would answer that question. “A conspiracy is being hatched in the country. AAP and Congress are doing this...blocking roads. I ask (Arvind) Kejriwal to come out and say whether he supports CAA or not. What does he want?” Gupta, the sitting MLA from Rohini, said.Congress’ Lovely, on the other hand, kept things simple as he went to the SDMC office in Gandhi Nagar along with a few supporters to file his nomination. “In the last five years, the traders have suffered a lot due to the sealing of shops and the economic slowdown. Even residents didn’t see any improvement in infrastructure. The roads are broken, water supply is poor and the number of community halls has remained stagnant,” Lovely said.He alleged that the elected representative was missing from the area and Delhi government had failed to initiate any development work in the constituency.Lovely also claimed to have worked closely with the residents in his years as an MLA in 1998-2013. “Being a local, I am aware about the problems faced by the residents. They trusted me for 15 years and I am sure that, if given the opportunity, I will be able to work even harder to speed up development work, which was on hold for five years,” he said.Delhi health minister Satyendar Jain filed his nomination from Shakur Basti.Congress candidate from Chandni Chowk, Alka Lamba, too, filed her papers, but wasn’t accompanied by supporters to “avoid inconvenience to commuters”. She said: “I am confident people will show the door to corrupt candidates,” she tweeted.

On whether the twin issues of CAA and NRC were factors, he said the people would answer that question. “A conspiracy is being hatched in the country. AAP and Congress are doing this...blocking roads. I ask (Arvind) Kejriwal to come out and say whether he supports CAA or not. What does he want?” Gupta, the sitting MLA from Rohini, said.

Congress’ Lovely, on the other hand, kept things simple as he went to the SDMC office in Gandhi Nagar along with a few supporters to file his nomination. “In the last five years, the traders have suffered a lot due to the sealing of shops and the economic slowdown. Even residents didn’t see any improvement in infrastructure. The roads are broken, water supply is poor and the number of community halls has remained stagnant,” Lovely said.

He alleged that the elected representative was missing from the area and Delhi government had failed to initiate any development work in the constituency.

Lovely also claimed to have worked closely with the residents in his years as an MLA in 1998-2013. “Being a local, I am aware about the problems faced by the residents. They trusted me for 15 years and I am sure that, if given the opportunity, I will be able to work even harder to speed up development work, which was on hold for five years,” he said.

Delhi health minister Satyendar Jain filed his nomination from Shakur Basti.Congress candidate from Chandni Chowk, Alka Lamba, too, filed her papers, but wasn’t accompanied by supporters to “avoid inconvenience to commuters”. She said: “I am confident people will show the door to corrupt candidates,” she tweeted.

Title: ‘Comunidades not funded by govt, not answerable to it’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: South Goa Comunidades Forum stated that comunidades do not receive any funding from the government and hence are not required to share records or information beyond their organisation.

Reacting to the order of the state information commission to declare comunidades as public authorities for effective implementation of the right to information act, the forum stated that the issue of whether comunidades are public bodies or not is pending in the high court in a number of writ petitions. In an earlier decision, the high court held them to be private bodies, the forum stated.

Forum secretary Savio Correia said that comunidades are autonomous bodies where the government only exercises administrative tutelage. “Much before coming into force of the RTI Act, the code of comunidades had envisaged the need for dissemination of information relating to its functioning among its shareholders and enabled it under Article 26 (7) and Article 88 (d),” Correia stated.

He added that protection of a private body from alleged loot and plunder cannot be grounds for recommending it to be declared as a public authority under RTI Act.

President of the Guirim comunidade and member of the erstwhile comunidade commission Tulio D’Souza said the existing code of comunidade provides sufficient transparency. “The comunidade is duty bound to provide information within the general body of its component but not to the public at large,” he said.

The government, he added, can direct comunidades to provide any information through the administrator of comunidades under sec 88(d). “It remains to be seen if any notification as directed by the state information commission order can be issued by the government within the provisions of the existing code of comunidade,” D’Souza said.

Title: Telangana: Asifabad rape case verdict on January 27

This story is from January 21, 2020
