Title: Lions walk 150km in four days to go back
Content:
File photo used for representational purpose

AHMEDABAD: When a lion and a cub were spotted in Dedhuki village near the temple town of Chotila in Surendranagar, they hit the headlines. Reports suggested that the big cats — whose population is burgeoning in Gir — had extended their footprints to another district! Informal estimates have pegged the lion population to be more than 700.Two months later, the lion and the cub may have become homesick. The state forest department is abuzz with speculation that the two are headed home to Amreli. “The lions have started retreating from Chotila, having trekked 150km over the past four days to Sardhar. Their movement was recorded last at Aji Dam near Rajkot city,” said S K Srivastava, the chief conservator of forest of Junagadh .Sandeep Kumar, the deputy conservator of forest (DCF) of Morbi, who is monitoring the movement of the lion and the cub, said that the extensive movement indicated that the lion is either searching for a suitable place or a mating partner to establish its own territory. “It is highly possible that it might settle down once it finds a partner,” said Kumar. “The other possibility is that the two lions may have got lost and have begun the journey to get back home.”Officials said that the lions were spotted in Dedhuki on November 20. This was significant as it marked the entry of lions into the sixth district of the state. For two months, they kept moving in the area — the farthest they went was to Kuvadava, 19km from Rajkot city only to come back.On Wednesday night, they embarked on the journey back and travelled 35km in a night. They crossed Gondal city and travelled on the Rajkot-Porbandar national highway up to Shapar near Rajkot. They were sighted last on Monday morning near Aji Dam in Sardhar village on the outskirts of Rajkot city.

Title: Shirdi Sai Baba temple consecrated
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Trichy: One of the largest temples for Shridi Sai Baba in south India, Akkaraipatti Sai Baba temple complex, was consecrated near Samayapuram here on Monday. Thousands of people from various parts of the state thronged the complex to witness the rituals.

Coined by the devotees as south Shirdi, home for the 19th-century saint Sai Baba, the Akkaraipatti Sai baba temple has a plinth area of 35,000sqft. The basement is likely to be used for yoga and meditation purposes. The ground floor of the complex accommodates a massive statue of the saint. The first floor of the complex has provisions for devotees to witness pujas from the corridors.

The complex also has four sub-shrines, including one for Vinayaka. Sources involved in the construction said that the work on the complex taken up at the end of 2015 was completed in December 2019. The consecration rituals were initiated by the priests by 7am. Around 9.30am, the kalasam of the temple situated at a height of 100ft was consecrated by priests by pouring holy water. The temple is situated about 4km from the Samayapuram toll plaza on the Chennai - Trichy national highway.

Title: Plea to conduct consecration of Big Temple in Tamil
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Trichy: The Thanjai Periyakoil Urimai Meetpukkuzhu (Thanjavur Big temple Rights Retrieval Committee) has planned to conduct a day-long conference at the Cauvery wedding hall in Nanjikottai in Thanjavur on Wednesday demanding the conduct of consecration ceremony of Brihadeeswara temple in Tamil.

The committee is opposing the consecration and associated rituals in Sanskrit. The meet is expected to be attended by spiritual leaders and Tamil scholars. Addressing reporters on Monday, P Maniyarasan, coordinator of the committee said, “Hinduism has multiple facets and worshipping procedures. Thanjavur Peruvudaiyur temple belongs to Tamil Saivism. Hence, conducting the consecration ceremony in Sanskrit is completely unacceptable.” Brihadeeswara temple, one of Unesco’s world heritage sites, has been gearing up for the consecration ceremony planned on February 5.

“Various political parties and organisations have expressed their stand by reiterating the need to conduct the consecration of Peruvudaiyar temple in Tamil instead of Sanskrit. Tamil Nadu government should take a decision in favour of Tamil language since the temple is considered as the cultural, architectural and spiritual identity of Tamils,” Maniyarasan added. TNN

Title: 124 protestors identified in Rajgarh, 12 arrested
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representativ eimage

BHOPAL: A day after a pro-CAA rally by BJP supporters in Rajgarh where protestors clashed with district administration, police identified 124 of the 500 people and arrested 12 people on Monday for violating section 144.

“Of the 12 people, including five women have been arrested. Search for other people among the 124 identified is going on and we are also trying to identify other protestors through the video footages,” Rajgarh SP Pradeep Sharma told TOI.

He added, “approximately 500 people have participated in the protests, these are estimates as per the statements of the officials. Numbers would be clear once we verify the video footages.

Apart from it, we have also arrested one person on the complaint by a female officer who alleged she was assaulted. One of the two accused, Bhupendra Rajput resident of Rajgarh was arrested and produced before court. We sought remand of the accused for one day,” Sharma said.

“We have the pictures of other accused but he is yet to be identified,” he said.

In the meantime, local BJP workers handed over a complaint urging the police to register a case against district collector Nidhi Nivedita.

On Sunday despite prohibitory orders, BJP workers led by former MLAs Amar Singh Yadav, Mohan Sharma and district president of BJP Dilbar Singh Yadav, took out a ‘tiranga yatra’ in support of CAA in Biaora town on Sunday. The situation took an ugly turn when district collector and another female officer had to take control of the situation. They lost their cool, and slapped protestors.

Title: Public sector banks to stay closed from Jan 31 to Feb 2
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Ahmedabad: If you are a salary account holder in a public-sector bank, chances are your pay might get stalled by three days, as public-sector banks will remain shut from January 31 to February 2 as bank employees will go on a two-day strike on January 31-February 1 (Friday and Saturday). As Sunday happens to be a bank holiday, public sector banks across Gujarat will remain shut for three consecutive days.

Some 70,000 bank employees and officers from across public sector banks in Gujarat are expected to go on a strike on these two days to protest non-revision of their wages. In fact, bank employees also held a demonstration outside UCO Bank on Monday evening to protest non-revision of wages. “The wage revision for bank employees has been pending since November 2012. Last year, banks made a provision worth Rs 1.25 lakh crore from their own profits for writing off non-performing assets (NPAs). Banks must make efforts to revise wages of their own employees,” said Janak Rawal, general secretary, Maha Gujarat Bank Employees’ Association (MGBEA).

Apart from wage revision, bank employees have also sought to initiate recruitment in banks. “We want the of new pension scheme for bankers to be scrapped have urged the government to re-initiate recruitment in the banking sector,” Rawal added.

Title: Gujarat high court grants permission for abortion to minor rape victim

This story is from January 21, 2020

Gujarat high court

Title: HC asks govt to compensate latest owner of land
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Ahmedabad: The Gujarat high court on Monday asked the state government to pay compensation to the latest owner of a land parcel in Kutch district, which was acquired by the government upon paying the compensation to the previous owners.

To the HC’s insistence that the state government should pay the new owner, Bhadresh Shah, the state government submitted that it would inform the court on Thursday about whether it would pay the entire compensation amount to the new owner, said Shah’s advocate Nirav Sanghvi.

The previous owners of the land, who had accepted the land compensation have been put behind bars by the administration. Proceedings have been initiated against a few revenue officials also for the goof.

In this case, Shah had purchased a piece of land in Nani Chher village of Lakhpat taluka in Kutch in 2006 and made payment to the previous owners, a Padiar family. A year later, the authorities initiated land acquisition process in the area for the Gujarat Mineral Corporation Ltd. The plot sold to Shah was also acquired. However, the compensation was paid to the Padiars after the process was over in 2011.

Shah took up the issue before the authorities, but nothing happened. He insisted that the revenue department should file a suit in court against the previous owners. With this demand, Shah approached the high court last year. The HC had called for records and summoned the district collector for explanation.

Finally, following the HC directions, the government lodged an FIR against the previous landowners, and initiated departmental proceedings against revenue officials.

Title: 16,000 drunken driving cases filed in Coimbatore in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The city police had registered the second highest number of drunken driving cases — 16,451 — in the state in 2019.

While the Chennai city police had registered about 48,000 cases, the Madurai city police had filed 9,900 cases in the same period. Police have already started cracking down this year as 1,140 cases of drunken driving have been registered in the city from January 1. To prevent fatal accidents in the city, police have been booking at least 60 cases of drunken driving every day, city police commissioner Sumit Sharan said. “We don’t collect spot fine for drunken driving as we sent the report to the court. The drunken drivers are fined Rs 10,000 each by the court,” he said.

While 132 people lost their lives in road mishaps in the city in 2019, it was 162 in 2018. The fatal accidents came down because of various efforts taken by the city police, he said. “Now, we started cracking down on vehicles using LED lights and air horns. The court imposes a fine of Rs 10,000 for using LED lights on two wheelers and other vehicles. In the case of air horns, we collect fine of Rs 1,000 penalty,” he said, adding, more cases will be filed against people violating traffic rules.

Title: Move to pick directors by ad hoc panel raises brows at BDU
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Trichy: The move by Bharathidasan University (BDU) vice-chancellor P Manisankar to select candidates through an ad hoc committee has raised several eyebrows as 11 candidates will be interviewed for two statutory posts on Tuesday.

The university intends to appoint two directors for the centre for distance education (CDE) and the council for curriculum and career development (CCCD). Data accessed by TOI reveal that five candidates have been shortlisted for CDE, but none meets the minimum eligibility criteria.

A senior faculty said the university is most likely to face objection from local fund audit if it goes ahead with the appointment through an ad hoc committee, adding that the directors hired the last two times were appointed after constituting a statutory committee.

The committee will comprise a nominee each from the governor’s office and state government, unlike in the case of the selection committee constituted by incumbent syndicate members, said the official.

An highly-placed source from the university said that candidates have already been selected for the post and interview is a mere formality. “This is perhaps the reason why the university received just 11 applications for the post,” said a senior faculty from BDU.

When asked about ineligible candidates for CDE director, BDU registrar G Gopinath, said that a scrutiny committee constituted by the vice-chancellor has scrutinised the applications based on which candidates have been called for the interview on Tuesday.

Asked as to why only 11 applications were received for the posts when direct recruitment of 54 faculty positions received 1,600 applications, Gopinath said faculty positions were from multiple departments, but for applying for a director’s post, a candidate should at least be an associate professor. Further, the post is for a three-year tenure.

Title: Assembly passes bills paving way for three capital cities
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Vijayawada: Amid uproarious scenes, the Andhra Pradesh assembly on Monday night passed two bills paving way for three capital cities in the state, signalling the end of the road for the much-touted greenfield capital in Amaravati.

With the passing of the two bills, the YSRC government led by Y S Jaganmohan Reddy scored a huge political victory over former chief minister and TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu.

Unfazed by the ongoing protests by farmers in the capital city region in Amaravati, the government introduced the two bills for the trifurcation of the capital. After the day-long discussion on both bills, the assembly passed the bills with voice vote. Speaker Tammineni Sitaram suspended 17 TDP legislators.

TDP is now planning to stall the bill in the legislative council where it enjoys majority.

On Monday morning, the cabinet met ahead of the assembly session and approved the bills which were then discussed in the assembly Business Advisory Committee (BAC) meeting. After the BAC meeting, the bills were introduced in the assembly paving the way for the trifurcation of the capital.

Finance minister Buggana Rajendranath introduced the Andhra Pradesh Decentralisation and Inclusive Development of All Regions (APDIDAR) Act 2020.

Title: 2 burglars remanded in police custody
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nashik: The Panchavati police have arrested two men and detained a juvenile in connection to a house break-in case committed by them at Sriram Vijay Society near Kalaram temple on Saturday evening.

The suspect duo was produced on Monday before a city court that remanded them in two-day police custody. “The suspects were arrested within 10 hours after a complaint was lodged,” a police officer said. The juvenile, however, has been sent to a correction home.

“At 4pm on Saturday, some unidentified suspects had entered a closed flat in Sriram Vijay Society by breaking the latch and lock of the house. They decamped with Rs 42,000 cash kept in a wooden cupboard inside the bedroom,” the officer added.

Assistant police inspector Sanjay Wankhede of Panchavati police station said that soon after the compliant was lodged they immediately swung into action and caught the suspects in no time.

Title: Three of Goswami gang taken for voice tests
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Vishal Goswami

Ahmedabad: Alleged gangster Vishal Goswami and his aides Ajay and Rinku, were brought out of jail on Sunday and taken to Forensic Science Laboratory for voice spectrograph tests on Monday by crime branch personnel.

Crime branch officials said after the first invocation of GujCTOC in the state, Section 268 of the CrPC was revoked on Ajay Goswami, Rinku Goswami and Vishal and they were brought out of jail.

“Suraj Goswmai, Bijendra Goswami, Jaypuri Goswami and Anuraj Verma had already been arrested and are in police custody till January 24, for allegedly running an extortion racket from within the jail. Vishal, Ajay and Rinku were remanded in crime branch custody for eight days by the court on Monday. The gang is from Morena district of MP and operating across the country, extorting businessmen, jewellers and bookies,” said a senior crime branch official.

The gang members are accused of 28 offences in Ahmedabad.

Title: Card data theft: Hoteliers hand-pick staffers to operate swipe machines
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Spooked by recent reports of data from guests’ credit card being stolen at restaurants

KOLKATA: Spooked by recent reports of data from guests’ credit card being stolen at restaurants, hoteliers and restaurateurs have decided to put in place safety measures and issue an advisory to customers.

The owner of a restaurant from where cases of data theft was detected got so rattled initially that he had even considered stopping card transactions only to realise that it was not a practical option given that 65%-70% customers pay their bill with plastic money.

“Card data theft is an extremely grave issue. It threatens the reputation of a business. If there is a theft from the cash box, it is an internal matter. But if a client's credit or debit card data is skimmed at a restaurant, not only will the customer never return, the news will spread over word of mouth and the reputation of the place will be tarnished forever. People will not trust the place any more. It doesn't matter if a professional gang that managed to infiltrate did it with no knowledge or involvement of either the owner or the managers, we cannot shrug off responsibility since it happened on the premises. We have to act to save our reputation,” he said.

Among the measures that several restaurant owners have either already taken or are in the process of doing so is fix responsibility. “Only hand-picked few trusted staff who have been working in the establishment for several years will handle the point-of-sale (POS) terminal used for card transactions,” said Suresh Poddar, who owns multiple restaurants in the central business district and is also the HRAEI secretary.

That is a significant change from the earlier practice of the waiter assigned to a table carrying the POS to the customer at the end of the meal. With only three of four persons now allowed to handle POS terminals, restaurateurs believe the machines will be more secure and the likelihood of customers being defrauded remote. “Fixing responsibility will act as a deterrent. If a fraud still does occur, the person can be easily identified. It will be one of the persons to whom the task has been assigned,” Poddar pointed out.

The POS terminal ‘handlers’, who are in several instances the managers who take the order, are also being taught card transaction etiquette that includes looking the other way when a guest enters the PIN. “Most POS terminals now have a cover over the keypad to hide the fingers when the PIN is being keyed in. Looking away only adds to the customer's sense of comfort and security,” explained Pranav Singh , president of HRAEI that has 1,000-plus members.

While restaurants are taking precautions, HRAEI functionaries also realise the need to caution customers. “We will make our premises safe. But customers, too, should be aware of what they are entitled to and how they should handle cards. We are preparing an advisory that will be issued soon,” said Poddar.

A draft of the customer notification that is proposed to be displayed by the HRAEI members is ready and will be handed out to all restaurants after it is ratified at the next meeting of the association in February where the issue of credit card fraud is listed on the agenda.

Title: GST evasion of Rs 1 cr by steel firm detected, claims U’khand tax dept
Content: Dehradun: The state commercial tax department has detected an almost Rs one crore tax violation in the payment of goods and services tax ( GST ) by a firm based at Kotdwar in Pauri Garhwal.According to officials of the department, the firm in question had not submitted any GST return details in this financial year which brought it under the scanner. “On Saturday evening, our officials surveyed the premises of the firm and found that there were several discrepancies in its accounts,” said a senior joint commissioner-level official.“The firm is into manufacturing of steel and has an annual turnover of over Rs 10 crore. During investigation, it was found that for the purpose of saving tax, the firm had floated some dummy companies which were shown to be conducting business. When our officials confronted the firm owner with the relevant documents, he paid up Rs 40 lakh. Our investigation is currently going on about the firm’s total GST evasion in the current financial year,” said the official while speaking to TOI.He added that in Uttarakhand, over 20,000 firms are found to be not complying with the GST rules. “Strict action is being planned against these firms,” the official said.

Title: Proud of women officers courage: Digvijaya on Rajgarh incident
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bhopal: State Congress on Monday reacted strongly to the alleged misbehaviour of BJP workers with women collector and deputy collector of Rajgarh district. In an early morning tweet, senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh said, “Rowdy behaviour of BJP has been revealed in Rajgarh in Madhya Pradesh. Woman district collector and woman were beaten, pulled by the hair. We are proud of the courage of women officers.”

Minister for law PC Sharma claimed that misbehavior with women is part of the BJP-RSS culture. “Section 144 was imposed in Rajgarh. If they had to do a protest, then a permission should have been taken. This woman collector and deputy collector had been working in the same capacity during BJP tenure also. No such incident took place then,” he argued. “BJP demonstrators took law into their hands. They pulled the deputy collector by her hair and kicked her on the waist. This kind of misbehaviour is culture of the BJP-RSS. Such behaviour with women is unfortunate and condemnable.”

Title: Mentally-ill man runs away with police car, caught after hot chase
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The city police were on Sunday night hot on the trail of one of their own vehicles after a man, thought to be mentally unstable, got into the car parked with its key still on the ignition switch and zipped past the city’s streets.

The police were able to corner the patrol car belonging to Nakkapalli circle police station only after a high-speed chase that lasted a little over 2 km. Luckily, no one was injured despite the ‘unstable’ man’s rash driving.

Nakkapalli police personnel TOI spoke to said the incident took place around 12.10 am along the highway when they were discussing measures to control the farmers’ agitation in Amaravati and the preventive arrest of TDP leaders who were accused of ‘instigating the ryots’. An inquiry revealed the man in question was mentally ill and wasn’t acting with any political motive. A memo has been issued to the driver of the patrol vehicle for negligence and dereliction of duty.

“We came to know the accused is mentally challenged. Our driver’s negligence caused the confusion. We have issued a memo to him. All we can say is we are fortunate the incident took place late in the night. Had it happened in the morning or evening, the situation would have been completely different,” an senior police official said, adding it was a miracle no one suffered injuries.

Title: Digital taxi meters: Govt to issue new fare chart in 15 days
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: The state government will issue a fare chart for taxis within 15 days, which will pave the way for digital meters to be installed in taxis.

In the contempt petition filed by the travel and tourism association of Goa (TTAG) over non implementation of taxi meters, advocate general Devidas Pangam told the high court that the government will notify the revised fare rates within fifteen days, after which installation of digital meters in taxis can begin. The revised fare rates have already been vetted by the law department and submitted to the government for approval.

Senior counsel Nitin Sardesai representing TTAG asked for a date by which the meters would be installed.

Counsel Suren Uppal representing Rosmerta Autotech Pvt Ltd, to whom the work order has been awarded, informed the high court that the company was ready to install the meters within a week’s time following the government’s notification of the revised fare chart.

Pangam stated that the implementation of meters in taxis on pilot basis began on November 26, and has been successful.

The pilot installation and operation of the meters, as well as the pilot running of the central tracking response system (CTRS) has been completed, the government submitted to the HC. The transport department had also sent a letter to the director general of police on January 3 for the integration of the CTRS with the state emergency response system.

TTAG filed a contempt petition after the transport department failed to comply with the court’s July 5 order of fitting taxis with meters.

The government in November tendered an apology to the HC over delay in implementation of the digital meters, and the transport department was asked to explain its failure to do so after a show cause notice was issued by the high court.

Title: GTDC resort ops to be outsourced
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji:The Goa tourism development corporation’s loss-making Calangute Annexe, a hotel with 30 rooms, spread over an area of 1,214sqm, will be renovated through a private player.

Targeted at middle-class travelers, the Calangute Annexe, despite enjoying a prime location, has not made a profit over the past five years.

A member of the board said there have been complaints about the property, and it needs to be renovated.

“The board has opted to have a private investor redo the property and operate it, but no structural changes will be permitted,” he said.

He added that the board was informed that the trend in revenues and profit margins of the facility has not changed much in five years, nor has the average room rent been modified.

“The rent has been kept on the lower side due to stiff competition from better placed hotels in the area,” he said. The no-frills resort charges Rs 2,100 to 3,000 for a standard room during peak season, and Rs 2,500 to 3,600 for an airconditioned room. Room tariff is lowed during the monsoon.

Title: Kolkata: Hand-cycle Bagan fan back home after Derby-day crash
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Rintu Das watches a match from the sidelines; at his home with his son

KOLKATA: An ardent Mohun Bagan fan and a double amputee missed a Derby in Kolkata for the first time in 19 years after a car hit his hand-cycle when he was on his way to the Salt Lake stadium on Sunday.

Ballygunge resident Rintu Das (29), a familiar face among Mohun Bagan fans and officials, said he was distraught after missing the game, which dented his enviable record. “Never have I missed a Derby in Kolkata since the age of 10. Even after I lost both my legs in a train accident in 2012, I went to the stadium on a wheelchair with a group of friends and cheered for my team. I was also geared up to root for my team from the side line on Sunday but then the accident happened. When I woke up at the hospital on Sunday night, I rued at missing out the live action but was happy that my team had won,” said Das, who lives in the Peyarabagan slum with his wife and six-year-old son.

On Sunday, Das was on his way to the stadium on his hand-cycle fluttering flags of Mohun Bagan and India. Just as he reached the stadium, he was hit by a car from behind and was flung off his hand-cycle. “It was a red car that dashed me from behind and sped away. I couldn’t notice the registration number of the car,” Das told TOI on Monday.

As he fell off the tricycle, Mohun Bagan fans picked him up and rushed towards the other side of the road where cops brought a police ambulance shifted him to NRS Hospital. Doctors said he had suffered sprain injuries on his neck, spine, shoulder and trauma on his head. However, there were no fractures.

“He has always been crazy about Mohun Bagan. Even after the accident, the first thing he asked after regaining consciousness was the score for Sunday’s match,” said Namita, his wife. Das was released from the hospital on Monday.

A passionate footballer himself, Das used play as a goalkeeper for a local club – Bhai Bhai Sangha – till he met with the accident in 2012. “We had won a tournament beating a Kalighat club in the final match before I went for a vacation with my wife to Delhi. But on March 2, during the train journey, I fell off the train near Ghaziabad and my legs came under the train wheels. I was bedridden for three months. But then, I was up again on a hand-cycle and was back to the ground.

Football fans were livid on Facebook after news of his accident went viral. “I have been receiving a lot of phone calls from anxious fans and this is what keeps me going. I love my team and would continue to support it even if they merge with ATK or any other team. My love for the team will remain intact,” said Das.

Title: In Prakash Naik suicide case, minister’s brother claims innocence
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Stating that he had no business dealings with Naik, Wilson, in his application, said that they were only conne... Read More

PANAJI: Goa police on Monday opposed the anticipatory bail application filed by panchayats minister Mauvin Godinho ’s brother, Wilson, before the sessions court apprehending arrest in former Merces sarpanch Prakash Naik’s death case.

Old Goa police filed their reply in the case and argument will be heard on Tuesday. Police on Sunday filed an FIR against Wilson for abetment of suicide in the case.

Wilson in his application said that he is “innocent” and that the allegations made by Naik in a WhatApp message that has since gone viral, are “patently false”.

Naik, who was a sitting Merces panch member, allegedly shot himself minutes after posting the message on a 200-member strong group. The message stated that he was “under tremendous pressure” from two persons over a property matter, which he could not handle.

In his application Wilson stated that “Naik has falsely alleged” that he had been harassing Naik.

“There is absolute no business dealings between me and Naik,” Wilson’s application stated. The only connection between them is a panchayat case, the application further stated.

Stating that political parties are calling for his arrest saying he is the panchayat minister’s brother, Wilson’s in his application said these political parties were seeking to take political mileage of unfortunate suicide. He also stated that he is not involved in any criminal offence as alleged in the FIR.

The applicant said he has strong reasons to believe that on account of the political pressure and influence exerted, some malicious plans and designs had been worked out with the intention of implicating him with cognisable and non-bailable offences.

During the hearing on Monday, Wilson’s counsel Rohit Bras de Sa said that they had not been provided with a copy of the FIR.

“I sympathise with Naik’s family. I am for a fair investigation, which should reach its logical conclusion,” Wilson told reporters outside the court.

Naik had contested assembly elections in 2017 on the ticket of the state’s oldest regional party, MGP.

On Monday, the Naik family took possession of the the body and performed the final rites. Earlier they had refused to accept the body till the two persons named in the message were arrested.

They also demanded that the case be moved from the Old Goa police to crime branch.

Title: Kolkata: Museum idol replica found in Salt Lake
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The figurine that was recovered from a Salt Lake temple

KOLKATA: The sudden recovery of an 18th century terracotta idol with a metal stamp by Bidhannagar North police from a temple in Salt Lake ’s BC Block created a stir on Monday. The idol titled ‘Ladies playing tambourine’ is a replica of the one in Indian Museum’s collection. However, the museum officials confirmed that the figurine was a replica, not the original one.

A month ago, Pankaj Biswas, a rickshawpuller found the figurine, measuring 1.5 feet × 8 inches, lying on a roadside. Without understanding its real value, Biswas collected it and decided to put it in a local temple. People started worshipping the figurine as well.

A local was surprised by reading the metal stamp on it. Understanding its significance, he informedBidhannagar North police and requested them to recover the figurine as it could be a treasure of the nation.

Title: 11 booked in gambling, articles worth Rs 6.33 lakh seized
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The city police busted a gambling den and booked 11 people with cash and articles worth Rs 6.33 lakh from Indiranagar the area on Saturday.

The police have also set up a special squad at the police commissionerate level to take action on the complaints received at the CP office. On Saturday, information reached the police commissionerate about a gambling den being in operation in the Indiranagar area.

The informer told the police that the gambling den was operating in a closed house in the Pandav Leni area and the people inside were gambling on cards.

Taking serious note of the complaint, the police raided the aforesaid place and booked the suspects. The police said that most of the people playing on cards were from the Ambad and Cidco area. One person was from Panchavati and one more was from Nandgaon area. Apart from the cash of Rs 26,000 seized from the spot, the police recovered other articles including 12 cellphones, a car, and four motorcycles all worth Rs 6.33 lakh.

The police said that more and more people are coming forward to inform about the illegal activities in their respective areas. The police said that the response from the informers is vital as their name is not disclosed to anyone.

Many people hesitate to bring such activities to the notice of their respective police stations, following which the senior police officials have to take such complaints at the police commissionerate level.

Those who want to give any such information can contact the police control room at 0253 – 2305233 and 2305234.

Title: NID students get lesson on compassion in elective course
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: When city-based designer Lokesh Ghai started working with 14 students from across the campuses of the National Institute of Design ( NID ) for a two-week open elective course, he was clear about the outcome. “I wanted the students to experience the compassion of society to inspire them. I took them to less-known individual and NGO-driven initiatives, where they listened and captured the experience in words and sketches,” he said.

The result is the ‘Wrapped in Compassion’ booklet, featuring 14 such intitiatives from Ahmedabad and covers areas ranging from women’s empowerment to the environment and education to charity. The course was taken by students of disciplines such as film and video communication, retail design, furniture design, automobile design and so on.

In search of missing children

The ‘Search my Child’ movement may have started with a missing girl in 2012 but Sanjay Joshi, a social worker, soon realized that his was not a solitary case. Joshi’s profile mentions how the movement snowballed into a phenomenon where the FIRs for missing children started getting registered under the section of the IPC dealing with kidnapping.

The courage to bounce back in Vatva

The profile of ‘Himmat’, a collective of 16 widows from Naroda Patiya who were relocated to Vatva, talks about courage and the strength to bounce back. Nazima, one of the widows profiled, says that that the confidence and skill she gained motivates her to help others. The women, now experts with sewing machines, earn their livelihood as a result of the project.

A hero rises

Aarti, a student at Vicharta Samuday Samarthan Manch girls hostel in the city, says in her profile that there are more medals at her home than utensils. A Class IX student, who is daughter of a couple who are manual labourers, she aspires to study medicine. She is one of the girls from de-notified tribes pursuing formal education under the initiative.

Title: Class VIII students to visit peers in other campuses
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Coimbatore: A total of 5,160 Class VIII students studying in government middle, high and higher secondary schools and some private schools, will visit their peers’ campuses as part of the Partnership Between Schools Programme (PBSP). The programme will be held in two phases, one each on Tuesday and Friday.

Officials of Samagra Shiksha said in the one-day visit, students from rural schools would go to those in urban areas and vice versa. This would help them to see, understand, get sensitised and appreciate each other’s ambience and lifestyle along with their academic practices, officials said.

While this was being done only in government schools for the past two years, this year five matriculation schools have also been included in the programme. A total of 20 students from each of the 258 schools would participate in the programme. tnn

Title: Trichy: Gang kills man to avenge family member’s murder
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

TRICHY: A 28-year-old man was killed to avenge the murder of an 80-year-old man. The incident took place at Thiruengoimalai on the outskirts of Trichy on Sunday.

S Suresh from Valairamani near Thathaingarpettai in Musiri was hacked to death by a four-member gang at Saliyar Street in Thiruengoimalai on Sunday afternoon. The accused have been identified as M Dhanushkodi , R Sathishwaran alias Sathish, M Tamilselvan and R Manjunathan alias Manju of Thiruengoimalai, police said. The incident took place when Suresh and his wife Sangeetha, 20, were on the way to meet their advocate on their two-wheeler. Police said that Tamilselvan intercepted them and picked up quarrel with them. Three others also joined him and began to attack Suresh with machetes. Suresh sustained severe injuries all over his body. As Sangeetha screamed for help from onlookers, the gang threatened her with dire consequences and fled the scene. On getting the information, the Thottiyam police rushed to the spot and recovered the body.

Police said that Suresh married Sangeetha, who was from the same community in February, 2017 but their marriage irked her family members. As a consequence of the dispute, Suresh murdered Ammiyappan, Sangeetha’s grandfather in May 2019 for which Suresh was arrested. After coming out on bail, he shifted his family to Valasiramani and was living there. Police said the accused were Sangeetha’s family members and murdered Suresh to avenge Ammiyappan’s killing.

Title: Budget basics: Focus on power, water, say Goa’s industrialists
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: The Union Budget, which is around the corner, is expected to outline steps to stimulate economic growth but expectations from the state budget are much lower. While Goa’s industrial sector is also counting on a turnaround, the captains of Goa’s private sector want the state government to focus on the basics -power, water, public transport and less red-tape.

The government might not admit it, but all the major sectors that contribute to the state’s tax kitty have witnessed a slump, say trade bodies.

Goa State Industries Association has submitted a budget wish list to the state government, highlighting steps to revive Goa’s mining, manufacturing and tourism sector.

“What is below the soil is the property of the government and we, the people living in the state, are stakeholders of the same. The government has to take over all mines under a corporation and tender mining activity and ore-selling activity separately,” said president of GSIA, Damodar Kochkar.

Kochkar has also listed eight steps, which the government can take to boost the manufacturing units. These include digitisation of all government departments through an online platform and reforms in industrial laws to make them business-friendly.

Basic issues such as consistent power supply, cheap availability of raw water, public transport, improvement of health services and cleanliness also need the state government’s attention, said Kochkar.

Verna Industries Association president Blaise Costabir also stresses that the basics need to be put in place. “A raw water supply network, akin to the one in Verna, needs to be expanded to different industrial estates and raw water rates need to be stabilised . For industry, incentivise water treatment plants, which in turn will help reduce the demand for water,” said Costabir. Both Costabir and Kochkar hope that chief minister Pramod Sawant will announce a reduction in raw water supply rates as promised by former chief minister Manohar Parrikar.

Speaking about power supply, Costabir recommends that the state needs to aggressively promote solar energy. “We want new industries, we want more jobs, but we don’t have electricity. We already have the policy in place for solar or renewable energy, but we have not moved aggressively on this. The government needs to encourage solar power generation,” he said.

The real estate sector is also reeling under poor demand. Credai – Goa, which is likely to give its budget recommendations in the next few days, is looking at a reduction in the infrastructure tax levied on all real estate projects.

Title: AFS Thanjavur gets first squadron of BrahMos-embedded Su-30MKI
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Thanjavur: Chief of Defence Staff General Bipin Rawat on Monday dedicated the newly-resurrected 222 Squadron, the Tigersharks, with BrahMos-embedded Sukhoi-30MKIs to the nation at a function held at the Air Force Station (AFS) in Thanjavur.

With the Sukhoi-30 MKI squadron now getting positioned at AFS in Thanjavur along with BrahMos Air Launched Cruise Missile (ALCM), the Indian Air Force (IAF) will get more air power to strike at any target at sea and on land with pinpoint accuracy during day and night and in all weather conditions, officials said.

The IAF test-fired the BrahMos ALCM from a Sukhoi-30MKI on May 22, 2019. It was the successful second test-firing of the BrahMos ALCM from a Su-30MKI, where the missile achieved a direct hit on the target, thus proving its high accuracy hit rate, officials added.

Addressing a gathering of a Sukhoi-30 fighter squadron, General Rawat said, “Su-30 MKI along with the BrahMos will be a gamechanger which will extensively enhance the security of the maritime domain. The Squadron will operate closely with the Indian Army and Navy to get the ball rolling in jointness of the Indian Armed Forces.”

Chief of Air Staff R K S Bhaduria said the mission was a huge achievement as the entire modification with Sukhoi-30MKI had been done indigenously with no historical background.

“Be it in terms of air defence of this southern peninsula, especially in view of some critical national assets in this area of responsibility, be it in the maritime road in support of Navy, or be it in any other offensive or defensive role, this aircraft is capable of any mission assigned by the Air Force,” he said.

Vice Admiral Atul Kumar Jain, Air Marshal Amit Tiwari, chairman, DRDO, Dr G Satheesh Reddy and chairman-cum-managing director, Hindustan Aeronautics Limited, R Madhavan, participated.

Title: Students watch PM Narendra Modi’s ‘Pariksha Pe Charcha’ live
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

COIMBATORE: Higher secondary students from around 150 government schools in the district on Monday saw Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s speech at the ‘Pariksha Pe Charcha 2020’ programme held in New Delhi, live. However, not all would have understood what he said. While at some government schools, teachers who knew Hindi acted as interpreters and paraphrased PM’s speech to students, other schools did not have such a facility.

School education officials said the PM’s speech was played alive in around 150 government high and higher secondary schools, which had ‘hi-tech’ classrooms, in the district.

When TOI visited the CCMA Government Girls Higher Secondary School on Raja Street in the city, more than 50 students were watching the PM’s speech on how to beat examination stress. A teacher was simultaneously translating his speech into Tamil. “He now says marks are not the goal in life. Life is more than just marks, he says,” she was saying to students.

In Ashokapuram Government Higher Secondary School too, an interpreter translated the PM’s speech to students, in a rather simplistic way.

However, in several other government schools in the district, there were no such arrangements, as not all government schools had teachers familiar with Hindi.

A government school teacher said in government schools outside the city, there were none to interpret Modi’s speech, and students had to just sit and watch the visual.

When asked about this, Coimbatore chief education officer P Ayyannan agreed that not all schools in the districts had such an arrangement. “Not all government schools would have teachers who know Hindi. Wherever possible, we have arranged for them to interpret,” he said. “However, we plan to translate Prime Minister’s speech and read it out in school assembly meetings in two days,” he added.

Title: Nashik police told to stop use of home guards' service
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The city police have withdrawn the services of 370 home guards following instructions from the police department headquarters in Mumbai.

In October last year, 370 out of 400 home guards had joined the police force. The home guards assisted the police force in bandobast, in police chowky level work, police station level, court bandobast, Kaidee Party, for vehicular traffic regulation etc.

DCP (HQ and Traffic) Pournima Chaugule said, “The services of the home guards were discontinued a couple of days back after instructions from our higher offices. Nonetheless, we would be able to use the home guards, for important events and occasions like election, Ganapati, Navaratra, etc.”

Meanwhile, a senior police officer of the city police said that there is approximately 3,000 police personnel with the city police, which work in shifts. For a city with a population of close to 19 lakh and the floating population, the force available with the police is very less. “The home guards were of great help at the newly formed police chowkies. Fifty-four new police chowkies came up under the jurisdictions of the 13 police stations. Thus in the absence of the police personnel of the concerned police station, the home guards manned the chowkies and also entertained the complainants till the arrival of the concerned officer,” said an officer.

Further, the home guards were also useful in managing vehicular traffic. Senior officials said that the decision of discontinuing the services of the home guards was mainly related to the remuneration they had to be paid for their services.

The city expansion is happening fast with newer areas coming in all the direction. “In a bid to maintain law and order, preventing crimes from taking place and detecting them after they have occurred, the available force is too small.”

Meanwhile, in view of the growth of the city, there are proposals to set up new police stations and also include a few police stations with the rural police. On the backdrop of all such things, the police would be needing additional forces.

Title: Kamal Nath to hold one on one with top biz honchos in Davos
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bhopal: Exploring investment possibilities for Madhya Pradesh and showcasing the benefits of doing business in Madhya Pradesh at the world stage in Davos, chief minister Kamal Nath will hold meetings with top business honchos at the World Economic Forum (WEF) scheduled to begin from Tuesday.

Nath will meet top industrialists from the field of FMCG, healthcare, pharmaceuticals, automobiles and information technology.

More than 3,000 business leaders, industrialists and politicians are expected to participate in in the 4-day summit.

The chief minister will hold one-on-one with more than 15 top industrialists during the summit at the popular ski resort situated in Swiss Alps.

In a luncheon session at the WEF on January 22, the chief minister will hold meeting with the 75 international industrialists. This include CEO and president of Hewlett Packard Antonio Neri, CEO of Danish pharma major Novo Nordisk, Lars Fruergaard Jørgensen, chairman of the Proctor and Gamble Asia pacific and Africa Mangesvaran Surjanan , managing director of Mahindraand Mahindra Pawan Kumar Goenka , chairman and managing director of Dubai based VPS Healthcare Dr Shamshir Vayalil and CEO and managing director of Wipro Abidali Neemuchwala.

Prior to Nath’s meeting with the CEOs, bureaucrats from Madhya Pradesh headed by the chief secretary SR Mohanty will apprise the representatives of 30 business houses with the industrial reforms initiated in Madhya Pradesh. In the last one year, Kamal Nath government had taken many steps to woo investors which include electric vehicle policy, a new policy for heritage hotels and concessions for promotion of MSMEs. The state has also come up with a new real estate policy. More than 10 amendments have been effected in the last one year to attract investment, a government spokesman said.

This will lead to generation of employment in state, a government spokesman said.

Title: Homage to Bapu: Weaving legacies
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Ahmedabad: The collection of 30 saris, woven in the Srikakulam jamdani style, displayed at the KL Museum at Shahibaug, has the warp and weft of history. The khadi saris, a homage to Mahatma Gandhi in his 150th birth centenary year, depicted some of the most loved paintings of Raja Ravi Varma. The three-year project, titled ‘Santati’, involved 20 families of weavers from Srikakulam, six dyers from Ajrakhpur, and six members of textile designer Gaurang Shah’s team.

The exhibition, open from January 21 to 26 from 10am to 5pm at the museum, highlights the hard work the weavers undertook to weave hues and expressions in the iconic oleographs and lithographs.

Title: Kolkata Municipal Corporation property tax form made easier
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Kolkata Municipal Corporation

KOLKATA: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) assessment department has made changes in the application form for existing property tax-payers to enable them switch over to the Unit Area Assessment (UAA) method.

Explaining the reason behind the move, mayor Firhad Hakim on Monday said it was necessary to make the form simple as majority of tax-payers were getting baffled by the unnecessary complications that existed in the old form. “Our officials were getting negative feedback about the form because of its length and unexplained complications. Now, we have done away with irrelevant matters and made the form citizen-friendly,” Hakim said.

Deputy mayor Atin Ghosh held a meeting with senior KMC assessment department officials during the day and asked them to arrange for help desks in borough offices to make tax-payers aware about the change in the application form. “We were committed to make changes in the UAA application form so that tax-payers don’t find it complex and refrain from switching over to the new tax regime,” Ghosh said.

According to a KMC assessment department official, the new form has been made slimmer by cutting down unnecessary instructions that were given to tax-payers in the older version. “This apart, we have deleted large portions of information from the previous UAA form which were not relevant for tax-payers. Cluttering of information proved to be detrimental for the tax-payers’ understanding of the new system,” said a KMC official in the assessment department. A KMC revenue department official said the new form would be a two-page document that will be self-explanatory and easy to understand.

Title: Stones hurled at East Bengal bus, two supporters injured
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Biswanath Chakraborty, who was injured on Sunday

KOLKATA: Two East Bengal fans were injured — one of them seriously — when a brick hit their bus while they were returning home after watching Sunday’s Derby. The brick was hurled at the bus near Apollo Hospital almost immediatetly after the supporters from Andul had boarded it. While one of them — Biswanath Chakraborty — has received seven stitches, the other person, Bijan Bhattacharjee , escaped with minor injuries.

“We, a group of 45 East Bengal supporters, had hired a bus to go to the stadium. When we were returning home, our bus had taken a U-turn and moved towards Kadapara when some men standing under the Metro station and claiming allegiance to a fan club started abusing us. First it was against our club, and then it became personal. One of our supporters tried to reply when stones started raining on us. A brick hit the back of the head of Chakraborty, who was sitting near the gate,” claimed Bhattacharjee.

At Apollo Hospital, club members and supporters, who had lined up for the treatment of footballer Edmund Lalrindika, pooled money for the initial treatment of Chakraborty. Several Mohun Bagan supporters turned up at the hospital from Andul to express their solidarity with the victims.

Phoolbagan police said a case of hurt had been registered. “Some unknown persons voluntarily assaulted the complainant’s friend — Biswanath Chakraborty — by throwing a brick when the complainant along with others were on their way to their residence in a bus,” said an investigating officer.

Title: AAP meets Sattari ryots, hears their grievances
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Valpoi: In light of the recent death toll of tigers in the foothills of Golauli village in Sattari forest, a delegation from Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) on Saturday met various farmers groups in the villages of Sattari. The meet aimed at ‘understanding the man-animal conflict’ that has remained unresolved in the area.

Present at the meet were AAP’s Elvis Gomes, Pradeep Padgaonkar, Sunil Signapurkar, Uday Barve and Mario Cordeiro.

AAP’s Vishwesh Prabhu told TOI that the delegation also visited the family members of the Dangar community who had been arrested in connection with the tiger deaths, and listened to their grievances.

Prabhu said one major issue the farmers were facing was that of crop loss due to inadequate attention from the government.

Title: Five die in separate hit-&-run cases
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nashik: At least five people were killed in separate hit-and-run incidents across the district between Friday and Sunday.

A 60-year-old person died in a road accident in the Ambad area on Friday around 11am. The deceased, identified as Arjun Sukhdev Bachchav, a resident of Satpur Colony, was riding his motorcycle on the road from the Power House to Xlo Point in Ambad MIDC area when he was knocked down by an unidentified biker. Bachchav succumbed to serious head injuries. Ambad police have registered a case of death caused by negligence against the unidentified biker.

At around 9pm on Friday, a 40-year-old woman was killed when she was hit by a speeding biker along the Abhona-Kalwan road in rural Nashik. Kalpana Gaikwad was on foot when the two-wheeler hit her. Abhona police have booked a case against the unidentified biker.

In another hit-and-run case, a speeding SUV knocked down Sanjay Revgade, a resident of Padali in Sinnar taluka. He riding his bike near the Gulwanch Phata. The accident occurred around 3pm on Friday. Revgade, 40, died of serious head injuries. Cops are still searching for the driver of the speeding SUV.

On Saturday, a 20-year-old man was killed in an accident at Pimpalgaon in Niphad taluka. Around 9pm, Dharmendra Kumar Madhura Prasad Patel, a native of Madhya Pradesh, was seated on the road near a truck when he was hit by a speeding lorry. An investigation is currently on.

On Sunday, a 41-year-old man, who was part of a group of pilgrims in Trimbakeshwar, was knocked down by a car sometime around noon. The victim, Dileep Devji Sambre, was a resident of Palghar. The driver of the car managed to flee the scene.

Title: Parking woes: GMC to issue passes to doctors
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Taxis, private vehicles and hearses occupy most of the parking area

PANAJI: Facing a major parking space crunch, Goa Medical College (GMC) and hospital, Bambolim will shortly start issuing its doctors passes to enable them to park their vehicles without difficulty within hospital premises. Besides, zones will be earmarked for the purpose.

Dean Dr S M Bandekar told TOI that “they have proposed to have passes issued to doctors that will enable them to park their vehicles in a designated zone.”

In a meeting held last week which was attended by heads of the departments, the parking issue was discussed, with doctors insisting that a solution be found at the earliest. Though the state’s biggest hospital has space earmarked for vehicles owned by its staff, it is inadequate— especially in view of GMC’s expansion this year.

The problem, a senior doctor said, is exacerbated further as many private vehicles – vehicles for hire, private ambulances and hearse vans – are parked in the GMC premises, leaving little to no space for doctors and other staff to park their vehicles.

“Nowhere else are private ambulances and vehicles on hire allowed to park within hospital premises. They take up most of the parking space. When we reach the hospital in the morning, we have to waste at least 10-15 minutes of our valuable time looking for parking,” said a senior doctor. Besides, visitors to the hospital also bring their vehicles. Once slots reserved for public vehicles are filled, motorists go looking for parking elsewhere within the hospital campus. Students’ vehicles – four wheelers – also take a lot of space. Bandekar said students will be asked to park their vehicles at the hostel.

Earlier, many people travelling from Panaji to Vasco or Margao for work, used to park their four-wheelers inside the GMC compound and take a south-bound bus from Bambolim. In the evening, they would return and pick up their vehicle to travel home. While this has reduced to a large extent, a GMC doctor said, more wings have been added to the hospital, and there has not been proportionate expansion in parking space. “Now, you see even vehicles parked outside GMC since there is no space inside. Plus, there are vegetable and fruit vendors adding to the chaos,” said a GMC staffer.

Title: Delhi elections: Prashant Kishor not in JD(U) campaigners’ list
Content:
Prashant Kishor

NEW DELHI: Janata Dal (United), which was given two seats by BJP under a pre-poll pact, on Monday released its list of 20 star-campaigners, including Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar . The list, however, does not mention the names of party national general secretary Pavan K Verma and vice-president Prashant Kishor , who has been opposing the Citizenship Amendment Act, National Population Register and NRC. Kishor is also working for AAP through I-PAC for Delhi assembly election.Both Kishor and Verma were JD(U)’s star campaigners in the recently concluded Jharkhand assembly election.The list included the names of party general secretary and Rajya Sabha member K C Tyagi, besides Rajya Sabha member RCP Singh, Bashistha Narain Singh and Ramnath Thakur. JD(U) Delhi in charge Sanjay Kumar Jha said the party would field candidates in Burari and Sangam Vihar constituencies that have a sizeable Poorvanchali population. Former MLA SCL Gupta, who is likely to be fielded from Sangam Vihar, joined JD(U) on Monday.

Title: GST rules hard on us, say micro, small industrialists
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Micro and small industrialists from the district say the current GST rules were hard on them. The practice of blocking the facility to generate e-way bill on the instance of not filing GST returns for two months, they say, has put them in a tight spot.

They say amid reduced orders and payments not coming in in time, they were not able to pay GST returns on time and such stringent measures has been causing even more hardships.

Micro and small jobwork industrialists and cottage industrialists say they need e-way bill for transporting material worth more than Rs1lakh. If they don’t have an e-way bill, they would be heavily penalised.

J James, district president Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Micro Enterprises’ (TACT), said on one side, their orders have reduced, and firms were giving them payment for their work only after 180 days, which has made it hard for them to file GST returns on time. “Now, with our e-way bill generation facilities being blocked for not filing GST returns on time, the situation has become worse,” he said.

James said of the micro jobwork and spare parts industries at Edayarpalayam and surrounding areas, the e-way bill generation facility of around 15 to 20 micro firms have been blocked due to non-filing of returns for two months. “We suspect the number to be around 100 across the district,” he said.

Members of the Coimbatore Tirupur District Micro and Cottage Entrepreneurs Association (Cotma) had recently submitted a petition regarding this to the principal GST commissioner in the city.

President of Cotma C Sivakumar said both public sector undertakings and private firms have been delaying payments of late. “Even the firms which had earlier been paying us within 45 days are now delaying it up to 180 days citing economic slowdown,” he said. The rule that non-filing of returns for six months would lead to the blocking of GST account has also put them in a tough spot, he said.

James said while such drastic measures would help in seeing better GST returns by the government, it would eventually affect the micro and small industry ecosystem. Sivakumar said they were expecting something positive in the upcoming budget.

When contacted, a GST official in the district said the process of blocking e-way bill generation was automated. “It was brought last year to penalise defaulters. But if they file the pending returns, it would be released immediately,” the official said. While acknowledging the issue faced by micro and small industries, the official said they should represent it to the Central GST commission as it was a policy matter.
