This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

Title: Organ transplant performed in Salem government hospital
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

SALEM: The organs of a 58-year-old brain dead man were successfully harvested at the government hospital in the city on Monday.

The authorities of Government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College Hospital said that this was the first time a multiple organ harvest and transplant was performed at the hospital.

The authorities said Sivalingam, of Nallipalayam in Namakkal district , met with an accident on January 15 and was referred from the Namakkal government hospital to Salem as his condition deteriorated. However, even as treatment was underway at Salem GH, he suffered brain death around 1am on Monday.

In a noble gesture, his son Ramalingam agreed to donate the organs of his brain-dead father.

Subsequently, his heart was harvested and sent to a Chennai hospital and successfully transplanted on a patient while one kidney was donated to a patient in a private hospital in Coimbatore and the other kidney to a patient in Salem GH.

“A team of 21 health staff led by transplant surgeon Periyasamy performed the exercise soon after the donor’s son gave the consent. This is the first time that a transplant surgery was performed in Salem GH,” said the hospital dean R Balaji Nathan.

Title: Madras high court dismisses advance bail plea of teacher
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

Title: HC seeks TN’s reply on plea by VAOs
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madurai: The state government has been directed to file a response to an appeal filed by seven village administrative officers (VAO) challenging an order by a single judge who directed the district collectors to constitute a special grievance cell to inquire and take action on complaints from the public regarding VAOs not residing in their jurisdictional village.

In the appeal petition, the seven VAOs stated that a petition was filed before the Madras high court Madurai bench seeking for a direction for the VAO of Melaiyur village in Thanjavur district. They stated that the judge in his order on July 1, 2019, expanded the scope of the petition which touches upon the entire state and passed a series of direction which includes the constitution of special grievance cells in all districts. They stated that VAOs were entrusted with a plethora of duties which includes preparation and maintenance of village revenue and land records, collection of various taxes issuance of certificates and other important functions. The VAOs have also dedicated a major portion of their efforts and energy towards the upkeep and well-being of their respective villages.

They said that they are often left struggling to find any decent accommodation in the village where they are posted. Sometimes the area of posting maybe an isolated village with no road connectivity, lack of infrastructure facilities. They further said that women VAOs face difficulties without proper accommodation and even office without toilet facilities.

The petitioners said they are present in the office during working hours and only leave during the night hours. In the present day advancements in technology, the continuous presence of the VAOs in the village becomes obsolete.

They stated that the order was passed without even providing an opportunity to hear the VAOs or their associations. Hence, they filed an appeal before the high court Madurai bench. When the appeal was taken up for hearing on Monday, sought response from the state government and adjourned the case to February 7 for further hearing.

Title: Now, MGP wants Mauvin to quit over ex-sarpanch death
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: MGP on Monday demanded that panchayats minister Mauvin Godinho resign from the cabinet to pave way for a free and fair investigation in former Merces sarpanch Prakash Naik’s alleged suicide case. Godinho’s brother Wilson has been booked for abetment of suicide in the case.

MGP’s Ramkrishna Dhavalikar said they support Congress’ demand for Godinho’s resignation in the matter for the same reason.

Dhavalikar said that even though Naik’s death has been called suicide, he suspected foul play. “This is not suicide, it is murder, because he has named two persons, including the brother of the minister,” he said.

“Till date they have not been arrested and we want to know the reason for not arresting them,” the former deputy chief minister said.

Stating that chief minister Pramod Sawant should take note of this incident, Dhavalikar said that since 2002 Goa has seen land mafia. “According to my information, from 2002, till date, the land mafia has purchased lot of land in the state, which does not have proper access, and that is the reason they are going to any extent.”

Minutes before he died, Naik had sent out a message on a WhatsApp group announcing his intention to take the drastic step. Referring to the message, Dhavalikar said there was need to investigate as to whether it was Naik who posted the message, or somebody else.

Dhavalikar said there should be an inquiry into Naik leaving MGP, and the two MGP and 10 Congress MLAs who quit their respective parties to join BJP. “They left the parties only because they were not able to carry out development or they were promised that their land would be converted,” he said.

Naik had contested the 2017 assembly elections on the MGP ticket from Santa Cruz constituency, but later quit the party.

The CM should conduct an inquiry into those who have applied for land conversion and at what stage the process has reached and then act against those people or else more murders will take place in Goa and the government will be blamed, he said.

Title: Cattle feed price hike: No respite for dairy farmers
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Ponda: Dairy farmers in the state are considering intensifying their agitation over the hike in prices of cattle feed, after Goa Dairy administrators refused to budge on their demand for a rollback of the hike. Goa Dairy administrator Arvind Khuntkar on Monday said that the milk co-operative has sought government grants to reimburse the losses faced by its cattle feed plant at Mharvasaddo-Usgao in Ponda. Goa Dairy had raised the rates of cattle feed by Rs 4 per kg from Thursday.

The agitating farmers have demanded a similar hike— of Rs 3 per litre— in milk procurement rates.

The farmers have been staging a sit-in outside the dairy since Friday, with heavy police presence.

The co-operative blamed their losses on the increase in prices of some ingredients used to prepare the cattle feed, as they have been brought under the ambit of Goods and Services Tax (GST). It added that its feed was much cheaper than the feed provided by other milk unions.

While the Goa Dairy's high-protein cattle feed would now cost Rs 23.3, high-energy feed will cost Rs 23.8 a kg. The animal pregnancy ration will now cost Rs 21.5 and calf ration, Rs 25.5 per kg.

Title: Delhi elections: Prashant Kishor not in JD(U) campaigners’ list
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Prashant Kishor

NEW DELHI: Janata Dal (United), which was given two seats by BJP under a pre-poll pact, on Monday released its list of 20 star-campaigners, including Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar . The list, however, does not mention the names of party national general secretary Pavan K Verma and vice-president Prashant Kishor , who has been opposing the Citizenship Amendment Act, National Population Register and NRC. Kishor is also working for AAP through I-PAC for Delhi assembly election.

Both Kishor and Verma were JD(U)’s star campaigners in the recently concluded Jharkhand assembly election.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

The list included the names of party general secretary and Rajya Sabha member K C Tyagi, besides Rajya Sabha member RCP Singh, Bashistha Narain Singh and Ramnath Thakur. JD(U) Delhi in charge Sanjay Kumar Jha said the party would field candidates in Burari and Sangam Vihar constituencies that have a sizeable Poorvanchali population. Former MLA SCL Gupta, who is likely to be fielded from Sangam Vihar, joined JD(U) on Monday.

Title: New policy to sort out tax issues between industries and local bodies
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bengaluru: In a move to end the constant tussle on taxation between industries and civic agencies, including urban and rural local bodies, the government said it will soon introduce a uniform taxation policy.

"We are holding discussions with the urban development and rural development and panchayat raj ministries to finalise rules. It will be tabled before the cabinet for approval soon," industries minister Jagadish Shettar told TOI before leaving for Davos to participate in the World Economic Forum.

For years now, industries have been accusing local bodies of levying "unreasonable" taxes, which they say is a violation of rules. Industries say local bodies are demanding tax even before industrial layouts are developed by the Karnataka Industrial Area Development Board (KIADB) and handed over to local bodies.

As per rules, layouts, whether residential or industrial, should be handed over to the respective local body, which, besides maintaining it, should provide water, power supply and other infrastructure. "Only after that they [local bodies] are can collect tax," said a senior official from the industries department.

However, a former mayor of a city municipal corporation in North Karnataka accused the KIADB of "intentionally delaying" handing over layouts after utility services were installed by local bodies. The former mayor said this has allowed industries to function without paying tax.

"If local bodies supply water, electricity and provide other infrastructure, industries are bound to pay tax," said the former mayor. "But because the KIADB takes it owns sweet time, industries avoid paying tax which is hurting the financial health of local bodies."

This tussle has led to industries knocking on the doors of courts, resulting in tax dues piling up. Besides this, there is also the issue of different tax slabs being devised by different local bodies — much to the discomfiture of industries.

"The new policy will address all these issues," Shettar said. "There will be a uniform rate applicable to all urban local bodies."

Under the new policy, sources say, industries will have to pay tax dues of the previous year from the date of implementation of the new policy. The government will also ask KIADB to share 50% cess it collects from industries with local bodies till it officially hands over the layout.

Title: Police seek 28 days’ custody of duo held in SSI murder case
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madurai: Kanyakumari district police have sought 28 days custody of A Abdul Sameem of Thiruvithancode and M Thoufiq of Elankadai near Nagercoil who were arrested for allegedly murdering special sub-inspector (SSI) of police, Wilson . The principal district and sessions judge (PDJ) who heard arguments on both sides said they will deliver the verdict on Tuesday afternoon.

On Monday, Sameem and Thoufiq were escorted from the Palayamkottai prison and produced before PDJ S Arulmurugan amidst heavy police security. Police sought 28 days custody of the duo for interrogation. Public prosecutor Gnanasekar argued that the police needed the time for extracting lot of information from the duo.

This includes getting information on where they hid the gun and knife used in the murder which are yet to be recovered and vital information regarding their terror links. However, counsels appearing for Sameem and Thoufiq said the court should not grant permission for police custody as the duo are facing serious threat to their lives from the police.

After listening to arguments from both sides, the judge posted the matter for Tuesday. The duo was then escorted back to the Palayamkottai prison.

Meanwhile, Thoufiq’s mother Y Jennath told reporters outside the court that her son was purposely framed in the murder. Claiming that her son is innocent, she added that he got married only 10 months ago and that his marital life has been ruined because of the police. His wife is in the eight month of pregnancy.

Earlier in the day, the Madurai bench of the Madras high court dismissed the habeas corpus petition (HCP) moved by Jennath that her son was not involved in this case and that he was kept in illegal custody and tortured. Accusing the police of harassing the family too, she expressed fears that the police might eliminate him in an encounter.

In her petition, she sought that her son be produced before the court and set him at liberty. When the petition was heard on Monday, the state government submitted that Thoufiq was arrested and remanded in connection with the murder of SSI Wilson, following which the division bench of justices T Raja and B Pugalendhi dismissed the petition.

Wilson was on duty at a Kaliyakkavilai check post in the inter-state boundary late on January 8 when two people murdered him by firing a few rounds and stabbing him. On January 14, the Karnataka police arrested the duo at the Udupi railway station in Udupi district, and handed them over to the Kanyakumari police. The duo was brought to Kanyakumari on January 16 and produced before the Kuzhithurai court. The court directed the duo to be lodged in the Palayamkottai Central Prison in judicial custody till Monday and to produce them before the court. Meanwhile, the duo was also booked under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act. Considering the sections and seriousness of the case was transferred to the PDJ court in Nagercoil.

Title: Nashik: Price of onions up by Rs 950/quintal at Lasalgaon
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The average wholesale price of onions at the Agricultural Produce Market Committee (APMC) in Lasalgaon shot up by Rs 950 to touch Rs 4,400 per quintal on Monday. The average wholesale onion price was Rs 3,450 quintal on Friday.

Sources in the APMC attribute the increase in the average wholesale onion price to the rise in demand compared to the supply.

In retail markets, good quality onions are being sold between Rs 40 to Rs 50 per kg. The sudden rise in average wholesale onion price is likely to reflect in wholesale markets in a day or two.

The minimum and maximum prices of onions at Lasalgaon were recorded at Rs 1,600 and Rs 4,853 per quintal respectively. Around 15,000 quintal of onions were auctioned at Lasalgaon on Monday.

“The unseasonal rain last year had damaged 75% of the kharif onions. However, late kharif onions have been cultivated in around 45,000 hectare area in the district. The harvest of late kharif onions has begun. Both kharif and late kharif onions are arriving in the market,” ssaid sources in the APMC.

The wholesale price of onions has been fluctuating since the past two months.

The average wholesale onion price had recorded an all-time high of Rs 8,625 per quintal on December 16 last year. However, the price had plummetted by 40% in just a week.

According to APMC officials, the price of onions would remain on the lower side notwithstanding the average wholesale price which shot up to Rs 4,500 in just a day. “We are expecting the average wholesale onion price to drop below Rs 3,000 per quintal in the next three to four days,” said the officials.

Title: This academic year, GU got nearly Rs 2cr in research funding
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: Goa University (GU) faculty and students worked on as many as 44 sponsored research projects in the academic year 2018-19, receiving funding of Rs 1.98 crore for the work. The university also received Rs 8.79 lakh for working on five consultancy projects, it told the Union human resource development ministry in its submission for the National Institutional Ranking Framework (NIRF) 2020.

The 2019 NIRF saw GU placed at no. 98.

When the ranking began in 2016, GU was ranked 20. As more universities entered the race in 2017, GU slid to the 64th spot. In 2018, it dropped to 68, but managed to retain its position as one of the 75 best universities.

The university has written to the HRD ministry stating that the ranking criteria is skewed in favour of bigger universities as the comparison is purely quantitative, and not based on average of faculty available, funds, outcome, etc.

In its submission for NIRF 2020, it said that during the academic year 2018-19, it had 1,556 students in various two-year postgraduate programmes. Of these, 1,122 were women. GU also stated that there were 105 students from outside Goa, and 19 foreign ones. GU has said that more than 80% of its buildings have ramps or lifts and specially-designed toilets for physically-challenged students.

Five of the university’s faculty members received different state and national awards 2018-19. Also, during 2018-19, 659 students graduated within the minimum stipulated time. Altogether, 408 students were selected for higher education and 65 found placement, the university said.

Title: Not prizes, it is honour that drives Alanganallur brothers to tame bulls
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madurai: It was K Kannan, a coconut tree climber, who taught the basic bull taming lessons to his sons K Rajithkumar and K Ramkumar, who emerged the best bull tamers consecutively in 2019 and 2020 in Alanganallur, their native village. However, Kannan, who himself a bull tamer, and his wife K Sundari do not approve of their sons participating in risky jallikattu events. Ranjithkumar got married only six months ago and his wife too does not like him taking part in jallikattu events, but it did not stop him from entering the arena . While he became the talk of the town for his scintillating performance, he got only scolding from his mother, he said.

Ranjithkumar, 24, and his younger brother Ramkumar, 22, have been training with bulls ever since they entered teenage. They would stealthily leave the house to take part in the events before their parents wake up. They would use the excuse of taking their bulls to the events, as they raise two bulls namely Karuppu and Vellaiyan, which are Umbalacherri and Theni Malaimadu breeds. Karuppu was among one of the bulls that won prizes in Alanganallur jallikattu this year. Ramkumar tamed 15 bulls and emerged winner last year to bag a car. Ranjithkumar tamed 16 bulls this year and won the first prize, again a car. He received a symbolic key from chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami in Chennai. When Ranjithkumar entered the ring in the last batch around 3.30 pm, just one hour before the closing time, little did the crowd know that he was the one, who is going to emerge as the winner. M Karthick from Ayuthanpatti, who had already spent quite some time in the ring, was clearly going ahead. Taming 16 bulls in just one round is unprecedented. But Ranjithkumar made it possible utilising the 30-minute extension allowed by the committee. “Prize not a big factor to emerge as winner. I just wanted to tame every bull and to make my village proud. Although there was a close competition with another tamer, I did not count the bulls. I just wanted to tame tougher bulls and earn appreciation,” he said.

His parents always wanted Ranjithkumar to find a government job. Unlike his younger sibling, who studied only up to 10th standard, he has completed diploma in electrical engineering. He is taking up odd jobs as a daily wager. “I asked the revenue minister to give me a government job as a reward of my performance. He said that he will look into it,” he said. Ramkumar sold his car and purchased the bulls using the money. He cited lack of parking space in his small house as a reason for buying bulls. “I work in a saw mill and earn Rs 7,000 a month, which is only enough to take care of my bulls. I always wanted to own bulls, since we see them as god in our village,” he said.

Title: Population survey in state from April 16 to May 30
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: The National Population Register ( NPR ) survey will take place in Goa from April 16 to May 30, while the houselisting survey of Census 2021 will be from February 9 to 28.

“In Goa, there are many Portuguese passport holders and other foreigners living. If they do not have an Indian passport, they can say so. Enumerators will not insist on any of this information or any documents to support these details,” officials of the Goa office of the directorate of census operations said.

Details of Aadhaar, passport number, voter ID and driving licence will be mandatory if you possess these documents, officials said.

While some of the details, like date and place of birth of parents, mother tongue, last place of residence, passport number, voter ID card number and driving licence number, are being sought for the first time, there will be no need to furnish documents to support this information, officials said.

Data collected from the houselisting survey will serve as a broad guideline for the actual Census 2021.

“Enumerators will visit a house up to three times, if it is found locked,” they said.

Officials said at least 3,000 enumerators and 500 supervisors will be trained for the survey and during the 45-day period of the survey, all households in Goa will be covered.

Last Friday, census officials from states and Union territories, including Goa, attended a meeting in Delhi to discuss the the NPR survey and the methods to conduct it.

A state-level coordination committee headed by the chief secretary will hold a meeting this month-end to plan the survey work. Training will be held for collectors, deputy collectors and mamlatdars during the second week of February.

They will then act as master trainers and will train 47 field trainers who will then train the enumerators, mainly primary school teachers.

The houselisting survey will also see enumerators asking details of facilities available in the household, like the number of rooms, main source of drinking water, main source of lighting, access to toilet, if the bathing facility is attached to the house, fuel used for cooking, availability of assets like television, internet, laptop, mobile phone and vehicles among others.

Title: Tourism corp does U-turn, to lease out its fuel pumps
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: Goa Tourism Development Corporation (GTDC), which plans to develop five petrol pumps across the state, will lease them out. It has already built one petrol pump at Pernem, which is ready for operation.

While it had initially decided to appoint a service provider to help operate and maintain the facilities, GTDC members opposed the idea of the corporation operating the petrol pumps. “A majority of the board members felt that GTDC shouldn’t take up the responsibility of operating petrol pumps,” a board member said.

“Who will account for fuel leakage and pilferage if GTDC starts operating the pumps,” the board member asked. Another member said it did not make sense for GTDC to take on the responsibility of running the petrol pumps when most of its residencies are in losses, and a major component of its expense is towards paying staff salaries.“GTDC will have to hire staff to work at the petrol pumps, and even if hired on contract-basis, surely there will be demands in future for regularisation of services, even if the pumps become economically unviable after a while,” he said.

The tourism department is already facing trouble with lifeguards even though it has appointed a lifeguarding service provider. The proposal to set up petrol stations was approved more than three years ago, in a bid to bolster GTDC’s falling economic health.

Title: Woman, her daughter stabbed by teenager
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madurai: A government school teacher and her daughter were stabbed by a teenager in a village near Usilampatti in Madurai district on Monday.

Police said the incident, which took place in Kokkudaiyanpatti village near Usilampatti, was a fallout of an enmity between the woman’s husband and the teenager.

The two were rushed to a nearby hospital with the help of relatives, from where they were shifted to a private hospital in Madurai. Police sources said the two are out of danger and responding to treatment.

According to police, Munipandi, a driver working with the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC), reprimanded the 17-year-old boy, studying first year in a private college for consuming liquor near his house three days back.

It resulted in an ugly quarrel, resulting in Munipandi beating up the boy, hailing from the same village.

The teen came to Munipandi’s house armed with a knife with the intention of attacking him.

However, as Munipandi was not at home, the boy picked up a quarrel with his wife Kala and daughter Ananda Swetha and attacked them. As they screamed for help, relatives rushed to the house. But the boy managed to escape by then.

A police team from the Usilampatti Town station rushed to the spot and conducted an inquiry. They also picked up the teen later and an inquiry was carried out with him.

Kala is working in the K Perumalpatti government school, while her daughter is studying third year in a city college.

Police sources said that the juvenile in conflict with law would be produced before the juvenile justice board and lodged in an observation home.

Title: Accident deaths come down by 15% in 2019: City top cop
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madurai: The number of road fatalities in Madurai has come down by 15% in 2019 compared to its previous year, police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham has said.

Speaking after flagging off a rally to create sensitization on wearing helmet organized by the road transport department as part of the 31st Road Safety Week, the commissioner said the number of road deaths is coming down in the city due to increased percentage of people wearing helmet after the intensive awareness created by various agencies including the city police. Police sources said that while 232 road deaths took place in 2016, it has been coming down every year since then. It is for the first time the number of accidents has come down to less than 200 mark.

Devasirvatham said the city police has set an ambitious target of bringing down the road fatality by 50% in 2020 compared to 2019. Most deaths in road accidents take place due to head injury, which can be reduced if all the motorists comply with the helmet rule, he added.

A large number of public, men and women police personnel from the city unit took part in the rally, which started at Thamukkam. It ended at Palanganatham junction after passing through Anna Statue, South Veli Street, Crime Branch, Madura College and Subramaniyapuram police station junction.

Madurai district collector, T G Vinay, deputy commissioner of law and order E Karthick, deputy commissioner of traffic K Sugumaran, joint commissioner of transport Ravichandran, road transport officers Selvam , Suresh and Ponnurangam took part in the event.

Title: Chhagan Bhujbal not in favour of Nashik bus service, Metro project
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Chhagan Bhujbal

NASHIK: District guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal has dropped broad hints that he is not in favour of Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) taking over the city bus service or being a stakeholder in the ambitious Nashik Metro project .

Bhujbal met mayor Satish Kulkarni on Monday evening to discuss various issues related to development projects in the city. The meeting lasted around 20 minutes.

“I reminded the mayor that financial condition of the civic body is not healthy. At this juncture, if NMC invests in projects like city bus service and Metro, it would add further pressure on NMC’s coffers,” Bhujbal said.

According to the guardian minister, he has suggested Kulkarni to seek advice from experts whether it would be feasible for the NMC to implement such projects that require huge investments.

These two projects were initiated during the regime of the erstwhile BJP-led government in the state. Former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis had directed the NMC to take over the city bus service as MSRTC is not keen to continue rendering services within the city limits due to mounting losses.

Similarly, Fadvanis had announced the metro project for Nashik and Maha Metro has already prepared the DPR, which was approved by the previous state cabinet. The DPR was then submitted to the Centre for its final approval.

Bhujbal said there were discussions on other issues like cleanliness, mosquito eradication and garden development. “I am of the view that Nashik city should be clean and beautiful and NMC should ensure for this. It does not matter which party the mayor belongs to. I will support development of the city and not give any political label for the meeting with the mayor,” he said.

Meanwhile, Kulkarni urged Bhujbal to make efforts and get grants from the state government for the city bus service project.

“MSRTC was unwilling to run financially-troubled bus service and poor bus service was causing inconvenience to the citizens. Giving services to citizens is the first priority of the civic body. Hence, the NMC has decided to take over city bus service from MSRTC. The NMC will bear loss because of the service and we want the state government to compensate the losses,” Kulkarni said in a press release issued by the NMC.

“They tyre-based Nashik metro project is the first project in the country which is to be executed jointly by Centre and state. The total cost of the project is Rs 2,200 crore and the NMC as stakeholder will have to contribute Rs 102 crore. The NMC is already providing space for the project. Hence, state needs to reduce the burden of this additional amount on NMC,” the statement added.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Farmers reap benefits of farm ponds during low rainfall
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Though agricultural experts and the government have been advising farmers to create small farm ponds in their ... Read More

COIMBATORE: Unlike the rest of the district, Udumalpet did not receive heavy rainfall last year – just two spells of rainfall.

Under normal circumstances, wells and borewells go dry by January-end in Udumalpet.

But water can still be seen in R Raghunathan’s well, thanks to a large 80ftx80ft farm pond he created in August 2019.

A coconut farmer, Raghunathan is now confident that he can manage till the next southwest monsoon with the water available in the pond and the well.

Though agricultural experts and the government have been advising farmers to create small farm ponds in their lands for years, as an effective method of rainwater harvesting , it is only now that farmers in the Pollachi region seem to be experimenting with the idea.

“It not only holds the rainwater but also allows it to percolate into the soil, recharging the groundwater table in the area up to 1km radius,” Raghunathan says.

In the last two-and-half years, nearly 590 farmers between Kinathukidavu and Udumalpet, as part of Marico’s Kalpavriksha project, have either created farm ponds, bunds or trenches to save the rainwater that their land receives. “While at least 135 farmers from August 2018 have created farm ponds of different sizes, around 458 farmers have created trenches or bunds,” says Marico’s executive vice-president Udayraj Prabhu.

As per the project, 80% of the cost to create a pond is borne by Marico and the rest by the farmer.

It costs between Rs 50,000 and Rs 1 lakh based on its size to make a farm pond.

Though they don’t have numbers to prove improvement in groundwater table levels, farmers say the fact that their dry borewells have begun yielding water is proof that these ponds are serving their purpose.

S Subramani, a coconut farmer in Kinathukadavu , who created a 20ftx16ft farm pond in his land says he has drilled borewells twice and they have come dry even at beyond 100ft. “We have had to buy water to water my trees and then ended up cutting down many of them during the drought,” he says. “For the first time, I can see water standing in the pond and the borewell yielding water,” he adds.

“A farm pond does take away the cultivable space of at least seven to eight trees, but by giving up this space, we are saving more than 250 of our remaining trees,” says Gopalsamy, a farmer from Kolapatti.

Urdhvam and Bhungroo are the other initiatives being tried by farmers in the region.

While Bhungroo is a system where they inject harvested rainwater straight into an empty aquifer to store it and lifts it out for use during dry spells, Urdhvam is a system where they slit the casing of an existing borewell from the side, for enhancing higher water recharging in the borewell.

“However, Bhungroo is expensive, and water needs to be shared with nearby farmer. If they agree, the system works,” says Prabhu.

R Amritharaj, in whose land a Bhungroo was created as a pilot project, says he had previously dug borewells twice only to find them empty. “However, my 100-ft deep borewells are now yielding water due to the Bhungroo,” he adds.

The Tamil Nadu government has also launched a farm pond scheme, where farmers can get a 50% subsidy on their pond creation costs.

Title: People sneak ‘special’ metro rides with ‘ordinary’ tickets
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

According to metro rail officials, nearly 99% of the people who travel in special class have ordinary class ti... Read More

CHENNAI: Only 1% of passengers travelling in special class coaches on the metro actually buy the more expensive tickets, according to CMRL officials. In the past nine months, only some 9,600 special class tickets have been issued, but the coaches, which have cushioned red seats unlike the hard blue seats in the regular coaches, are often crowded.

“Nearly 99% of the people who travel in special class have ordinary class tickets. Of them, 50% to 70% are our own staff and police personnel while the rest are other commuters ,” a metro rail official said.

The comfort of cushioned seats comes at a premium. While the minimum fare in ordinary class is Rs 10 and the maximum Rs 70, a ride in special class costs double that.

CMRL numbers show that the service has gained traction over the past few months since the last leg of 45km phase-1 between Washermenpet and AG-DMS began operations in February 2019.

Between April and December 2019, around 9,617 people paid for special class tickets — 9,222 commuters purchasing tokens at the ticket counters in the stations while the rest had smartcards . “Most of our commuters in special class are one-time travellers,” an official said. Special class commuters get a gold coloured smartcard that looks different from the regular ones.

So, why are there no ticket checkers? Metro rail officials said though they have a separate ticket inspection team trained to use a handheld device to scan tokens and smartcards, they do not conduct surprise checks as they think it would discourage people from using the metro. Already patronage is lower than expected. The average daily ridership is 1.16 lakh for the 45km stretch against an earlier projection of 7.76 lakh.

“Our patronage is only now slowing increasing. Let people enjoy the ride and start using our service regularly. We do not want to stop people from using our service. Once our ridership goes up, we will have regular ticket checking. As of now, we have our train operators who, at times, step out of their cabin to check tickets,” said an official.

Title: Karwar native held for thefts
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

VALPOI: Valpoi police on Monday arrested Naseer Madnali, 33, in connection with thefts at various places across the state. A Karwar native, Madnali currently resides at Indiranagar , Chimbel.

Valpoi police said that during the interrogation, the accused confessed to committing thefts at Pernem , Bicholim and Ponda. Madnali has been remanded into four days police custody and a case registered under sections 457 and 380 of Indian Penal Code .

Title: Rajasthan to get goat milk dairy in Tonk district
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

JAIPUR: Rajasthan will soon have its own goat milk dairy at Dooni in Tonk District that will be run exclusively by the women of nearby villages. The dairy has been branded as ‘AJA’ which means goat in Sanskrit, it will be run by the Matree Mahila Dairy & Agriculture Producer Company Ltd ( MMDAPC ) which has more than 1,000 women as its members.

This company contains a group of women who will collect the milk from the villages around them, bring them to the collection centre and from where it will be transported to the dairy where it will be processed. The scheme is looked after by Rajasthan Agricultural Competitiveness Project (RACP).

Project director of RACP and Rajasthan agriculture commissioner, Om Prakash, said that they have already received a grant of Rs 3.10 crore from the state government and the work will start very soon.

“Tender for the construction of the dairy will float very soon. We have provided the MMDAPC a 90% subsidy in opening the dairy. They will process the milk and will sell it in the market of Delhi, Jaipur and other prominent cities in Rajasthan,” said Om Prakash.

The project to venture in the production of the goat milk is going on since 2019 when the RACP organised the women in Rajasthan to sell goat milk and goat milk soap. A few months ago, milk and soaps were launched by RACP and are now available in shops situated at Gandhi Nagar, Jagatpura and Vaishali Nagar in Jaipur. But opening a dairy will enhance the capacity of milk production and the products.

Pritpal Singh Kalra, Project Coordinator (Livestock) at RACP said, “We are now utilising our goat milk share in the state properly. This dairy will process plain milk, flavoured milk, cheese, yogurt and ghee. Goat milk is nutritious, especially for children. In metro cities it is being sold at higher rates but here it would cost around Rs 35-Rs 50 per kg. At present it is being sold in bottles but in future we will sell it in tetra packs.”

At present, India is producing five million tonnes of goat milk every day. Goat milk has digestive elements, medium and small fatty acids and has components almost equivalent to human breast milk, which is why it is beneficial for children.

Title: Plan to expand ferry service in Kanyakumari hits a roadblock
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The existing jetty is 37m long and 8m wide. The proposal was to extend it to 140m length at Rs 20 crore

CHENNAI: Expansion of passenger boat services to Vivekananda Rock Memorial and Thiruvalluvar Statue in Kanyakumari might be delayed further as a proposal to expand the existing jetty to berth more passenger boats has been rejected. The Tamil Nadu Coastal Zone Management Authority (TNSZMA) rejected Tamil Nadu Maritime Board’s proposal, which involved constructing groynes, citing a National Green Tribunal order.

The existing jetty is 37m long and 8m wide. The proposal was to extend it to 140m length at Rs 20 crore. Protective groynes (low wall or barriers) built using rubble mounds, tetrapod armor units and pre-cast concrete blocks were to be constructed throughout the length to protect the jetty from erosion and wave action.

While a ferry service operating from 8am to 4pm exists, most days and especially during tourist season and weekends, queue at the passenger boat ticket counter is over 1km long, according to official documents submitted with the proposal by TNMB. Everyday, at least 2,000 people don’t get a chance to visit the famed tourist spots, shows TNMB data.

Following this, TNMB and Indian Ports Association proposed to resolve the issue by extending passenger jetty so that two more vessels can be berthed, increasing the number of ferry services. “If the proposal materializes, more people will get to visit the rock without waiting for a long time,” TNMB sources said.

The proposed project falls in Coastal Regulatory Zone-IB (intertidal zone) and CRZ-IV (water bodies influenced by tides) areas. CRZ Notification 2011 prohibits alteration of landscape in such areas for entertainment, recreation and beautification activities.

The National Green Tribunal (NGT), in 2013, had directed the state government not to construct groynes or sea walls along the Tamil Nadu coastline without preparing a Comprehensive Shoreline Protection Management Plan (CSPMP). This plan, prepared with the help of experts from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Madras, is pending for approval by the Union environment and forest ministry.

Citing the lapse, the TNSCMA in November last put a stopper on TNMB’s request to expand the jetty. It had asked the maritime board to instead study the feasibility of expansion without formation of groynes.

Title: 13,000 staff on Delhi election duty to stay overnight at polling booths
Content:
File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: The three municipal corporations will be making lodging arrangements for over 13,000 employees deployed on election duty at 13,463 polling booths the night before voting takes place.The initiative has been taken on the direction of Election Commission making it mandatory for male staff deployed on election duty to stay on site at night before election day so that mock polling can be conducted before 7am. It’s optional for women staff to stay overnight at the polling booths.A senior East Delhi Municipal Corporation official said there will be 3,131 polling booths at 566 sites in areas under its jurisdiction.“Each site has 3-10 polling booths. At each booth, there will be one polling team, including 2-3 polling officers, one presiding officer and an assistant. They will have to be on duty by 5am on election day so that EVMs can be checked and mock polls conducted in front of the polling agents. This is the reason why their lodging arrangements have been done on site,” the official said.A nodal officer and sanitation and health department employees of the municipal corporations will be stationed at the sites, including primary, Delhi government and private schools and community halls.The civic agencies have been asked to install porta cabins instead of tents this time. “We have called for a joint meeting with officials of all zones on Tuesday to identify sites that have a shortage of rooms,” said a North Delhi Municipal Corporation official.

Title: 13,000 staff on Delhi election duty to stay overnight at polling booths
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: The three municipal corporations will be making lodging arrangements for over 13,000 employees deployed on election duty at 13,463 polling booths the night before voting takes place.

The initiative has been taken on the direction of Election Commission making it mandatory for male staff deployed on election duty to stay on site at night before election day so that mock polling can be conducted before 7am. It’s optional for women staff to stay overnight at the polling booths.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

A senior East Delhi Municipal Corporation official said there will be 3,131 polling booths at 566 sites in areas under its jurisdiction.

“Each site has 3-10 polling booths. At each booth, there will be one polling team, including 2-3 polling officers, one presiding officer and an assistant. They will have to be on duty by 5am on election day so that EVMs can be checked and mock polls conducted in front of the polling agents. This is the reason why their lodging arrangements have been done on site,” the official said.

A nodal officer and sanitation and health department employees of the municipal corporations will be stationed at the sites, including primary, Delhi government and private schools and community halls.

The civic agencies have been asked to install porta cabins instead of tents this time. “We have called for a joint meeting with officials of all zones on Tuesday to identify sites that have a shortage of rooms,” said a North Delhi Municipal Corporation official.

Title: Rising cases of cylinder thefts in Mayem
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

BICHOLIM: Mayem locals are irked about the rising instances of cylinder thefts that have occurred over the past few months.

With nearly 15 cases of empty cylinders being stolen from Gaonkarwada and Ardhawada, the villagers claim that a gang of thieves is at work.

Since cylinder refill services are offered just once a week, many office-going residents keep their empty cylinders outside their houses. The suppliers, however, said they did not find any empty cylinders. Later it was found that the empty cylinders were being stolen.

Title: ‘Become entrepreneurs, don’t settle down in big companies’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madurai: Daniel Chellappa J, senior scientist, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre (BARC), has urged engineering students to try to become entrepreneurs using and inventing technology for development rather than settle in big companies. He was speaking at ‘Technological empowerment of budding entrepreneurs’, a programme organized by the Rotary Club of Madurai Meenakshi being held at the Solamalai College of Engineering.

“There are better options available for students to settle for in their life other than getting placed in reputed companies. They can generate revenue easily even in lakhs through entrepreneurship. Their concept should be technically viable and economically feasible,” he said.

Chellappa further demonstrated how a regular RO filter works with electricity and later explained a new project, ‘Ultra filtration B Nova water purification,’ for which, no electricity needs to be used to filter water. “We are getting resources of daily consumables through imported sources. Through soil resources available in Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Odisha, we can repay our nation’s debt. Electricity can be produced using these soil resources,” he said.

The participating students were sensitized about various schemes and resources available for budding entrepreneurs, including the district industries centre (DIC), which aims to offer services and support to all medium and small Enterprises (MSMEs), under a single roof.

Pre-final year and final year students of both engineering and polytechnic colleges from across the district took part in the programme.

Title: Shirgao locals halt ore trucks, want water bills settled
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bicholim: Demanding that their pending water bills be settled first, Shirgao villagers on Monday halted vehicles transporting ore through the village.

With majority of their wells having run dry due to mining activities, residents are wholly dependent on water supplied by the public works department (PWD). Since the last several years, the water bills were paid by the mining company.

During the last two years, however, the company stopped paying the bills stating that no mining work is being undertaken.

Villagers have received notices from the PWD threatening that their water connections would be cut.

On Monday, furious at seeing trucks transporting ore from the mines, a large number of villagers, especially women, gathered on the road and halted the trucks. “We demand that the mining company first settles the pending water bills,” Shirgao deputy sarpanch, Vijaya Mandrekar said.

Following the commotion, a special meeting of all the stakeholders was held at the office of deputy collector Sachin Desai. He later told reporters that for now, the PWD will not cut water connections of any villagers. In turn, transportation of ore will temporarily continue from Tuesday onwards.

Title: Sivaganga MCH to begin eye transplant procedures soon
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madurai: ‘Hospital Cornea Retrieval Program’, an eye donation initiative organized by the Government Sivaganga Medical College Hospital (GSMCH) in association with Aravind Eye Hospitals (AEH), Madurai, was inaugurated on Monday.

A human eye can be donated if it is removed within six hours after a person’s death. “Initially, GSMCH will donate the eyes for transplantation and the procedure will be performed at AEH. Within a few months, the procedure will be done at GSMCH itself. We will train a team of doctors for the process and the infrastructure required would be set up here itself by then and only the processing of the eye will be done by AEH, free of cost,” explained dean of GSMCH, Dr A Rathinavel.

Many organ donations and transplants, like the kidney, require an organisational structure at the state level, but eye donations and transplants involve a simpler process. “In this case, since we can remove the eye only from a dead person, all we need is consent from the patient’s kin. This can be managed at the institutional level. We’ve reached out to local groups,” said Rathinavel.

On Monday, Dr N Venkatesh Prajna, opthalmology director, Aravind Eye Hospitals and Rathinavel inaugurated the programme at a special event held on the GSMCH campus. “We’re having public-private partnerships with many government medical colleges. We reached out to GSMCH especially because we want to help start corneal transplantation in Sivaganga as well. The first step is to create awareness,” said Prajna. A special helpline number (7598520007) for eye donation was also released for the public to contact.

Title: 4 centres to serve Shivbhojan thali in district
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nashik: Shivbojan thali — the discounted food programme of the state government — will be available at three centres in the city and at one centre in Malegaon from January 26, a senior official from the district administration said.

The state government has decided to give food at a discounted rate and will give a subsidy of Rs 40 per thali to the vendor who can charge only Rs 10 for the food served between 12 noon and 2pm.

The food should be provided by a non-profit organization, a non-governmental organization or the ones run by the Mahila Bachat Gat so that there is no profiteering from the scheme and only genuine people get the benefit of the same.

Also, it has to be noted that the organization willing to served food should have its own property and not serve the food in public place.

Accordingly, the district administration has planned three places in the city — at district collectorate, Nashik Road and Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC). In Malegaon, the food will be served in Malegaon Corporation area.

A district administration official said none of the government employees were allowed to benefit from the scheme as the beneficiary was necessarily expected to be from the economically weaker section.

While there are no major criteria set up by the government so far, the vendor has been asked to click the photo of the beneficiary who has been served the food. “The beneficiary has to produce a Below Poverty Line (BPL) card and get his picture clicked for benefitting from the scheme,” the official said.

He added that though food is to be distributed from January 26, formalities have to be completed before-hand.

Title: Schools turn to make-do translators for PM’s event
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madurai: Thousands of school students across Madurai, especially between Classes VIII and XII, tuned in to see Prime Minister Narendra Modi interact with school students across India at this year’s ‘Pariksha pe charcha’ in New Delhi. However, with most of the content spoken in Hindi and no subtitles or translation in Tamil, many schools had to turn to teachers and students who knew Hindi to translate.

Most schools in the city, barring a few private schools, screened Modi’s nearly two-hour long ‘Pariksha pe charcha’ programme using a projector or a computer. “When we started screening, we started getting concerned as students, especially those who don’t understand English well too, began showing disinterest. Luckily, we had a student who knew Hindi so she was asked to translate and explain,” said the principal of a corporation school.

Meanwhile, when asked if proper Hindi translators could have been appointed in the schools in advance, Madurai district chief educational officer, R Swaminathan said that so far no complaints were received. “It can’t be helped. However, I am sure students and teachers, who know Hindi, definitely would have pitched in to ensure everyone was able to listen and take in whatever our Prime Minister spoke about,” he said. On the other hand, students who were able to understand the programme, said that the PM’s speech was refreshing to listen to ahead of their exams.

Title: I-T case: Karti Chidambaram must appear in court
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Karti Chidambaram

CHENNAI: Former Union finance minister P Chidambaram ’s son Karti Chidambaram and wife have to appear before a special court for cases against MPs and MLAs on Tuesday, as the Madras high court has refused urgent hearing of their pleas challenging the prosecution initiated by the income tax department. The case pertains to non-disclosure of income to the tune of Rs 7 crore by the couple.

On Monday morning, when the high court commenced its proceedings, senior counsel Nalini Chidambaram made a mention before the first bench headed by the Chief Justice A P Sahi about the representation made to the registrar (judicial) on behalf of Karti. The CJ informed the senior counsel that the case would be listed before Justice M Sundar.

The senior counsel appeared before Justice Sundar post lunch and made a mention for urgent hearing of the plea, since the special court is scheduled to hear the matter on Tuesday. However, Justice Sundar refused any urgent hearing and made it clear that the plea would be taken up for hearing in due course.

According to the prosecution, Karti, his wife Srinidhi, and his mother Nalini Chidambaram had sold their lands at Muttukadu near Chennai to Agni Estates and Foundations Private Limited at Rs 4.25 crore an acre. However, the sale deed executed by the three was registered only for the guideline value of Rs 3 crore an acre and the remaining Rs 1.25 crore per acre was paid to them in cash. As such, Karti received Rs 6.38 crore and Srinidhi received Rs 1.35 crore, said the department.

As per the department’s complaint, Karti had not disclosed the receipt of cash components in their income tax return for the assessment year 2014-15 and Srinidhi in her return for 2015-16. The non-disclosure came to light during a joint search conducted by the I-T department and the Enforcement Directorate on December 1, 2015, in connection with the case of Advantage Strategic Consulting Pvt Ltd.

On January 7, the special court dismissed a plea moved by the duo to discharge them from the case and directed their appearance on January 21 for framing charges.

Title: Delhi: Legal tag to colonies matters, but access to basic necessities may weigh
Content:
Agricultural land has given way to colonies

NEW DELHI: “I can now get ownership rights of my house and it will help me get a loan if I need one,” smiled 60-year-old Gopal Das outside his imposing house in north Delhi’s Himgiri Enclave, one of the 1,731 unauthorised colonies in the city where conveyance deeds to their properties are being given to the residents. Das is grateful to Bharatiya Janata Party for fulfilling this long-pending wish.In the same breath, however, Das says that the Aam Aadmi Party has done a lot of work in the Burari assembly constituency, where Himgiri Enclave is located. “Two CCTV cameras have been installed in our lane by Delhi government and the road has been paved too. The MLA, Sanjeev Jha, is very accessible and tries his best to solve our problems,” Das testified.Himgiri Enclave is among the ‘better’ of the constituency’s unauthorised colonies. Burari is one of the bigger assembly constituencies not only in terms of area, but also the electorate. With 3.5 lakh voters, it is third largest constituency in Delhi. It has quite a few villages such as Burari, Mukandpur, Mukhmelpur and Jagatpur. While some areas are still agricultural, much of the farm lands have been urbanised or taken over by authorised colonies. Some like Himgiri Enclave and Harit Vihar have wide roads and kothis built on large plots, but the rest of the unauthorised colonies have poor drainage and sanitation and almost non-existent roads.“The road is being constructed,” said Awadesh Kumar, 50, a resident of Samta Vihar, pointing to the sludgy, undulating lane. “The area might look shabby, but it was much worse five years ago. A lot of development has taken place, including laying of sewer lines,” said Kumar, who hails from Uttar Pradesh but has been living in Burari for two decades.Sewage still overflows on to the lanes in Sant Nagar on Burari Road. The area is a hub of coaching institutes and offers students accommodation at low rates. “I have seen big hoardings telling us we will now get ownership rights to our houses,” said local Lalit Chauhan, 30, “but I’m not sure about the process because there is little clarity and no one from this locality has got registry of their holding.”So while regularisation of the unauthorised colony is cheering the people at election time, the ambiguities still bother them. Harit Vihar resident Ram Lakhan Vishwakarma confessed to being unsure of banks extending loans because his colony is still categorised as agricultural land in revenue records. “Regularisation of colonies will take time, but we have the basic necessities because AAP has done a lot of work here,” the 62-year-old said.The Burari constituency has a mix of people from different communities, most of them migrants. While BJP’s Shri Krishan won the seat in 2008, AAP’s Sanjeev Jha was victorious in both the 2013 and 2015.“There were huge farms here earlier, but this place is no longer a village. Agricultural land has given way to colonies and people from Uttar Pradesh, Haryana and Bihar are now in a majority,” said Karn Singh, 62, in Mukandpur Village. “Some development has taken place in the last few years,” he added. According to Yashoda Kumari, 29, a resident of Janta Vihar, another unauthorised colony, road construction had started in her area.Burari village’s Mahendra Singh, 40, however, is not so complacent. “Our electricity bills have not reduced,” he grumbled. “In any case, nothing is free because we end up paying taxes one way or another. I’m happy with Prime Minister Narendra Modi. He has accomplished what no other leader before him did.”

Title: Whiteflies spell doom for Pollachi coconut farmers
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Coconut farmers, who had to cut down several trees during the drought season in 2017, said the flies pose a bi... Read More

COIMBATORE: Walk into any coconut farm in Pollachi and you are greeted by the sight of bright green, yellow and red coconuts. However, a closer look at the leaves that have fallen on the ground reveals a white coating on them an unmistakable sign of whiteflies.

Coconut farmers, who had to cut down several trees during the drought season in 2017, said the flies pose a bigger threat to their livelihood now. The insects, which feed on the underside of coconut leaves, have brought down production by 50% to 75%.

The sap-feeding bugs, despite the bio-control methods advocated by the state government and the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University , have been spreading rapidly in the district. The farmers knocked on every door in the last three months, seeking a remedy.

The bugs are especially attracted towards hybrid varieties, which most farmers prefer as they are short, said T Sakthivel, a member of the Vinayaka Coconut Producers Company , which has 2,500 farmers on board.

“Among the hybrid varieties, whiteflies seem to affect the red coconut varieties the most,” said Gopalsamy, who cultivates native tall varieties as well as the hybrid varieties. “The hybrid trees are heavily affected. I found all pesticides ineffective against the bugs,” he told TOI.

The farmers want the government to step in and save the rest of the trees. “In two years, coconut production has fallen by 75%. We don’t know how long it will take the bugs to destroy all the trees” said S Subramani. “Coconut production in the region will fall drastically if the government does not find solutions to eliminate the insects” the farmer said.

Title: Chennai: Wife of man who died during divorce is heir
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

CHENNAI: A city accident claims tribunal held that the wife of a man who died during pendency of divorce proceedings is a legal heir and eligible for compensation.

The tribunal directed an insurance firm to pay Rs 86 lakh to the family of an engineer who was killed in a road accident in 2012. Of the total amount, the tribunal held that Rs 43 lakh is to be paid to the wife, though she did not move the tribunal seeking compensation and divorce proceedings were pending in family court at the time of the man’s death.

P Jayaraman of Ambattur and his daughter Premalatha moved the tribunal seeking compensation for the death of Jayaraman’s son, Vijayaraghavan. Vijayaraghavan, who was working as a senior engineer in an IT firm was riding his bike along Medavakkam-Perumbakkam Road when a rashly driven truck knocked his two-wheeler down. Jayaraman moved the tribunal seeking compensation and also included his late son’s wife as one of the respondents for proper adjudication.

The insurer of the truck, in response denied that the driver drove in a rash and negligent manner and stated that they are not liable to pay any compensation.

After perusing the oral submissions and documentary evidences, the tribunal held that the truck driver was responsible for the accident. On deciding the legal heir of the deceased, the tribunal noted that the legal heir certificate showed only the father’s name and neither the sister nor the wife’s name was mentioned.

“Since Vijayaraghavan died during pendency of the divorce proceedings before the family court, the divorce petition was dismissed. However, since divorce was not granted, the woman is still to be treated as wife and is entitled for compensation,” tribunal judge V Sudha held and added that the father and the wife of the deceased are entitled for loss of dependency while the married sister is entitled only for loss of love. The tribunal arrived at a compensation of Rs 86 lakh, of which the father and wife are eligible for Rs 42.8 lakh each and the sister Rs 40,000.

Title: Shinde brothers stand out from the herd in buffalo farming
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Brothers Ranjeet (left) and Amit Shinde with the biggest of the six full-grown bulls on their farm. The 9-foot... Read More

In his growing up years, Ranjeet Shinde would quaff a litre of buffalo milk every night. He needed it to build muscle mass not for body demos but to wrestle to the ground invaders with nifty touch-and-flee techniques in the rustic game of kabaddi.

Ranjeet knew even then that the milk he drank scored over cow milk in fats and proteins just as he knew how to toss a bale of hay, fill the right mix of cattle feed in troughs and tell a Murrah buffalo from a Jafarabadi from the shape of its horns.

Migrants from Kolhapur, the Shindes have been rearing buffaloes for milk over four generations. Ranjeet’s grandfather Ramchandra, who worked in the darbar of Shahu Maharaj , came to Pune with a lone buffalo, ‘Hira’, in 1918 and settled down in Somwar Peth which then quite resembled the village he had left in Kolhapur.

The numbers in the shed grew steadily and by 1955, the Shindes had shifted their herd to Kharadi. When the animal count was around 250 in 2010, the Shindes, by then a joint family, decided to split their holdings in the business. Accordingly, Ranjeet and older brother Amit, both in their early 40s now, got 35 buffaloes and moved out to their present 8-acre farm at Wadebolhai, around 18km from Kharadi.

The business expansion was swift. In less than a decade, the Shinde brothers now have 600 buffaloes — the most on any farm in and around Pune. This, even as their cousins from the joint family sold off their share of buffaloes because they were unable to cope with the rigours of the milk business. “The cycle of buying, selling, tending and rearing the animals has to be perfect. More importantly, one’s physical presence on the farm is necessary. Nothing can be controlled remotely,” says Amit.

So the brothers are wide-eyed at the farm even at 1.30am when the first of the two mechanised, bucket-milking sessions happens each day. When in search of buffaloes of good breeds, they travel distances up to 200km daily in the now-familiar villages of Haryana and Bhavnagar (Saurashtra).

The farm gets the best in cattle feed like cotton seed oil cakes, corn, wheat husk and dry sugarcane, all cut and ground in a branded foreign milling unit. The weighing and cooling process for the milk and the drinking water supply to the animals have been fully automated. Of the two trucks of dung generated each day, most is used for the biogas plant on the premises while neighbouring farmers line up for the rest.

Infusing such vitality into an otherwise dreary business has earned the Shinde brothers recognition and accolades at various farm exhibitions and from agricultural agencies. Some of their animals are meritorious in their own right, like the buffalo named ‘Maharani’ which won an award at the Krishi Vigyan Kendra exhibition at Baramati recently for giving a whopping 35 litres of milk in a day, which Ranjeet claims is a record in the state.

Ranjeet says the high-quality feed and care of the animals ensure that no buffalo gives less than 15 litres’ milk per day. Of the 3,000 litres of milk produced at the farm, 2,000 litres are delivered around the city while 1,000 litres go into making byproducts like paneer and curds. In the pipeline is also a plan to make quality mozzarella cheese.

A well-known ‘mastani’ manufacturer in the city primarily uses milk from the Shindes’ farm for its ice-cream because of the high fat content. Ditto for another sweets’ manufacturer with outlets spread across Pune.

The ‘kadhai’ with oil goes on the stove in the evenings at the Shindes’ sales outlet at Kharadi and techies from nearby IT companies shuffle in to savour ghee-laced ‘jalebis’ with milk. Watching the crowd, Ranjeet reminisces how the jalebi-milk combination used to be a favourite with the cauliflower-eared ‘pehelwans’ of Kolhapur, for whom energy in the ‘akhara’ mattered more than calorie count. An energy similar to what Ranjeet himself derived from the copious milk consumption of his youth, which powered his leaps at raiding kabaddi players’ legs.

Title: 4 lakh Warkaris seek saint’s blessings
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

4 lakh Warkaris from across the state seek the blessings of Sant Nivruttinath Maharaj

NASHIK: Over 4 lakh Warkaris from across the state today converged at Trimbakeshwar to seek the blessings of Sant Nivruttinath Maharaj .

The Warkaris, most of whom came on Sunday evening, took a bath at the ‘Kusahavarta’ (sacred pond) and then went to Nivruttinath Maharaj’s temple, where a special puja was performed around Sunday midnight.

District guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal, along with his wife, performed a puja on Monday morning seeking blessings for the welfare of the state and the citizens. The Maharaj’s procession on a palkhi was the star attraction in the evening.

“The procession of the Maharaj is an important programme where the Maharaj is taken to Trimbakeshwar temple on a palki to greet Lord Shankar. When the Maharaj is paraded on the streets on a palki, people young and old queue up on both sides of the street to watch the procession and catch a glimpse of the Maharaj,” said Keshav Tungar, a resident of Trimbakeshwar.

It was only after the palki reached Trimbakeshwar temple did the Warkaris step inside the temple. “It is a tradition that Warkaris don’t visit Trimbakeshwar temple until Nivruttinath Maharaj palki doesn’t visit the temple on Ekadashi,” said Shankar Patil, a member of the palki.

The MSRTC had pressed into service 68 buses, which made more than 500 trips and trasnported 20,000 people between Nashik and Trimbakeshwar. “The bus service from Trimbakeshwar to various parts of the district and the cities across the state will continue till Tuesday evening,” said sources in the MSRTC.

Title: Cong panel to address Gehlot, Pilot tiff
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Jaipur: Congress interim president Sonia Gandhi has constituted a coordination committee for the four Congress-ruled states of Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Puducherry on Monday.

The move is being seen as a mechanism to address factional feud of leaders in the party, including that between chief minister Ashok Gehlot and PCC president and deputy CM Sachin Pilot.

AICC general secretary (organization) K C Venugopal said the committees had been set up to ensure better coordination between the party and the government.

There were instances of government and party leadership having divergent views. Pilot has been quite vocal in his criticism of his own government handling over children’s death in Kota, local bodies elections and the government’s decision to allow non elected people for the post of chairman of local bodies.

The committee for Rajasthan comprises eight members. The committee comprises AICC general secretary incharge Avinash Pande, Gehlot, Pilot, former minister Hemaram Chaudhary, minister Master Bhawarlal Meghwal, former Speaker Deependera Singh Shekhawat, former minister and tribal leader Mahendrajeet Singh Malviya and minister Harish Chaudhary.

In the committee, the high command not only tried to balance the two camps – Gehlot and Pilot- but also ensure caste representation. Hemaram Chaudhary, Mahendrajeet Singh Malviya and Harish Chaudhary are said to belong to the camp of Gehlot while Master Bhawarlal Meghwal and Deependra Singh Shekhawat are said to be in the anti-Gehlot camp.

While Hemaram Chaudhary and Harish Chaudhary are from the Jat community, Malviya is a firebrand tribal leader from south Rajasthan. Deependra Singh Shekhawat belongs to the Rajput community while Meghwal represents dominant scheduled castes.

Title: Shimoga man rescued at Calangute beach
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Calangute: Lifeguards on Sunday rescued a Karnataka tourist from drowning at Calangute beach. Drishti said its lifeguards spotted Sridhara Tipseshappa, 20, from Shimoga, who was having a dip, move into deeper water and warned him to return to a shallower area. Sea conditions were rough due to changing tides.

However, after the lifeguards’ vehicle moved on, Tipeshappa again moved into deeper waters and was dragged into the sea. A lifeguard spotted him struggling and rushed to his aid and brought him to shore. Since he was unconscious and his pulse weak, he was given CPR and oxygen, and shifted to the North Goa district hospital, Mapusa. tnn

Title: Students seek ‘azaadi’ from new citizenship laws at Dharna Chowk
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Students and activists participate in a protest against implementation of the Act

HYDERABAD: Slogans of ‘azaadi’ resonated at Dharna Chowk on Monday where hundreds of students from various educational institutions participated in a massive public meeting against CAA and NRC.

Organised by the Young India Coordination Committee, students joined protests supporting protesters in Shaheen Bagh and Jamia Millia Islamia in Delhi, who have been on a sit-in protest against the CAA for the past one month. “Women protesting at Shaheen Bagh have set an example for the entire country. Their peaceful protest has made a huge impact,” said Mohammed Abbas , a student.

The protest had support from student unions of Maulana Azad National Urdu University, English and Foreign Languages University and other independent student bodies such as Students Federation of India, National Students Union of India and others. During the three-hour protest, people raised anti-government slogans and waved the Tricolour.

The protest was attended by actor Prakash Raj, who said the country instead needs a register of unemployed and uneducated people. “If they (BJP) want to make a register, they should make a register of the unemployed and those who could not secure education,” said Raj. Taking a dig at PM Narendra Modi’s ‘Pariksha pe Charcha’ event held on Monday, he said people who don’t have a degree are seeking our documents and holding Pariksha pe Charcha,” said Raj.

Title: Silent protest foiled, actor Prakash Raj turned away
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Prakash Raj

HYDERABAD: A silent protest organised by students of Government Nizamia Tibbi College (Unani) was foiled by police on Monday. The silent gathering against CAA was scheduled between 5 pm and 8 pm, but the programme was stopped within an hour and the students were told to leave.

Meanwhile, activist and actor Prakash Raj who was to address the students, was turned away from Nayapul and several students were reportedly barred from entering the premises even after showing their identity cards. The students have been holding silent protests at the college for a fortnight now. “I was turned away from the college gate. The cops asked me who I was and why I wanted to get into the college. When I said I am a doctor and showed my ID card, I was told this is not college time and that I should go back,” said Sheik Mohammed , a final year student.

Students said that policemen were deployed at the college from 12.30 pm onwards and had created an intimidating atmosphere. “About 30 cops were on the campus by 12.30 pm and were stationed there throughout the day. We were holding a peaceful gathering. As soon as some of the student leaders went near the mike, the cops threatened us to disperse saying that it is a public meeting and they will take action against us. The students were forced to leave the gathering mid-way. Police presence in the college is intimidating and undemocratic. It feels like we are in a dictatorship,” said Zubair Alam , another student.

Even parents who had wanted to join the protest were told to go back from outside the gate. “While we were expecting atleast 500 people to participate, hardly 150 students could enter. Even then we could not have a peaceful gathering. We are scared,” said Arafat Raza, a final year student.

Content:
