Title: Fund crunch leads to unclean MSRTC buses, premises
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

As the windows of AC buses are completely closed, the commuters tend to spit in the corners of the seats and t... Read More

NASHIK: The mechanised cleanliness system started in Nashik division in the year 2017 for Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation ( MSRTC ) buses and premises has now fizzled out as the organization does not have money to pay for the job.

All MSRTC buses in the division bore an unclean look as the onus of cleaning s on the state transport utility staff which the number of which is already lower than the required manpower.

“Shivshahi air-conditioned luxury buses looked attractive but today things have changed. Not only the external appearance of the bus has been damaged, but from inside as well the buses are not being kept tidy,” Vinita Chowgule, a frequent traveller between Nashik and Pune, said.

As the windows of AC buses are completely closed, the commuters tend to spit in the corners of the seats and this is affecting travelling by the MSRTC buses.

“The MSRTC though is not primarily to be blamed for the situation inside the buses as it is also the passengers job to maintain hygiene and cleanliness,” Nagesh Raut, another commuter, said.

The situation at the bus terminals is no different as blacks spots have started appearing in pockets. At this point in time Swachh Sarvekshan is being carried out in the city and all the government agencies have been asked to ensure the premises are kept clean.

The MSRTC, however, finds itself struggling to maintain the standards it has set when the mechanized cleaning of the platform was being carried out.

“Just a month ago we could see mechanized cleaning being carried out but all of them are now gone,” Ajiz Shaikh, resident of Wadala Naka, said.

A MSRTC official admitted that there were some issues over payment to the contractor for the cleaning job.

A senior MSRTC official said that the cleanliness contract was allocated centrally to a company which was responsible for washing the buses, platforms and MSRTC premises.

“Nashik division is facing financial crunch and we are unable to foot the cleaning bill to the contractor. Therefore, the contractor has stopped functioning from December-end,” the official said.

Title: Yediyurappa goes sightseeing in Davos
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bengaluru: Braving the biting cold, chief minister BS Yediyurappa took time out of his busy schedule to go around Davos on Monday.

Clad in a long coat over a suit, scarf and leather gloves, Yediyurappa, with secretary S Selvakumar in tow, took in the sights of well-laid bylanes, quaint houses and snow-covered pine trees. He also rode a cable car at Persenn.

A cook from Andhra Pradesh, who works at an Indian restaurant in Davos, served the CM shavige uppittu and khara pongal for breakfast. Yediyurappa had chapatis and rice for dinner.

Meanwhile, Karnataka is likely to have a ‘ Centre for Internet of Ethical Things ’, perhaps, the world’s first, which will seek to ensure ethical practices in trade and businesses, besides addressing issues like misuse of artificial intelligence, a concern that has been bothering business leaders across the globe.

At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Yediyurappa signed an informal agreement with Murat Sonmez, the forum’s managing director, on Monday. "Investors around the globe are worried about unethical practices in business and a centre is the need of the hour," Sonmez was quoted as saying in a press release. "If the Karnataka government is serious about securing investment, it should set up the centre immediately."

Yediyurappa immediately responded to the suggestion by prompting Sonmez to write down an informal agreement on a sheet of paper which both signed. "This centre will go a long way in Karnataka’s history of industrial development," Sonmez was quoted as saying in a release by the Karnataka delegation.

At the inauguration of Karnataka’s pavilion, Yediyurappa promised all support to investors. "We are happy to be here and look forward to engage you on various development agenda," he said adding that he was keen to partner on certain strategic research that can help Karnataka become a major player on the global stage. "With Karnataka emerging as a leading industrial state in India, we can make it a major player on the global stage," he said.

Industries minister Jagadish Shettar , chief secretary TM Vijaya Bhasker and industries secretary Ramana Reddy were also signatories to the informal agreement.

Title: Docs beauty pageant: 3 from city stamp class
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nagpur: It was raining titles for city doctors at the ‘Mrs Maharashtra Mediqueen’ beauty pageant held in Pune recently. Ayurvedic doctor Komal Gorale Kashikar won the ‘Mrs Determined’ title while dermatologist Dr Pooja Dharmik was crowned ‘Mrs Photogenic’ and gynaecologist Dr Nidhi Adhao was bestowed with ‘Mrs Ambitious’ award.

The theme of the beauty pageant was ‘Anandi Urja’ (women’s health). Organized by Urja Healthcare, the first-ever beauty contest for woman doctors saw 265 contestants going through three rounds viz ramp walk, introduction and talent show. Of them 65 made it to the grand finale.

“It’s a surreal feeling to bag the beauty title. It’s an opportunity for doctors like us to showcase our talent and get acknowledged for it,” said Kashikar, who presented ‘inhuman crime of rape’ through a captivating dance in the talent round.

Young gynaecologist and mother of two Dr Adhao bagged the ‘Mrs Ambitious’ crown in child-bearing age-group.

‘Mrs Photogenic’ winner Dr Pooja Dharmik said, “I feel extremely happy as well as flattered. I am thankful to all the experts who groomed us well and gave us a chance to celebrate our beauty.”

The grand finale of the pageant was held in two rounds spread over three days. Other titles presented in the final round were ‘best interview’, ‘best presentation’, ‘best outfit in western, Indo-Western, traditional saree and evening gown’.

The contestants were groomed by a panel of experts before every round. The criteria of judgement were introduction, beauty, presence of mind, talent, confidence, presentation, etc. The winners are expected to work for the whole year on women’s health theme.

Directed by Dr Manisha Garud, the event was hosted by Dr Prerana Kalekar. Dr Ritu Lokhande was the styling expert while show coordinator was Dr Jyoti Mate.

Title: ‘People not yet paid for land given for NH 66 expansion at Colvale’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Panaji: The state government has failed to compensate all land owners whose land has been acquired by National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) for expansion of NH 66 at Colvale, Congress said here on Monday. The party also sought an inquiry into the quality of the highway construction, being done by M Venkata Rao Infra Pvt Ltd (MVR).

The party has served the government an eight-day ultimatum, threatening to launch an agitation if no action is taken.

“People should not be made to repeatedly go to government offices with all their documents looking for relief. There were shops, stores and hotels, with permissions from all departments. They paid fees for excise licences, panchayat permissions and trade licenses. Now, after their land has been taken, people have nothing. Who will compensate them?” Congress spokesperson Amarnath Panjikar said.

Congress claims to have found three cases where original land owners, or those with businesses, had not been compensated for their losses. One of these, Colvale-based Ramesh Salkar, claimed his entire liquor store was demolished without prior warning and that he is yet to receive any compensation.

Congress also alleged that MVR is not adhering to safety norms. “MVR is doing sub-standard work. Many have met with accidents and many have lost their land or homes because of the work. The PWD must check and ensure that work is streamlined and improved. Lights, signages and safety measures must be put in place,” Panjikar said.

Title: Is Jaleb Chowk next JLF venue or hotel?
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Jaipur: With the organisers of Jaipur Literature Festival scouring the city for a new “home” from next year, Jalebi Chowk, hotel Clarks Amer, and JECC have come up as options. At an interactive session on Monday, Sanjoy Roy, managing director of Teamwork Arts, which organizes the event, said while JECC just cannot be an alternative given the character of the literary extravaganza, they have been suggested to look at Jalebi Chowk.

“Jelebi Chowk has come as suggestion,” he said attributing the offer to a senior official in the government but Roy is also weighing on options like hotel Clarks Amer, which currently hosts the evening music shows of the festival. “We have not finalized the venue as yet but looking at various options,” Roy said at the sideline of the event.

Senior officials at tourism department said while Jalebi Chowk cannot replace Diggi Palace, it can give some heritage look and feel but the road traffic could be an area of concern.

“If they can use the Ram Niwas Bagh parking lot having capacity for 500 vehicles, and run a shuttle service for a distance of about 2 km to Jalebi Chowk, the festival will retain the heritage quotient that it thrives on. The shuttle service can also allow visitors to see and enjoy the heritage of the Walled City area,” said the official.

Speaking on this year’s festival that starts from January 23, Roy said the economic slowdown made it difficult for them to organize the event. “At one point we thought of skipping the event this year,” Roy said highlighting how they tried hard to find sponsors. One should not be surprised if they come across signs of austerity.

Roy also talked about the impact of JLF on the tourism in the city. He said about 4 years ago, they had conducted a study to assess how much the city benefits from the visiting delegates and participants to the festival.

“We found that delegates and participants had spent about Rs 50 crore during the days of the festival. They used hotel rooms, bought jewellery, textiles, carpets, handicrafts, etc. Today, the figure could be more than double, more than Rs 100 crore,” added Roy.

Keeping in view the issues of security, traffic and concerns of the local people, the government and the organisers of JLF have decided to shift the festival from Diggi Palace to a new venue from next year.

Title: Madras high court raps Vijayakanth for wasting its time with frivolous pleas
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Censuring DMDK founder Vijayakanth for wasting the court’s time by filing unnecessary appeals seven years ago, the Madras high court dismissed as withdrawn one such appeal moved by him challenging refusal to quash criminal defamation complaints made by AIADMK government in 2011.

“Filing of such petitions and appeals unnecessarily consumes the time of the court and care should be taken in the preparation, drafting and presentation of such petitions and should not be brought forth unless there is any constitutional question, keeping in view of the nature of allegations that have been made. We hope and trust that such care shall be taken in future,” the first bench of Chief Justice A P Sahi and Justice Subramonium Prasad said on Monday.

The bench also informed the counsel for Vijayakanth that they are refraining from imposing cost as he had volunteered to withdraw the appeal. The criminal defamations were filed by the then AIADMK government led by former chief minister J Jayalalithaa against Vijayakanth when he was the opposition leader of the Tamil Nadu state assembly.

Vijayakanth moved the high court in 2012 seeking to quash all such proceedings pending before the subordinate court. However, the same was dismissed by a single judge in the admission stage itself. Aggrieved, the petitioner moved the present appeal. In his affidavit, Vijayakanth submitted that his plea challenging the validity of Sections 500 and 501 (criminal defamation) was pending before a constitutional bench of the Supreme Court.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Denied BJP ticket, two former MLAs back in Congress
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bhisham Sharma (Photo taken from his verified Facebook account)

NEW DELHI: Former MLAs Amrish Singh Gautam and Bhisham Sharma returned to Congress on Monday after they were denied a ticket by BJP.

Title: JP Nadda’s elevation could be good news for Karnataka CM BS Yediyurappa
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

BS Yediyurappa

BENGALURU: For chief minister BS Yediyurappa , the BJP’s decision to hand JP Nadda a bigger role on the national stage is nothing short of a blessing in disguise.

Several senior party leaders are of the view that Nadda’s elevation as BJP national president will help Yediyurappa expedite the process of expanding his cabinet, which has been pending for more than a month now.

“Outgoing president Amit Shah was a busy man, handling dual responsibility of being party chief and Union home minister. So it was always hard for state leaders to get his time. Now, with Nadda taking over, it won’t be an issue,” a senior BJP functionary said.

Many feel Nadda’s good working relationship with the CM will alter equations in state politics and that he would take a decisive role in expanding Yediyurappa’s cabinet. He had played a crucial role in the formation of the BJP government in the state and had strongly backed Yediyurappa then. “Yediyurappa is leader of BJP’s Legislature Party and it is natural for him to be the party's choice for the chief minister’s post,” Nadda had said.

Nada’s elevation also opens up new possibilities for the state unit as he is known for his organisation skills. Top functionaries say he may frequent the state to ensure the state unit under Nalin Kumar Kateel takes up new programmes to strengthen the party.

Nadda also enjoys close ties with the Sangh Parivar and ABVP. “Our new president rose from the ranks of ABVP and so we expect to get more prominence,” said BJP spokesperson and former ABVP leader Anand AH.

However, some political analyst feel the change of guard will have no significant impact. “It makes no difference as the levers of control in the party will remain with the PM and home minister. While formal transfer of leadership in the party has happened, the de facto head for decision making will still be the ‘Big Two’,” said Sandeep Shashtri, a political analyst.

Title: Maharashtra: Class XII board examination hall tickets available online
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Students taking the Standard XII board examination in February-March will be able to access their hall tickets online from Tuesday, said an official notification from the Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education.

The colleges can access and download the hall tickets using official college login and password from the official website www.mahahsscboard.in. The notification said if the colleges were unable to access the hall tickets for any technical reasons, they could contact the respective divisional boards for grievance redressal.

“It is the college’s responsibility to download the hall tickets and give printouts to the students free of cost after getting the required stamp or signature of the principal. If the school finds any fault in the subjects or the medium of examination printed in the hall ticket of any student, it is their responsibility to get it corrected with the divisional board and issue the student the rectified hall ticket,” said the notification.

If a student misplaces or loses his or her hall ticket, he or she should be issued a new print of the hall ticket with the word “duplicate” written in red.

Title: Pariksha Pe Charcha has students glued to screens
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

PM Narendra Modi

CHENNAI: “We completed all our homework and lessons on time because we were thrilled and excited to listen to Prime Minister Narendra Modi,” said P R Divyashree, a Class IX student at Government Girls Higher Secondary School , Ashok Nagar.

Divyashree, along with her classmates and 600 other children, assembled inside their school auditorium at 11am and were listening keenly to Modi’s interaction programme Pariksha Pe Charcha 2020 with students from across the country and abroad, when he discussed with them ways to overcome and beat exam stress .

“There was pin drop silence in the room, for a change,” said P Mallika, assistant headmistress of the school.

Since the PM addressed the students in Hindi, a Hindi teacher was put on standby to translate everything he said to Tamil.

“The students were listening to him with such earnestness, I don’t think they needed any translation. They were responding to almost everything he said, even when most don’t know the language,” said Jeeva Rani, teacher at the T Nagar government school for girls.

Modi urged students to value time and learn to balance academics and extracurricular activities. He also said though they need decent marks and grades, it was important that they focus on other aspects of life and improve their personalities. The students cheered for the last statement.

But their takeaway was when he told them to use technology judiciously and not use it while spending time with families.

“We keep telling them this all the time, but they all nodded in agreement when the Prime Minister said it,” said Hemalatha Sivan, English teacher from Ashok Nagar government school.

A few students from the school had even registered to get a chance to hear the PM in person, but couldn’t make it. But that doesn’t seem to have broken their spirit. “We’ll apply again next year and I’m sure I’ll get to meet him then,” said P M Sandhya, a Class IX student. She had also prepared questions to ask him. “I want to know the rapport he shared with his teachers and what inspired him to serve our country. It was a great experience to hear him,” she said.

Title: Muslim MLAs seek resolution against CAA in assembly
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Jaipur: Muslim MLAs have asked CM Ashok Gehlot to bring a resolution against the CAA in the state assembly following pressure from protesters.

MLA Shafia Zubair from Ramgarh (Alwar), Wajib Ali from Nagar (Bharatpur), Amin Kagzi from Kishenpole (Jaipur) and Zahida Khan from Kaman (Bharatpur) have urged Gehlot to take a stand similar to Punjab and Kerala governments against the Act.

The latest to demand a resolution is Kagzi who shot a letter to Gehlot on Monday demanding a resolution against the CAA during the assembly session starting from January 24.

“I have apprised the CM about the sentiments of people from diverse faiths on the nefarious designs of the central government to divide the country. I have urged the CM to take a strong institutional stand against the CAA through the state assembly,” said Kagzi.

Kerala and Punjab have already announced to bring a resolution in their respective assemblies. First-time MLA Shafia Zubair feels that Rajasthan, which is on the fore fighting the fascist forces, should have taken the lead against the attack on the Constitution. “Gehlot has been upholding the ethos and values of the Mahatma Gandhi, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and BR Ambedkar. Needless to say that CAA, NPR or NRC will ever see the light of the day in Rajasthan,” said Zubair.

Ali, a graduate from Australia, was the first to pitch for the resolution in the assembly. A vocal critic of CAA, he has held protests in Melbourne a couple of weeks ago had asked the CM last week to protect the tarnishing of the Constitution by the fascist regime. “I would love to see Rajasthan leading the anti-CAA front,” said Ali, who was elected on a BSP ticket and merged with five other BSP MLAs into the Congress in Septemer 2019. MLA from Kaman (Bharatpur) Zahida Khan went to the extent of writing to Congress acting president Sonia Gandhi to ask all Congress and Congress allied ruled states to have a debate on the CAA and bring a resolution against it.

The state has eight Muslim MLAs in the assembly. They are all from the Congress, while the previous BJP regime led by Vasundhara Raje rule (2013-2018) had two Muslim MLAs from the saffron party. Interestingly, Congress MLAs have been toeing the party line on CAA but none other than the Muslim lawmakers of the party has demanded a resolution.

Title: Cobra rescued from parking lot
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hyderabad: A cobra was rescued from the parking lot of a jewellery store, PMJ Jewels, in Himayatnagar on Monday. The incident came to light after a customer, who was parking his vehicle in the store’s parking lot, spotted the snake and informed the staff of the store.

Soudharm Bhandari of Greater Hyderabad Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (GHSPCA), who rescued the snake, said, “The snake was hiding behind the electrical junction. It took me about 20 minutes to rescue it.” The snake, around 4 feet long, sustained a few minor injuries and was provided first aid. “We shifted the snake to our shelter. It will be released into its habitat after two days,” he added. tnn

Title: Caution, glitches ahead: Faulty FASTags take toll on commuters
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Several commuters on Monday complained that they were being forced to make cash transactions because their FASTags were not read by sensors at toll plazas. This is against a National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) notification which states that if the electronic toll mechanism fails to register the tag, the trip must be free.

FASTags were made mandatory from January 15. As per NHAI notification in 2018, vehicles are allowed to travel toll-free if machines fail to scan the tags. The notification states that if a person has a valid, functional FASTag with sufficient balance and is not able to pay user fee owing to malfunctioning of electronic toll collection infrastructure, then “the vehicle user shall be permitted to pass the fee plaza without payment of any user fee”.

Bala Vittal, who was returning to Hyderabad from Vijayawada, said, “The machine did not read the tag. After repeated attempts, I was asked to pay cash.” Vittal added he was unaware of the notification.

Kiran Babu, who was heading to Vijayawada, said he was made to move his vehicle back and forth so that the sensor could read the tag. “When the machine failed, I was asked to pay cash. When I refused they used the manual scanner which read the tag.”

Nishikant Panda, a resident of Bowenpally, who was travelling from Jhansi to Hyderabad, said, “At a toll plaza in Madhya Pradesh, the sensor didn’t read the tag and I paid by cash. Later, I got a message that the amount was deducted from my FASTag as well.”

Title: February 25 deadline for SSC students to opt for fine art subjects
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Maharashtra State Board of Secondary & Higher Secondary Education (MSBSHSE) has extended the date for schools to submit the list of students appearing for Class X board examinations who have opted for classical art, painting and folk art.

Class X students are supposed to submit the details regarding their subjects to their respective schools by February 15, instead of the earlier date of January 15. A circular issued by the board said all students who are appearing for SSC examinations this year must complete the formalities and submit the formal applications to their respective schools.

The students who opt for classical art, painting and folk art get extra marks from the board, as it happens with students of sports quota. The deadline will not be extended further. Students will not be able to submit their choice in the optional subject of fine arts after the stipulated date, stated the circular.

The circular was released for all the students, parents, teachers and school headmasters.

“No student should remain deprived of the provision of extra marks which they can earn by showcasing their talent in the field of fine arts,” the circular stated.

All the schools in Nashik division are directed to submit the list to the divisional office latest by February 25. The SSC Board examinations are to begin from March 3 and will go on till March 23 this year. There are a total of 2,721 schools in the division, where a total of 2,16,375 students (regular as well as repeaters) will sit for the examination this year.

Title: Schools step in as kids forget the art of reading clocks
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

CHENNAI: As digital devices have made their way into homes and schools, children seem to be slowly forgetting the art of reading a clock. Several educators say they notice that a lot of children, including those in senior classes, have no idea about reading a clock or are struggling to do so.

Educators and psychologists pointed out that knowing to read an ‘ analogue ’ is a basic mathematical life skill and lack of this knowledge is concerning.

“By observing the minute and hour hands, children learn about passing of time and its value. It is a life skill that numbers that pop on digital screens do not provide,” Ganga Natarajan, principal of SAN Academy said. She recalled an incident where she saw a few 12 and 13-year-olds struggling to read the clock. “Because they are so accustomed to using a digital watch , they have little or no idea about the little hands and big hands in a clock. They feel it does not make any big difference, but it actually does,” she said.

The school now insists all students wear an analogue wrist watch and discourages the use of digital ones. And they are not alone.

At Vidya Mandir, a teacher found that a few students had trouble understanding the time left during exams as they struggled to read the analouge wall clock. “We have no digital clocks on campus, especially not in the exam hall, as a rule because it will help children have a spatial plan of time and complete accordingly,” said Shobha Raman, principal of Vidya Mandir.

T Gowri, parent of a 15-year-old, complained that she had to remove all analogue clocks from her house and replace it with digital ones since her son had difficulty reading time. “I even told this to the teacher but they paid no heed. They said my child does know to read the clock because everyone is taught the concept in primary school,” she said.

“But children will only learn to read clocks if they see it everyday. It should be practised,” said Revathy Parameswaran, principal of PS Senior Secondary school. Here, there are no rules against wearing digital or analogue watches. “We want our children to be exposed to both concepts. But at the same time, we teach them the importance and benefits of analouge watches ,” she said.

Neuropsychologist Dr B S Virudhagirinathan added that it lays the basic foundation of numerical learning such as differentiating ‘big’ from ‘small’, ‘less’ from ‘more’. “Since the clock shows time in multiples of five, children will learn numbers and fractions, which will sharpen their minds and improve developmental skills. It is crucial that teachers teach them well to read clocks.”

Title: Consumers ask Maharashtra for power tariff relief
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Power consumers and representatives of consumer forums have decried the MSEDCL’s proposal to increase the power tariff stating that rather than putting in place efficient mechanism to collect the dues from defaulters, the state electricity board was trying to recover the revenue gap from consumers.

“Currently, the new state government is reconsidering the projects undertaken by the previous government. It should also reconsider the power tariff hike proposed by the Maharashtra Electricity Distribution Company Limited and also the decisions taken by the previous government in the power sector,” said Prataprao Hogade, a member of the forum of power consumers.

The previous government had assured the power consumers that the hike in power tariff would be slightly reduced but the MSEDCL did not budge from its decision. “This government should consider all the steps it can take to reduce the burden of higher power tariff on residential, agricultural and commercial consumers,” said Vilas Deole, another consumer activist from Nashik .

Proposing the increase in tariff— both in fixed charge and the tariff per unit—in the multi-year tariff proposal presented before the Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC), the MSEDCL has claimed that the hike was in the range of 1-5%. However, consumer outfits claim that the MSEDCL’s proposal would take the power tariff up by 20% from the very first year.

There are several factors that need to be taken into consideration when it comes to the power tariff hike, as what appears to be a marginal rise is likely to have a huge impact in the long run.

“Take for instance, the average cost of supply (ACOS) is currently pegged at Rs 6.73 per unit. The MSEDCL expects it to grow to Rs 7.24 per unit in the 2020-21 fiscal and then to Rs 8.10 per unit in the 2024-25 fiscal,” said Siddharth Varma, a former representative of the forum of power consumers from Nashik at MERC.

Despite the Central government taking steps towards cleaner energy and proposing solar energy, the MSEDCL appeared to be neglecting the contribution of green energy and hence the rise in ACOS, said representatives adding that this would take the power tariff up by 12-35% for all consumers.

The consumer associations have called upon all consumers to write to the MERC against the proposed power tariff hike. MERC is going to conduct a hearing on the proposal presented by the MSEDCL.

Title: Mormugao MLA, MMC VC argument goes viral
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Vasco/Panaji: A recording of a telephonic argument between Mormugao Municipal Council (MMC) vice chairperson Reema Sonurlekar and urban development minister Milind Naik over the delegating of labourers to Naik’s home, went viral on social media on Monday.

In the audio clip, Naik is heard arguing, threatening and later apologising to Sonurlekar.

Sonurlekar and Naik, both members of the BJP, have denied leaking the clip on social media. Sonurlekar is part of the panel backed by Vasco MLA Carlos Alemida and Naik's panel is on the opposition, within the MMC. The power play between the two BJP factions has caused disturbances in the functioning of the council, say sources.

In the clip, Naik demands that Sonurlekar depute labourers to his home and is repeatedly heard stating that he is a minister and is thus entitled to seek workers from the council. Sonurlekar informs Naik about a staff shortage and the need for workers in other wards, and later offers to send four workers, to which Naik replies, “That is not my problem...” Stating that he should get as many labourers as he wants for the next six months, Naik warns her of “party-level problems”, to which she challenges him to “do what he wants”. Towards the end of the clip, Naik is heard apologising and requesting Sonurlekar not to object when the chief officer deputes labourers to his constituency. "I had called her only to speak about labourers. She is a councillor, she cannot stop them," Naik told the media. Sonurlekar said, “MMC is short-staffed, the minister should understand this”.

“CM Sawant should take action against Naik,” said youth Congress president Varad Mardolkar, accusing Naik of disrespecting women.

Title: Former GAIL employee gets 5-yr RI in bribe case
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Dehradun: A special CBI court in Dehradun on Monday awarded five years’ rigorous imprisonment and also imposed a fine of Rs 25,000 on a former contractual employee of Gas Authority of India Limited ( GAIL ) in a bribe case.

The convict, Shashikant Pandey, who was working as a ‘chainman’ at the Rudrapur office of GAIL, had demanded Rs 20,000 bribe from a person for disbursing the cheque of compensation against the acquisition of his land by GAIL for laying gas pipeline.

The court of special CBI judge Sujata Singh found Shashikant Pandey guilty under section 8 of Prevention of Corruption Act and sentenced him to five years of rigorous imprisonment.

“Acting on the complaint of CBI, the convict was caught red-handed while accepting the bribe amount from the complainant on May 27, 2013,” said Abhishek Arora, prosecution lawyer.

Title: Carcass of leopard found in plastic bag in US Nagar
Content: Rudrapur: In a shocking incident, carcass of a sub-adult leopard was found packed in a plastic bag in a village under Terai forest in Udham Singh Nagar district on Sunday. It is suspected that the big cat was poisoned elsewhere by local residents as the region has recently witnessed cases of leopard attacks and its carcass was later dumped here.According to the forest officials, the leopard was a male, about two years old, and it is suspected that the big cat was either poisoned or was electrocuted due to illegal electric fencing around private farms in the region.Himanshu Bagri, divisional forest officer, western Terai region, said, “As the carcass was putrefied, the autopsy could not ascertain the exact cause of death. We have now sent the food consumed by the leopard, its liver, kidneys and viscera to the Forensic Science Laboratory in Bareilly for further examination.”Forest officials have ruled out poaching as the big cat was not fully grown and all its body parts – the teeth, claws and hide – are intact.“It seems that the leopard was fed poison-laced animal used as a bait by the villagers as there have been cases in the area where leopards have killed cattle and dogs of the farmers. The carcass packed in a plastic bag clearly indicates that the leopard was killed somewhere else and lately dumped here,” the DFO said.The forest officials have also filed a complaint against unidentified people under section 51 of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972.In October 2019, three 'maneater' leopards were killed in Uttarakhand. One of them was killed by hunter Azhar Khand who works with a team of hunters led by Joy Hukil in Pauri Garhwal district. Joy had himself killed the other two ‘maneater’ leopards -- one in Pithoragarh on October 5 and other other in Pauri on October 30.Before that, four leopards were found dead on August 2 at the Rajaji Tiger Reserve and the Shivalik Forest Circle in Uttarakhand. The carcass of three leopards were found within one kilometre from the reserve. Two of the leopards found dead were females and one was male.According to a report by the Wildlife Institute of India (WII), Uttarakhand is one of the worst state in terms of man-leopard conflict. According to a survey conducted in 2015, there are 706 leopards in the Himalayan state. Statistics suggests that nearly 300 humans have been killed in leopard attacks from 2000 till 2018. Particularly in Pauri, leopards killed an average of three persons and injured 11 people each year between 2006 and 2016.

Title: Two arrested for duping investors of Rs 10 crore
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Two persons who allegedly duped several investors after collecting Rs 10 crore with a promise of providing high returns were arrested by Central Crime Station (CCS) sleuths on Monday.

CCS officials said that Fiyaz Mehmood Ansari and Hamed Ali were nabbed on Sunday after receiving information.

Police said that Ansari, Ali and Mohammed Jahangir , another accused who has been absconding, started two companies Ansari Capital Solutions and Ansari Perfumes and Cosmetics and allegedly collected Rs 10 crore by inviting investors to invest in their business. However, the accused allegedly went absconding in September 2019. They were arrested on Monday and produced before a local court in Thane. Police have obtained a transit warrant to bring him back to Hyderabad.

Title: Issue due to less balance, improper tags
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

FASTags may not be read by machines at toll plazas for reasons such as insufficient balance, blacklisted or damaged tags, wrong positioning of the tag among others. A Krishna Prasad, regional officer, NHAI Hyderabad, said, that many times the user does not realise that there might be other problems with the tag at their end. Citing an example, he said that many tags are blacklisted. “We have found that several commercial vehicles used tags meant for cars, so that they could pay less toll fees. Such tags have been blacklisted and won’t be read.” tnn

Title: A bumpy ride: New buses to hit road after 3-month wait
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Dehradun: Around 150 public buses which were purchased by the Uttarakhand Transport Corporation (UTC) in November last year are finally preparing to hit the state’s roads by next month after they finish a 15-day road trial.

Soon after the buses were delivered in November 2019, several of them were reported to have glitches while they were being tested by UTC drivers. Subsequently, a Central Institute of Road Transport (CIRT) team was called in to inspect the buses. The team in its report termed the buses as “faulty and unfit for active transportation.” Consequently, the buses were returned to the manufacturing company who was asked to send back the buses after modifications.

The modified buses were received last week by the corporation. Speaking to TOI, Ranvir Singh Chauhan, managing director of UTC, said, “The modified buses have been reviewed by our qualified drivers. They are being tested on the road for 15 days and thereafter, if all reports are okay, they will be brought into service.” When queried if the modifications have been carried out by the manufacturer as per their satisfaction, the official added that a minor technical snag was reported in one of the modified buses but it was fixed within an hour.

The buses have several features like panic buttons, broader seats, and CCTV cameras to give passengers a better travel experience. They also have a GPS system and fire detection alarm. To recall, UTC had announced to purchase 300 new buses. Of these, around 150 buses were added to the UTC fleet in November 2019. Among these, 50 buses were for Dehradun depot, while the rest were for the Kumaon region.

Title: Manic Monday: Delhi marches to a halt
Content:
File photo of heavy traffic in Delhi

NEW DELHI: The arterial roads in central Delhi were choked on Monday afternoon owing to back-to-back roadshows, rallies and protest marches.While southeast Delhi is already under siege due to the closure of Kalindi Kunj road , traffic being diverted through Noida Link Road and DND Flyway was also stalled during peak hours. The worst impacted was Vikas Marg between 11am and 1pm.The snarls started around 1pm when supporters of Aam Aadmi Party gathered at Mandi House and Connaught Place Outer Circle for a protest march and a roadshow. Police shut one carriageway of Sikandra Road and a portion of Outer Circle from Minto Road for the rallies.As a result, traffic jams started building up on Sikandra Road, DDU Marg and Minto Road. The ripple effect of the jam reached ITO within an hour. Soon, police shut Outer Ring Road and Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg for VIP movement from Talkatora Stadium to the BJP office on DDU Marg.Since ITO crossing had to be closed for 15 minutes for the VIPs to pass, the snarl reached Vikas Marg and Noida Link Road even as police tried to clear the vehicles accumulated on the stretch. “I was stuck on Vikas Marg for nearly 40 minutes around 3pm before I could reach ITO for work,” said Devika Bhalla, a resident of Noida.Commuters tweeted about the snarls tagging the traffic police. Police said they had to control the traffic signals manually.A senior police officer said that the increase in volume of traffic from Noida added to the mess. According to an estimate, there has been a 20% increase in the number of vehicles that earlier used the south Delhi stretches to enter the city from Noida. As a result, nearly 40,000 vehicles are added to the existing volume at ITO, which is the busiest intersection in the city.With the Kalindi Kunj road closed, motorists take Noida Link Road during peak hours to reach central and south Delhi to avoid the snarls on DND Flyway and Barapullah road.Construction activities at crucial intersections like Ashram and Bhairon Marg add to the chaos.

Title: 16 mobiles worth Rs 2 lakh confiscated
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Teams of the Government Railway Police (GRP), Igatpuri, on Monday busted a three-member gang of mobile phone thieves that allegedly targeted passengers near doors of moving trains.

A total of 16 mobile phones worth Rs 2 lakh were recovered from the gang by the GRP teams, which had been tasked with the investigation following a spate of complaints registered at the police station here.

"A case of theft was registered at the Igatpuri GRP police station. The complainant alleged his mobile phone was stolen when he was sitting near the door of a coach," said Sudhir Patil, the assistant police inspector with the Igatpuri GRP. "So we kept a close eye on that specific part of the trains. And ultimately caught a suspect on January 15."

According to police officials, the suspect then named two others during interrogation. "Sixteen mobile phones were recovered by the police," Patil said.

On January 13 Dhindori resident Tushar Pawar filed a complaint that stated his phone was taken while he was traveling on the Tapovan Express from Nashik to Mumbai. Pawar alleged that he dropped the phone when someone hit his hand hard as the train approached Igatpuri station. He said that since it was dark, he was not able to spot the thief.

The police, as part of the investigation, deployed personnel in plainclothes on the train. On January 15, a policeman in plainclothes was holding his phone out of the window on purpose when someone knocked him on his hand.

“Someone hit his hand hard. And that's when we realised that the suspects hid behind poles. The cops immediately got out of the train and rushed to the spot. The accused had started to run, but we managed to apprehend one of them." Patil said.

All three suspects - Rahul Salve, 20; Lalit More, 22; and Vishal Atkari, 23 - are from Igatpuri taluka. The police said Salve already has six cases registered against him at the Igatpuri GRP police station.

Title: Mothers to prepare midday meal as workers go on strike today in Bengaluru
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

MYSURU: In a unique development, mothers of students studying in primary and high schools in the district will come together to prepare lunch for their children for two days, on Tuesday and Wednesday, as midday meal workers have decided to participate in a two-day protest in Bengaluru.

Midday meal workers have decided to hold a protest at Freedom Park in Bengaluru on January 21 and 22 demanding minimum wages, job security, provident fund and ESI, Rs 3,000 pension and Rs 2 lakh lump sum after retirement among other demands.

Karnataka State Midday Meal Workers Federation district convener K G Somaraje Urs said that the midday meal workers will leave their villages on Monday (January 20) and will reach Bengaluru by train.

“We will participate in the two-day protest. Midday meal workers will have to bring or arrange their own blanket to sleep and food for two days. They will not prepare food for two days,” Urs said.

There are 5,206 midday meal workers in the district – 752 in HD Kote, 727 in Hunsur , 591 in KR Nagar, 621 in Mysuru taluk , 363 in Mysuru City North, 182 in Mysuru City South, 758 in Nanjangud, 623 in Periyapatna and 589 workers in T Narasipura taluk who play a key role in ensuring nutrition and education to more than two lakh children.

Meanwhile, the department of public instruction, in order to avoid any problems, had requested the children’s mothers, who are members of the Mother’s Committee, to prepare food for the children in their respective schools in the villages.

As per the Central government guidelines, the education department is supposed to form a ‘Mother's Committee’ in all schools. This committee comprises only parents who are motivated to attend school and observe the preparation and serving of meals, so that children feel a homely atmosphere.

Deputy director for public instruction (DDPI) Panduranga told TOI that the mothers will prepare food for the children till the workers return to their work from the protest.

“After we came to know about the protest, we asked the committees and villagers to support the department in preparing lunch for the children. They have agreed and so there will be no problem for the midday meal for children in the district,” he said.

Title: Uttarakhand: Harish Rawat joins anganwadi protesters
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Congress leader Harish Rawat

DEHRADUN: The anganwadi workers, who have been protesting in Dehradun for nearly two months against low wages and other demands, were joined by former chief minister Harish Rawat on Monday.

The senior Congress leader joined agitators at city’s Dharna Sthal and sung songs along with them in protest. While the agitators appreciated his support, they added that their protest isn’t political in nature. “We respect his emotion but we would not like to say anything about political leaders showcasing their support. We are battling for our survival unlike them,” said Rekha Negi, president of anganwadi workers’ association.

At present, two anganwadi workers — Vidya Devi and Anju Chand — are sitting on hunger strike unto death to press for their demands.

Earlier, six anganwadi workers, who were sitting on a hunger strike, had been taken to Coronation Hospital by the police. The condition of three anganwadi workers among these six is worrisome, spokesperson of their association told TOI.

Title: Hostels, paying guests directed to install CCTVs
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Dehradun: Reacting to complaints regarding keeping a better check on students, police on Monday directed colleges, educational institutions, hostels and paying guest houses to install CCTVs in their premises.

Superintendent of police (SP) city Shweta Choubey chaired a meeting with the representatives of around 70 colleges, educational institutions, hostels and PG houses operating in Selaqui area of Dehradun. The area has in the past few years emerged as a major hub of higher education, where a large number of institutions and universities are located.

Speaking to TOI, Choubey said, “From the point of view of security, we have directed hostels, paying guest facilities, colleges and other institutions at Selaqui area to install CCTVs. They have been directed to enforce the decision at the earliest.”

Besides, the owners of student hostels and paying guest accommodation have been directed to share the database of students living in their properties with the concerned police stations. Police verification of the staff working in student hostels and paying guest houses has been made mandatory.

Police will also provide a copy of an advisory to the hostels and paying guest facilities, which they will be required to paste at their entry gates. Security staff at hostels have been instructed to ensure that no student brings in banned substances.

“Entry and exit register must be maintained by every hostel and paying guest facility,” Choubey said, adding that police have been receiving complaints regarding consumption of alcohol in these facilities which needs to be curbed by the property owners.

Title: Crop survey: Farmers told to file objections by January 30
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

MYSURU: The state government has asked all farmers of the district, who have joined the farmer crop survey mobile app and uploaded the details of their crop, to update their RTCs and file objections before January 30.

They are requested to file the objections through crop survey mobile app web application only. They can also file their objections by writing a letter to the nearest Raitha Samparka Kendra within the deadline.

The officials in charge of Raitha Samparka Kendra will file the objections on behalf of the farmers two days after receiving their written objections. The details of their objections they upload will be displayed on crop survey web application and it will be cleared within seven days by the concerned agriculture supervisors after conducting a survey.

An SMS alert will be sent to all the applied farmers after clearing their objections.

The state government has been conducting the GPS-enabled crop survey from 2017 through the mobile app.

The information fed through the application will help farmers in availing government benefits such as compensation and insurance

The government wants farmers to directly take part in the survey. The farmers must download the mobile application and enter the details of the crop. The details are to be uploaded through the app every year. Every crop is provided with a code and there are nearly 1,500 crop codes made available in the app. The crop details will be integrated with the e-platform Bhoomi and will be updated in column 12 of the RTC showing crop details.

Title: British Sikh student killed in street attack, 1 suspect nabbed
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

London: A 20-year-old Sikh student at Nottingham Trent University, who was assaulted on Saturday night in Nottingham city centre, England, succumbed to his injuries on Sunday. Nottinghamshire Police have now launched a murder investigation and suspect two people to be behind the crime.

“Police are trying to trace two men who fled the scene on foot,” a police spokesperson said. Police are questioning one person on suspicion of murder of Arjun Singh, who was rushed to the Queen’s Medical Centre following the attack, but died soon after.

“This was a serious assault which has resulted in a young man losing his life,” said detective inspector Richard Monk.

“Our thoughts are with Arjun’s family and friends and we would ask that people respect their privacy at this very sad and difficult time. We need to hear from anyone who may have dash-cam footage, including taxi drivers who were in the area of Long Row West and Angel Row at the time, or any mobile phone footage of the incident. It is really important that if anyone has any information, no matter how small it may be, they come forward immediately,” Monk added.

Pete Knowles, who delivers newspapers in the area, told a local newspaper that he saw an ambulance speed off as he was doing his delivery. “I saw someone on the floor, with a blue blanket over them. There were two ambulances that came and then police cars.”

Students of the Nottingham Trent University Sikh Society and the University of Nottingham Sikh Society, besides members of Sikh Youth UK and the GAD Gym at Guru Arjan Dev Ji Gurdwara Derby, are planning a vigil from 5pm on Wednesday at the spot where the attack happened.

The area was cordoned off all day on Sunday.

Title: Tank murder case: NRI booked for threatening eyewitness
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

ABOHAR: Police have booked a non-resident Indian (NRI) for allegedly threatening Gurjant Singh Janta , a prime eyewitness in the Bhim Tank murder case of Abohar whose statement had led to the life imprisonment of liquor baron Shiv Lal Doda and 24 others.

Bhim was hacked to death and his friend Gurjant was grievously injured by the henchmen of Doda at his farmhouse in Ramsara village near Abohar on December 11, 2015.

In his police complaint, Gurjant alleged that one Ankush Chalana, kin of a member of the core committee constituted by Doda when he contested the assembly elections as an independent candidate from Abohar constituency in 2017, threatened him in a post on a social media platform. Gurjant alleged that the post read: “Janta, tera time a gaya (time is up, Janta).” tnn

Fazilka senior superintendent of police (SSP) had earlier marked an inquiry into the matter to Abohar deputy superintendent of police (DSP) Rahul Bhardwaj. After investigating the matter, the DSP ordered the registration of a case against Ankush under Section 66 of the Information Technology (IT) Act, 2000, on Sunday.

Gurjant was the key eyewitness in the murder of Tank and had also sustained grievous multiple injuries during the attack. Janta has been provided police protection, keeping in view the threat to his life.

Title: 22-yr-old from Patiala among 3 Sikh men stabbed to death in London
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

London: Three Indian-origin Sikh men were knifed to death on the streets of Ilford in east London on Sunday evening in a drunken fight believed to be over unpaid work. Videos being circulated on social media show their bodies lying on the ground in large pools of blood, with personal belongings scattered around.

Emergency services were called to a “disturbance” in Elmstead Road, Seven Kings, a district of Ilford, at around 7.40pm. Police officers and London Ambulance Service attended and found three Sikh men, believed to be aged 22, 26 and 34, lying in different spots on the ground suffering from serious stab injuries.

A London Ambulance Service spokesperson said: “We were called at 7.37pm to reports of a stabbing outside Seven Kings station in Ilford. We sent three ambulances, three medics in response cars, two critical care paramedics, two incident response officers and our hazardous areas response team. We also dispatched London’s Air Ambulance.” But despite the best efforts of the medics, the three men were pronounced dead at the scene.

By Monday 9am the Metropolitan Police had arrested two Sikh men, one aged 29 and one aged 39, on suspicion of murder.

According to news reports in local media, one man was stabbed in the neck, shoulder and chest, while another had been smashed in the head with a hammer. The men are all believed to be Indian migrant workers who had only been in the UK a few years. They worked in the construction industry.

A local man, Mr Pali, said: “The argument was all over money for unpaid work. That happens a lot around here because we have a lot of immigrants from India who work as builders.”

The Daily Mail identified two of the victims as Narinder Singh, 26, a construction worker, and his best friend Harinder Kumar , 22, both of whom have relatives in India. Harinder was originally from Patiala in Punjab, and had been living in London for eight years, most recently in Seven Kings. His brother-in-law, who lives in Patiala, told Mirror Online: “Honey was a very simple and religious guy. He can’t get involved in any quarrel.”

A Metropolitan Police spokesman told TOI: “At this stage we believe all three victims and the two men arrested are Sikh and we believe they were all known to each other. We do not yet know if they are British or Indian citizens.”

Title: Bihar: Robbers loot Rs 13 lakh and gun from LIC office in Samastipur
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

SAMASTIPUR/PATNA: Unidentified criminals looted over Rs 23 lakh and snatched the licensed gun of a security guard in two separate incidents in Samastipur and Darbhanga district on Monday.

In the first incident, the criminals looted over Rs13 lakh and the security guard’s gun from the Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) of India office at Shahpur Patori in Samastipur district. In another incident, armed criminals looted Rs10 lakh from a customer service point incharge near Harauli under Kusheshwarsthan police station in Darbhanga district. SHO Manish Kumar said the incident took place around 4pm when the victim was returning to his office after withdrawing cash from a local bank. Raids were on to nab the culprits, who decamped with the looted money on their motorbikes.

The Samastipur incident took place around 1pm when the employees were busy in dealing with the customers. Police said over six criminals barged into the office and held the staff as well as the customers captive at gunpoint.

The robbers first snatched the gun from the security guard, Girish Deo Singh, after hitting him with revolver butts and then went to the branch manager Manoj Kumar’s chamber. They took the keys and collected Rs8.54 lakh from the locker and looted Rs4.69 lakh from the cash counter.

Locals said the robbers also snatched cash and mobile phones from a few customers before leaving with the booty. The victims told the police that the robbers had covered their faces with clothes and helmets.

Samastipur SP Vikas Burman along with additional SP and other police officers rushed to the spot. The SP later told the media that a special investigation team (SIT) has been set up to solve the case at the earliest. “The borders of the district have been sealed and search operation was launched to nab the robbers,” he added.

Locals told the police that the criminals escaped towards the railway crossing on their motorbikes. At least six persons, including branch manager Manoj Kumar, Santosh Kumar (employee), Girish Deo Singh (security guard), Manish Jha, Suresh Kumar and Anand Kumar (all agents) were injured in the incident.

Shahpur Patori SHO Mukesh Kumar said the injured were admitted to the subdivisional hospital where their condition was stated to be out of danger. “We are trying to ascertain the identity of the accused with the help of the CCTV footage,” he said. Meanwhile, the members of the SIT conducted raids in neighbouring Vaishali district in search of the accused late in the evening.

Title: Pune: PMC, police join forces for encroachment-free spaces
Content:
Hawker-free pavements along Fergusson College Road

PUNE: The civic anti-encroachment department and traffic police have joined forces to rid pavements of encroachments.Over the past fortnight, the authorities have been carrying out sustained drives in select areas to ensure encroachment-free pavements for pedestrians. The civic administration has identified 11 key roads for the drive, and told all ward offices to take action in their areas.“Earlier this month, we began taking action against encroachments on FC Road. We are following a focused approach — first clear encroachments from the roads and pavements and then station policemen to ensure that vendors do not return. We will replicate the model on other major roads in the city gradually,” additional commissioner of police Sanjay Shinde said.Officials from the traffic department said they were also utilizing their portal, PuneTrafWatch, to remove encroachments. “If we spot any encroachments — reported by citizens or otherwise — on PuneTrafWatch, the closest police personnel spot are immediately dispatched to evict the vendors. We are doing this across all the 11 major roads that have been identified for the drive,” one official said.The official added that they have also posted personnel on FC Road to ensure nobody double parks or stops their vehicle in front of Vaishali, a popular eatery. “This remains a no-parking zone,” the official said.Dattatray Langhe, regional encroachment inspector, Pune Municipal Corporation ’s anti-encroachment department, said they were gradually expanding the drive to outside the 11 roads. “Action is also being taken on smaller roads across the city. We are acting suo motu and also on complaints received from citizens,” Langhe further said.Langhe said the civic body has acted against over 1,200 encroachments/illegal constructions between January 6 and 12, and against 744 from January 13 to 17 across Pune. The structures removed include stalls, handcarts, hawkers, gas cylinders, sheds and vehicles.

Title: Apex court entertains plea challenging renaming of Allahabad as Prayagraj
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The Supreme Court on Monday entertained an appeal by NGO ‘ Allahabad Heritage Society ’ challenging the UP government’s October 18, 2018, decision to rename Allahabad as Prayagraj.

A bench of Chief Justice SA Bobde and Justices BR Gavai and Surya Kant sought the state government’s response to the appeal filed by the NGO, which has challenged Allahabad HC’s February 26, 2019, order dismissing its PIL against renaming the city. The petitioner said the Yogi government ignored settled norms for changing the name of a city and hurried through the process within five days of initiation of the proposal on October 13, 2018, without even conducting a survey to know the views of residents of the city.

Title: West Bengal: Fishing cat on CCTV spreads tiger panic
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The CCTV grab showing the fishing cat

KONNAGAR: A fishing cat caught on a CCTV camera on Monday at Kanaipur of Hooghly’s Konnagar sparked panic among the locals after they mistook it for a tiger. The footage was scanned by the security staff of a local grille factory.

The security guards of the factory, along Delhi Road, started their shift with a routine scan of the previous night’s CCTV footage on and around the premises. While doing so, they were stunned to discover a ‘tiger-like’ animal walking past a goods carrier parked outside the factory.

Soon, word about a “a tiger on the prowl” in the area spread. The panicked factory workers and locals started looking for the animal. The forest department, local panchayat office and Uttarpara police were informed. Panchayat pradhan Acchelal Yadav and Uttarpara IC Suprakash Patnaik arrived at the spot and appealed to the people to remain calm.

“We even sent out a team that went around Kanaipur with a microphone and urged the people not to panic,” said Yadav.

Munna Ray, a factory worker, said, “Earlier, we spotted pug marks on the fields in the area. Looking at the CCTV footage, we were absolutely sure that a tiger was roaming in the area.”

Chandernagore police commissioner Humayun Kabir said, “The forest department has been informed. The animal in the CCTV footage was a fishing cat, which is yet to be caught. We are trying to ensure that people don’t kill the animal.”

State forest minister Rajib Banerjee, too, confirmed that the animal was indeed a fishing cat and not a tiger.

Title: 10% property tax rebate for adopting eco-friendly processes
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) general body on Monday approved rebate of 10% in property tax for houses adopting at least two of four eco-friendly projects — producing compost by garbage segregation, rainwater harvesting, wastewater treatment and reuse, and producing solar or any type of renewable power. Also, approval has been given for 50% rebate in property tax where persons with disabilities reside.

NMC has become the first municipal corporation in the state to launch rebate for producing compost by garbage segregation, wastewater treatment and reuse, and persons with disabilities.

From April 1, 2015, NMC has been giving rebate of 5% for houses having solar power system or rainwater harvesting system. But the rebate is on general tax, one of the components in property tax. The rebate was very low and failed to encourage people to adopt eco-friendly projects.

Now, the civic body has changed the system and launched rebate system on entire property tax, excluding three components of state government, which are minimal in total property tax. Also, NMC has included producing compost by garbage segregation and wastewater treatment and reuse. The taxpayer will be eligible for 5% rebate for adopting only one of the four eco-friendly projects.

The civic body has miserably failed to encourage garbage segregation and reuse of wet waste at households itself, which led to this rebate offer.

Taxpayers can avail the rebate only if they pay property tax regularly. The taxpayer will have to declare eco-friendly projects, after which tax inspector or assistant engineer from zone will inspect and certify it every year.

A NMC official told TOI this will be implemented from fiscal 2020-21, which begins from April 1, 2020. “Demand notes for current fiscal have been distributed. Also, the department will have to change the format in the systems,” he said.

The decision to give 50% rebate in property tax for persons with disabilities will be submitted to the state government before implementation. The benefit will be given in case any one member of the family has certificate issued by civil surgeon.

Earlier, NMC had decided to give rebate to senior citizens. But in this case, the owner of the building should be a senior citizen.

The general body has also approved a proposal to establish a plant to treat 200 metric tonne (MT) mixed garbage at Bhandewadi dumping yard on DFBOOT basis. The private operator will be leased 4 acres to develop a plant at its cost, operate and maintain for 15 years.

Mayor Sandip Joshi said, “This plant will ensure scientific disposal of entire city’s mixed garbage. NMC has proposed various projects to reuse the segregated garbage. Plant will be closed down if 100% garbage segregation is achieved.”

The general body also approved the proposal to establish Plastic Waste to Fuel Plant to be developed by Pune-based Keshav-Sita Memorial Foundation Trust , under its corporate social responsibility (CSR) funds. NMC will lease 8,000 sq ft land and build a shed. The firm will operate and maintain the plant for 10 years and hand over entire project to NMC free of cost.

The general body also approved a proposal to set up a plant for treatment and reuse of 200 MT construction and demolition waste in 4 acres land at Bhandewadi dumping yard on DFBOOT model. The operator will develop, operate and maintain the project for 15 years.

Similarly, the general body cleared the proposal to develop Semi-Automatic Material Recovery Facility at Bhandewadi dumping yard with capacity of 200 MT, where dry waste will be disposed off in scientific manner. NMC will lease one acre land and operator will operate and maintain it for five years at its cost. Here, the operator will accept and pay for all types of dry waste, including paper, plastic and others.

Title: Sudden transfer of justice Haq ‘shocking’, lawyers protest
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nagpur: A week after Bombay high court chief justice (CJ) Pradeep Nandrajog transferred justice Zaka Haq from Nagpur to Aurangabad without assigning any reason, some lawyers have protested the move terming it “shocking”.

They’ve requisitioned the High Court Bar Association (HCBA) to immediately convene a meeting to condemn the development. The District Bar Association (DBA) too has supported the lawyers’ move.

According to them, its “injustice” to city judges. For the second time in recent past, they have been shifted out after passing several verdicts against the government and judicial officers. Earlier, justice (retired) Arun Chaudhari was transferred to the Punjab and Haryana High Court.

The HCBA office-bearers agreed to discuss the resolution moved by top lawyers which includes former advocate general Shreehari Aney, Mukesh Samarth, Shreerang Bhandarkar, Ravi Sanyal, Neeraj Khandewale and DBA president Kamal Satuja among others.

“A general body meeting has been convened at 1.45pm on Tuesday to discuss the resolution,” vice president Purushottam Patil told TOI.

On January 13, the CJ transferred justice NB Suryawanshi (from Mumbai) along with Haq. While Haq will have Aurangabad as his headquarters, for Suryawanshi it will be Nagpur. The new order comes into effect from February 1.

Bhandarkar and some others have called for a total boycott of working in courts. Senior counsel Aney felt that a boycott call would amount to interference in the judiciary. “Even though a resolution was mooted by the HCBA members, it can’t boycott the HC’s working, as it would amount to contempt. Bar can’t interfere in the justice administration, it’s impermissible. Such actions can lead to obstruction of the justice,” he said.

While recalling an earlier such instance, Aney said the HCBA had proposed a resolution against late justice Ashok Desai for boycotting his court. “As president in the 1990s, I withheld an objection to this resolution. The bar can’t stop court’s working because it is dissatisfied with its actions,” he said.

Adding that the CJ has every right to transfer judges, Aney said, “If the members are concerned that his transfer is affecting court’s functioning, they can protest, but can’t stop HC’s functioning.”

Aney also flayed former CJ’s decision to transfer high-profile cases like of Sophia Power Plant in Amravati and alleged naxal kingpin GS Saibaba’s petition to principal seat in Mumbai.

In their resolution, the protesting lawyers stated that justice Haq was an illustrious member of the bar and had an extensive practice in the Nagpur bench before being elevated as a judge. “With unfortunate news of his transfer, the HCBA apprehend that this region would lose one of the most honest, upright and principled judge. The transfer is affected when he’s retiring in May 2021. Rumours are that the transfer is on a complaint by some lawyers. If it’s true then, the action appears to have been taken on the basis of the false complaint which may be motivated, and without verifying the truth,” they said.

The members demanded that Haq continue to be in Nagpur bench and resolved that the HCBA committee would deliver a representation of all lawyers to CJ for withdrawing the transfer orders immediately.

Title: Special drive on for enrollment in government schools: Vijay Inder Singla
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

CHANDIGARH: Punjab education minister Vijay Inder Singla on Monday called for people’s participation in improvement of education.

Singla, in his keynote address at the Education World Forum in London , laid stress on responsibility of industrialists and appealed them to come forward for developing infrastructure of schools.

Highlighting Punjab education department’s initiative ‘Each One, Bring One’, he said the department had started a special enrollment drive for government schools to enhance enrollment at pre-primary level. He said 2.5 lakh students had been enrolled in pre-primary classes so far.

Title: Mumbai: Missing autistic boy traced in 24 hours
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Even as there is no word on the whereabouts of autistic teen Tarun Gupta over three months after he went missing from Colaba , his family could take hope from the fact that another autistic youngster missing from western suburbs was found within 24 hours.Trilok Kadam (12) had stepped out of his Borivli home with his football around 4.10pm on Sunday. By 10am on Monday, his parents received a phone call from Samta Nagar police station, Kandivli East, that he had been found with his football. It is a well-documented fact that children with autism have a tendency to wander. As Trilok does not speak, his family says they may never know how he landed four kilometres away, across a very busy Western Express Highway.Trilok’s family said they are happy and relieved that he is safe and unharmed. Trilok attends a school for children with special abilities and is always accompanied by his mother. On Sunday, she was unwell and taking rest when he took off the latch on the door and left home with his football. When he did not return, his family got worried and started to look for him. CCTV footage from the society showed him walking out around 4.12pm. Trilok was not wearing slippers and was not dressed for the cold at night.While his family registered a complaint with Borivli police, friends and relatives started a massive hunt for Trilok. They checked every corner of Borivli and posted Trilok’s photograph on social media and WhatsApp. The search parties only took a break at 3am before starting again at 4.30am as they knew Trilok would be hungry and might appear at food stalls that open early in the morning. By 10am, after having looked for Trilok for nearly 17 hours, the family received a call from Samta Nagar police. Police sent across his photo to his family to confirm. Apparently, locals had spotted Trilok wandering the streets in Kandivli East the previous day and had brought him to the police station.Samta Nagar police sent across a message to their counterparts at other police stations, including Borivli, where a search was already on for Trilok. “It appears the little boy walked down the stretch. He hasn’t suffered any injury and went home with his family around noon on Monday,” said a police officer.Tarun’s family has been waiting for news of him after he got separated from them on October 1, 2019. The family has offered Rs 2 lakh for any information on his whereabouts and has got 25 leads from Belapur, Virar, Thane, Sawantwadi and Pune, among others. On Sunday, at Tata Mumbai Marathon, posters and pamphlets were distributed by Tarun’s father and other parent-volunteers to highlight the search for the teen.

Title: As India opts out of RCEP ice creams set to get dearer by 8%
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Chennai: Come summer, and everyone looks forward to having their most favourite dessert — ice-cream. Kids and adults alike enjoy licking their shares as the mercury rises. However, this season you may have to shell out more for your favourite cone.

With the industry seeing a shortage in milk supply by 10%-15% and India opting out of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnerships (RCEP) — a proposed free trade agreement in the Asia-Pacific region between the ten member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and their five FTA partners — the availability of skimmed milk powder, a key ingredient in ice creams and dairy products, has dipped.

Opting out of the RCEP means fewer avenues for importing skimmed milk powder. The Indian Ice Cream Manufacturers Association (IICMA) says that coupled with low milk supply — caused by low availability of fodder, owing to irregular monsoons — and little room for imports, SMP prices have more than doubled from Rs 150/kg to Rs 330-Rs 360/kg.

Dealing with a shortage of the key ingredient, brands such as Amul, Vadilal, Mother Dairy are looking to increase the rates of ice creams by 5%-10% per unit or have already increased the prices. “This is potentially a dangerous situation and liquid milk prices have already been increased by dairies by 20% y-o-y and with summer coming up, as the supply falls, the prices are likely to see a Rs 5-Rs 8/per liter rise. SMP prices which are already hovering in the Rs 330+ range will further go up to Rs 360 or more. This will lead to retail prices of ice-cream and dairy products going up by 8%-10% — compared to last year,” said Rajesh Gandhi, president, IICMA. Gandhi, who is also the managing director of Vadilal Industries, says given the current price situation, by February, prices would be up by 5%-8% for their brand. “However, we cannot pass on the entire burden to the consumer. There will be a backlash and demand will drop,” he added.

Amul ice creams are costlier by 8% since the beginning of January 2020 and other milk products are up by 5%. RS Sodhi, managing director, Gujarat Co-operaitve Milk Marketing Federation says that the price increase is because of the rising prices of sugar, along with the skimmed milk powder.

The supply of milk has also dropped by 10%-15%, industry players add. Chennai-based Gho Agro is also looking to increase the prices of paneer and curd by 5%-8% following the short supply. “We are considering an increase of around 5% in the next month given the drop in milk supply and we have to keep our margins intact,” said Vimal Chordia, co-founder, Gho Agro. To manage the situation, the IICMA has proposed the creation of a buffer stock of 65,000 metric tonnes, through imports, which would be used to stabilise market to maintain /reduce prices within acceptable levels.

However, Amul’s MD Sodhi adds that there is no need to import and the shortage in supply is temporary.

“The flush season — the time of the year when the increase in milk supply commences - which generally starts after Diwali — has already started in December for this season. We are getting 60 lakh litres more milk than the summer season and the situation will continue till April. The shortage in supply is not as bad to rely on imports or create a buffer. Besides, imports will hurt farmers which cannot be encouraged,” Sodhi said.

Title: ‘Pak Hindu girl rescued, yet to return to family’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Amritsar: Pakistani Hindu girl Mehak Kumari (15), who was abducted, forcibly converted to Islam and married to a Muslim man, was recovered by police on Monday, five days after she had gone ‘missing.’

General secretary of All Pakistan Hindu Panchayat (APHP) Ravi Dawani told TOI on phone from Karachi on Monday that police had recovered Mehak from Ghariyasin town, about 100 kilometres from Jacobabad, in Sindh province. Mehak was abducted by 28-year-old Ali Raza Machi, who had earlier divorced his two wives and had four children. Machi reportedly forced Mehak to embrace Islam and married her at Dargah Amrote Sharif.

Dawani said Mehak was in police custody in Shikarpur district, which was a bordering district with Jacobabad. While hailing Jacobabad police and civil administration for helping the Hindu community for restoring confidence among them, he said police had also arrested Machi.

He said the accused would be produced in a local court on Tuesday. “We expect that she will be handed over to her family after completing legal formalities,” said the general secretary of APHP. Dawani said since the girl was minor, her conversion to Islam and marrying a Muslim man shouldn’t be accepted.

On the reports of abduction of another Pakistani Hindu girl Guddi Kumari, Dawani said, “We have been hearing reports of her abduction in news. Neither her parents, nor any other family member has come forward claiming her abduction. As of now, we can’t confirm her abduction.”

Title: Rahul Gandhi to kick-off anti-government rallies from Jaipur on January 28
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Rahul Gandhi

JAIPUR: Rahul Gandhi will kick off a series of anti-Modi rallies from Jaipur on January 28.

With students in universities up in arms against the Centre and youth disillusioned with the Modi government on the job front, the Congress is trying to use it as an opportunity to tap on the anger of the youth against the Modi dispensation.

Youths have been a staunch supporter of Modi who had garnered vote for development. But Modi’s second term has seen the party slipping on governance and focusing more on its Hindutva agenda with the people divided on the Citizens Amendment Act. The economy is also sliding and the Congress sees this as an opportunity to attack the Modi government.

Thus, the party had planned several outreach programmes by Rahul Gandhi.

Party sources confirmed that Rahul would kick off several public meetings from here on January 28. But the party has not yet decided on the venue of the meeting.

AICC general secretary incharge of Rajasthan Avinash Pande confirmed that Rahul’s meeting in Jaipur was not confined to support the anti-CAA protests. It will encompass wider issues including pressing ones like widespread unemployment, agriculture distress, atrocities against students and youths and national economic disaster.
