Title: ‘Modi govt akin to drunkard selling family silver’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nagpur: Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) founder Prakash Ambedkar on Saturday compared Narendra Modi government with a drunkard selling family silver to fuel his addiction.

“Just like a drunkard sells jewellery and utensils of home for purchasing liquor, Centre is selling its stake in Navratna companies. These are golden hen providing a revenue of over Rs1 lakh crore every year,” he told reporters.

Ambedkar reiterated his statements that funds meant for proposed Babasaheb Ambedkar memorial at Indu Mills should be spent on modernization of Wadia Hospital for children in Mumbai. On being criticized by members of Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government over this, he said, “I don’t care about anyone, as they are not true disciples of Dr Ambedkar. Serving living human beings is more important than building statues. If the funds are being utilized for a hospital, it would help us in protecting our future generations. Even a Bombay High Court judge had made similar observations.”

Endorsing tourism minister Aditya Thackeray’s demand for making Mumbai a 24x7 city, Ambedkar said it was a must for citizens, particularly those who work in night shifts. “There’s a big disparity in social lives of citizens. Those in morning and evening shift can enjoy social life but those working in night are deprived of it. It gives rise to increased crime.”

On Congress leader Kapil Sibal’s statement that states can’t refuse to implement Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), he said they could express dissent by uniting and handing over a joint representation to the President of India. “The states must explain to the President different parties were ruling them and Centre whose ideologies don’t match. Therefore, national debate is required on the topic with a larger consensus. In my opinion, even the Supreme Court shouldn’t interfere in such issues.”

On Vinayak Savarkar, Ambedkar said he was undoubtedly a revolutionary leader but he had a different face when it came to his alleged relations with British government. The VBA president said though there was no recession, the government was pushing the economy towards bankruptcy.

Charging the Centre and state with crushing the tribal movement, the former MP challenged them to publish a note written by late prime minister Indira Gandhi to the Japan Government when latter sought permission to excavate minerals from Surjagarh mine in Gadchiroli.

“The British failed to win the tribal dominated areas in Bastar, near Palghar and Gadchiroli in their tenure. Indira’s note would make us realize importance of national security. Both governments are trying to exploit the tribals who want to protect their Jal, Jangal and Jameen. It is the reason the Maoist movement is still continuing and those supporting them are labelled as Urban Naxals,” he said.

On forthcoming budget, Ambedkar said in the last budget government had targeted a revenue of Rs24 lakh crore but in November, the economic survey report indicated it wouldn’t cross Rs11 lakh crore. “For running a country, Rs14 lakh crore is needed. The government is out to sell the Navratnas started by our earlier leaders with a particular vision in the mind for raising the Rs3 lakh crore shortfall,” he said.

Title: N Maha sees 83% rabi sowing
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Nashik: North Maharashtra has completed rabi sowing on 83% of the total estimated area this season.

Of the total estimated rabi acreage of 4.30 lakh hectare, sowing has been completed on 3.55 lakh hectare. North Maharashtra comprises four districts — Nashik , Dhule, Jalgaon and Nandurbar.

Crops like wheat, gram, jowar, maize are taken up for cultivation during rabi season. “Continuous rainfall till the first week of November last year, led 17% drop in estimated rabi acreage in North Maharashtra. rabi sowing is now over in North Maharashtra,” an official from the agriculture department said, adding that the sowing includes Jowar on 44,770 hectare, wheat on 1.51 lakh hectare, gram on 1.20 lakh hectare.

Statistics revealed that rabi sowing in Nashik district is around 102%, while it is around 91% in Jalgaon, 69% in Dhule and 50% and Nandurbar district.

The total acreage drop in North Maharashtra was estimated at around 4.50 lakh hectare. But due to continuous rain till the first week of November, sowing acreage marginally reduced to 3.55 lakh hectare.

There has been marginal rise in acreage in rabi crop in Nashik district, but it has dropped by 50% in Nandurbar and 30% in Dhule.

Total estimated acreage of wheat is 65,503 hectare in North Maharashtra. Of which, wheat has been sown on 44,770 hectare — 68% of total estimated acreage.

Total estimated acreage of gram in North Maharashtra is around 1.66 lakh hectare and sowing has been completed on 1.20 lakh hectare, which is 85% of total estimated acreage.

Jowar has been sown on 44,770 hectare of total estimated acreage of 65,503 hectare in four districts of North Maharashtra.

Title: AMU revised date sheet for pending exams released, check here
Content: AGRA: Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) on Monday announced fresh dates for commencement of the pending examinations in different faculties.According to a notification issued by Controller of Examination (CoE) Mujib Ullah Zuberi, pending examinations of the Faculty of Unani Medicine and ZH College of Engineering and Technology, barring BTech and BE final year, will start on January 27. While examinations at the Faculty of Medicine will commence from February 1 and final year BTech and BE examination will be held from February 10.Faculties of Law, Commerce, Science, Life Sciences, Management Studies and Agricultural Sciences will begin the examinations from January 30. Faculties of Arts, Social Sciences, International Studies and Theology, Polytechnics and the Community College will start the pending examinations from February 3.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Waste mounds pile up in shut Pallavaram yard
Content:
Vehicles carry garbage and empty the load in the dump yard on the bed of Pallavaram Periya Eri

CHENNAI: What happens when a civic body is unable to dump garbage at a designated spot? It empties trucks in a legacy dump yard created on a large water body.This is the state of affairs in Pallavaram. Garbage collected from houses in Pallavaram municipality is being sent to a dump yard south of the Pallavaram Periya Eri (lake).David Manohar, a social activist and local resident, took photographs of vehicles ferrying garbage and emptying it in the dump yard. “This has been happening for the past few days. Garbage collection from houses has also become erratic,” he said.The legacy waste in this dump yard is supposed to be biomined to help restore the water body. (See graphic)Sources in the municipality said problems began after National Green Tribunal (NGT) pulled up Tambaram and Pallavaram municipalities for dumping waste in the Vengadamangalam yard located on the Vandalur-Kelambakkam Road.In 2015, it was decided that waste from these two civic bodies would be sent to the waste-to-energy plant in Vengadamangalam. The waste collected from houses would be taken to a transfer station, where it would be compressed and then sent to the Vengadamangalam yard. However, the state government found several lapses in the working of the private contractor and work stopped.Also, reports by the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board showed that frequent fires broke out in the yard leading to pollution over which nearby residents protested.Advocates appearing for the municipalities before NGT said that there would be no fresh dumping of garbage from September 2019 in Vengadamangalam. But then where was this garbage going? Residents of Pallavaram found this answer — into the lake.An official from Pallavaram municipality told TOI they were in talks to transfer the garbage to Perungudi dump yard which is under the control of Greater Chennai Corporation .S Narasimhan, a resident and former councillor of Pallavaram municipality, said there was major mismanagement at the Vengadamangalam yard as well as in the biomining project in Pallavaram.“A work order was given a year ago, but there appears to be no change in the size of the garbage mounds. Frequent fires cause pollution while the water in the lake, used by local residents, is polluted,” Narasimhan said. “How can the government itself contribute to polluting a water body,” Narasimhan asked.Manohar has documented how raw sewage is being pumped out from a collection well into a channel connecting Pallavaram lake and Kilkattalai lake. Sewage is being let outinto the Periya Eri through an inlet channel.Despite repeated calls, the Pallavaram municipality commissioner could not be reached for comments.

Title: Cold wave sweeps through Agra region, city records 6.2°C
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Image used for representational purpose only

AGRA: A cold wave swept through Agra region on Monday, with the mercury level in the city plummeting to 6.2 degrees Celsius. Moderate fog covered the region till 10 am and residents got a reprieve only later in the day when clouds gave way to mild sunshine.

According to meteorological department officials, moderate fog and cloudy sky conditions are likely to continue till Thursday. They said that maximum and minimum temperatures are also expected to decrease further.

On Monday, the minimum temperature in Agra city was 6.2 degrees Celsius, 3.2 degrees lower than Sunday. Similarly, the maximum temperature recorded was 15.3 degrees Celsius, seven degrees below normal. Besides Agra, cold wave swept through Firozabad , Mathura , Etah, Aligarh and Mainpuri.

At 212, the air quality index (AQI) in Agra was in the poor category on Monday. According to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) data, particulate matter 2.5 remained the prominent pollutant.

Title: SUV driver tries to mow down cop in Pune
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Pune rural police on Sunday arrested a primary teacher from Satara district for trying to mow down a sub-inspector of Rajgad police and dragging him around 50 metres with his SUV when the latter tried to stop him.

The incident occurred at Khed-Shivapur toll plaza.

Samir Kadam (35), the sub-inspector, sustained injuries on his legs and right shoulder. The teacher, Dnyandev Suryavanshi was remanded in judicial custody on Monday and sent to Yerawada prison, Dattatreya Darade, assistant inspector, Rajgad police, said.

On Sunday there was a long queues of vehicles at the toll plaza. “Suryavanshi was blocking other vehicles, so Kadam asked him to take his vehicle aside,” he said. “But he accelerated the vehicle and tried to mow down Kadam. He also drove the car along with him for 50 metres,” he added.

Title: Aravalis again: Trees axed, land fenced, room built
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Gurgaon: Environmentalists have highlighted encroachment over 15 acres in the Aravalis, almost a week after pointing out that another patch of land had been taken over in a similar manner.

The activists said they had recently visited Behalpa along the Damadama Lok Marg and found that large tracts of land had been encroached upon.

They referred to a few Google images from 2018, which showed tree cover over a large area and a waterbody nearby. They pointed to a few images captured recently to buttress their point that the green cover has shrunk within a year.

“Recently, a few of us had visited the site in the forest areas of Behalpa, right on the Damadama Lok Marg. As one turns left to go inside the forest, there are huge tracts of land that have been encroached upon. The area is approximately 15 acres,” said Vaishali Rana Chandra, a green activist who filed a complaint with the chief conservator of forests.

The area, Chandra said, falls in mustil no 17, 18 and 24. “Hundreds of trees have been felled and the area levelled using an earthmover. It has also been fenced using a barbed wire. At mustil no 24, a 12ft wall has been constructed along with a room,” she added.

Residents said the area had over 200 trees, most of which have now been cut and the area fenced.

District forest officer Subhash Yadav said he had received the complaint on Sunday. “We immediately checked our records and found that it is private land. Only kila no 25 of mustil no. 24 (a small part) has Aravali plantation. Trees were cut in the area two years ago. We need to check old records for that,” he added.

Title: Immigration fraud in Kurukshetra: Duo booked
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

KURUKSHETRA: Thanedar City police station on Saturday registered a case of immigration fraud and cheating after Nitish Lamba of Charuni Jatan village in Kurukshetra district alleged that he was duped by immigration agents of Rs 5.9 lakh on the pretext of settling him abroad.

The case has been registered against immigration agents Ravinder Singh and Vishal Maan under sections 10 (no person to function as a recruiting agent without a valid certificate) of the Immigration Act and 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

“The facts of this case are being verified and arrests would be made soon. The accused agents are not returning around Rs 5.9 lakh. An investigation into this case is being carried out,” said inspector Jaspal Singh, station house officer (SHO), Thanesar City police station.

While the SHO said the fraud seemed to be around Rs 5.9 lakh, Lamba claimed that he was defrauded of Rs15 lakh. The cop said the accused had returned Rs 11 lakh to the youth and his parents. However, they had refused to return them the remaining money. He had paid installments of Rs 50,000, Rs 76,000, Rs 10.3 lakh and Rs 3.44 lakh, it has been alleged.

Title: Lalapet flyover repair work at snail’s pace
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Lalapet flyover (File photo)

SECUNDERABAD: Closure of the Lalapet flyover for close to eight months has left commuters fuming as they claim that repair work taken up by the GHMC is going on at a snail’s pace. The GHMC had commenced the repair work of the flyover, which is regularly used by commuters to reach Habsiguda, Tarnaka, Nacharam, Moulali and ECIL X roads, in May last year. Traffic curbs were imposed on the flyover from April 27, 2019 wherein only one side of the flyover was open for vehicular movement.

As per the initial deadline set by the GHMC, the repair work was expected to be completed by August. Due to delay in procurement of bearings, the officials were unable to complete it on time. Subsequently, the GHMC had decided to reopen the flyover for public use by December. However, the municipal corporation failed to keep its promise of reopening it by year-end, thereby leaving commuters agitated. “For the last eight months, we are forced to take a detour to reach Tarnaka, Habsiguda and Nacharam. Closure of the flyover has caused traffic snarls on Mirjalguda T junction,” said Rajesh Modugu , a resident of Moulali who regularly uses the flyover.

Attributing the delay to traffic diversions, the GHMC said the repair work is nearing completion. “There was delay in traffic diversion even after diversion permissions were accorded. There were also a lot of damages which were unanticipated. We are expected to reopen the flyover latest by January-end,” assured Ravinder Raju, superintendent engineer (projects).

Title: Bob’s big dream sinks with his yacht off Sudan
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Bob Bechler resting on the lifeboat after escaping from his wrecked yacht Sisiutl off Sudan coast. The wrecked... Read More

Kochi: When Robert Eugene Bechler alias Bob (76), a US yachtsman , and his wife Alexandria (32) sailed to Sudan after a three-year halt at Kochi Marina with their two-year-old twins Ethan and Harper (born during their stay in Kochi) in SV Sisiutl on March 26, 2018, their dream was to reach Cyprus eventually and settle down in the country after selling off the yacht.

But that dream crumbled after their yacht hit a coral reef and sank off Sudan’s coast two weeks ago. Though Bob managed to save his family with the aid of a lifeboat, their ‘home and belongings’, which he had earned over the past 19 years of his sailing life, were lost. With a bagful of what he could salvage from the wreckage, the family returned to his hometown Seattle, seeking refuge. It is learnt that his boat was not insured.

Bob posted about the incident a few days after the accident. The yacht was sailing to the port city of Suakin after a halt in Djibouti, on the Horn of Africa.

“Good and bad news. Alex and twins are safe. The pictures show everything we were able to salvage. I can’t watch. In middle of the night we were surfing down some big waves when we hit a reef. Sisiutl was immediately holed and filled with water. Her disassembly is now complete when the keel-stepped main mast chewed thru deck while coming down. I am beat up and bedridden. Delusional bedridden,” said his FB post.

TOI had exclusively reported the heartwarming yachting story of the family on March 27, 2018 after they left Kochi. It was in March 2016 that Bob and Alex came to Kochi in Sisiutl as part of their voyage towards the Red Sea and berthed at the Marina. Alex, who became pregnant during their stay here, gave birth to twins in a city hospital in January 2017 and they stayed in their yacht for two years until the babies were ‘ready to sail’.

The two weeks in crisis-hit Sudan too was troublesome for the family. Bob’s FB updates said they could not leave their hotel because there was gunfire in the streets. “The hotel is short on food and I have lost any semblance of a sense of humor. I can’t fly out because sanctions stop financial transactions. I tried booking a ticket and failed at payment stage because local currency is not recognized. Never been more helpless,” said the update posted on January 14.

Though TOI tried to contact Bob through FB, there was no response. But Bob later confirmed through another post that they have reached Seattle safely on Monday. “Arrived safe and somewhat sound in Seattle. Now to get some lost sleep,” the post said.

According to sailors at Kochi Marina, who had frequent contacts with Bob, the boat was not insured. “Many yachts out there have no insurance as companies charge high premium for yachts that sail around the world. For many yachtsmen, it may not be affordable. It is learnt that, Bob’s yacht too was uninsured,” said Wade Alarie, a Canadian yachter at Kochi Marina.

Title: AMU Women’s College students demand resignation of VC, registrar; boycott classes
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Agra: Students of Aligarh Muslim University’s Women’s College boycotted classes on Monday when the institution reopened after an extended winter break, demanding the resignation of the vice-chancellor, registrar and proctor over the university’s failure to protect students from police excesses on the campus on December 15. They have also announced that their boycott will continue till the officials step down.

Later, a group of women students took out a protest march on the campus against CAA and NRC and shouted slogans of ‘azadi’. They also urged the administration to revoke the false charges and cases against the students.

Nida, one of the protesters, said that they would continue the boycott till AMU VC Tariq Mansoor and registrar Abdul Hamid quit their posts. She added that they have submitted a memorandum, addressed to the President of India, to the principal of the college.

Similarly, the students of law, life sciences, commerce, science and agriculture faculties of AMU also joined the women students’ protest. They urged the Union government to immediately roll back the Citizenship (Amendment) Act stating that it’s against the pluralistic foundations of India and tarnishes the principle of equality in the country.

Mohammad Ghayasuddin, a court member of life science department, said, “We believe that CAA is a divisive law that was principally brought after Assam NRC to accommodate the Hindus who could not make it into the list due to lack of documents. The Act deliberately kept the Muslims out of loop to send an Islamophobic message to the nation. We reject the BJP’s hatred for Muslims and want the Union government to roll back CAA.”

The protesters also demanded that the NPR exercise should be stopped immediately claiming that the initiative is the first step towards a nationwide NRC.

Another student said, “The CAA, NRC and NPR combine is anti-poor, anti-Dalit and anti-minority. Indians are mostly poor and can’t even afford to obtain documents to prove citizenship.”

Claiming that the police and RAF used disproportionate force against students during the violence on AMU campus on December 15, the protesters sought stringent action against the guilty. They said that the campus is not safe under an insecure administration and demanded that the VC must resign along with his team so that students can go back to classrooms.

Title: Pune: Show-cause notice to water plant operator
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The civic body has issued a show-cause notice to the contractor operating the Vadgaon Budruk water treatment plant for the death of an 11-year-old boy, who drowned after falling into the open overhead tank at the facility while flying kite on Sunday afternoon.

Mayor Murlidhar Mohol on Monday announced that the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) would provide the boy’s family with financial aid under its Pandit Deendayal Upadhyay insurance scheme.

Elected members from all parties raised the issue of the boy’s death and claimed that security lapses at the plant led to the fatality. The corporators sought explanation and action against the officials concerned for negligence.

V G Kulkarni, head of the PMC’s water department, said some sections of the plant premises had been kept open for the residents of nearby areas. The entry would be plugged once an alternative route is made available, he said, adding that CCTV cameras have been installed at the plant.

Title: No change in Dubai flight timings, relief for passengers
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Indore: In major relief to passengers, who have booked Air India Dubai-Indore flight between February 1 and April 30, the airline announced to reinstate the flight after cancelling it two days ago.

“The flight AI -904 has been reinstated at the same timing as it was operating earlier and affected passengers will now be moving on the same flight without any change,” said an official with the airline.

The airline operates the flight thrice a week. The flight departs from Dubai at 8:10pm and lands at Indore at 12.45am. On January 17, the airline had announced to suspend the flight from February 1 to April 30 for construction of taxi-way near the runway.

Airport authority had proposed to carry out the development work during night hours between 11pm and 5am from February 1 to April 30, 2020. Air India was asked to re-schedule its flight as its scheduled arrival timing was coinciding with the schedule planned for construction of the taxi-way to provide a path for aircraft at the airport connecting runway with 15 parking bays. Thereafter, the airline announced to cancel its Dubai-Indore flight.

However, on Monday, after communicating with the airline as well as travel agents, airport authority on Monday agreed to halt the proposed development work to pave way for arrival of the airline as per its scheduled timing.

Airport director Aryama Sanyal said that the board has approved their proposal of halting development work for about two hours to avoid any impact on movement of international flights to and from Indore airport.

“We have decided to stop development work between 00.00hrs and 02.00hrs to pave way for the AI flight, which comes from Dubai at 00.30 hrs and departs to Delhi at 01:30hrs,” said Sanyal.

The announcement has come as a relief for hundreds of passengers who have booked tickets and were supposed to travel on this route. Travel agents association members had estimated that about 2000 passengers were directly getting affected with cancellation of the flight. “It is a big relief for all passengers travelling from Dubai to Indore during this period. It could have caused huge inconvenience to passengers if they would have had to travel via Delhi and Mumbai,” said the association president Hemendra Singh Jadon.

Title: Fake IAS officer held
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Jaipur: A 20-year-old person, who failed in class XII exam three years ago, was arrested by police for allegedly impersonating as an IAS officer on Monday.

Police arrested Neeraj Kumar, a resident of Hindaun, from a luxury hotel near Sawai Man Singh stadium. Ashok Nagar police had received two complaints against him from two people as they suspected that Kumar was not an IAS.

When police received the complaint, they took the steps cautiously as the two were alleging that a person impersonating was IAS. Senior police ifficers verified their complaint. “Kumar had demanded money from the two and promised them jobs. He presented himself to the complainants that he was posted as OSD at Rashrapati Bhawan,” said ACP Ashok Gupta said.

He said the duo had given him some money, which he had demanded.

Kumar had asked two persons to come with more money at the luxury hotel, where police reached and arrested him. It is not for the first time he had been arrested. Earlier, he was arrested by Bajaj Nagar police for the same crime.

Police claimed that the accused had in the initial investigation told them that he was allegedly was involved in such crimes in Jodhpur, Sriganaganar, Sikar and Hindaun.

Title: Chennai: 'Filth from e-toilets pollutes road to girls' school in Mint
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The two e-toilets on way to Vivekananda Centenary Girls Higher Secondary School on Saravana Street, Mint, are ... Read More

CHENNAI: Walking to school has become increasingly difficult for students of Vivekananda Centenary Girls Higher Secondary School on Saravana Street, Mint.

They have to cross a narrow stretch of 100m before they enter the school, walking past two e-toilets that are unusable and awash in filth. Besides, vendors from local markets relieve themselves outside, with some also defecating there. “It is disgusting. They know there is a school here, but people still come in groups and use this space as urinals. We have a hard time crossing this road,” said a Class VIII student.

The toilets were set up a year ago, and as residents and school authorities pointed out, became dysfunctional soon after inauguration. They were rarely cleaned and people now use the adjoining walls, which includes one near the school entrance, as toilets.

School faculty members showed a letter sent six months ago to the district collector requesting to either shut or move the toilets to another place. “A few local officials, including the area engineer and zonal officer also came to the spot and inspected it. They saw the place was in a mess and promised to take action. We are still waiting for it,” said Shashi Shikhananda, secretary.

Several parents have complained about the unhygienic road the girls are forced to take. They are worried it might spread infection or disease since that side of the road is hardly cleaned. “But what more can we do? We have made our staff stand outside while students come to school and leave for home. But the situation persists,” said M Vijayalakshmi, maths teacher and school coordinator. She said the condition of the road is worse when it rains. “Sewage flows on to the road and we have a hard time,” she said.

A few residents who live opposite the toilets complained about the stink and the mosquito infestation because of the stagnant water nearby. “We are forced to keep all our windows closed. It becomes bad in the evenings,” said V Padma, a resident. The place has also become a hub for alcoholics at nights, she added. “They sometimes get into loud arguments. We are scared.”

The zonal officer of the area did not respond despite many attempts to contact him.

Title: Jewellery shop burgled in Pune
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A gang of burglars broke into a jewellery shop in Walhekarwadi in Chinchwad and made away with cash and ornaments worth Rs 17.27 lakh on Monday.

Champala Chaudhary (39), owner of Balaji Jewellers, has lodged an FIR with the Chinchwad police. “The suspects stole 42.5kg of silver, 55g of gold and Rs 65,000, totally worth Rs 17.27 lakh, from the shop,” senior inspector of the Chinchwad police Bhimrao Shingade said. tnn

Title: For Swachh & green Indore, civic body takes the e-way
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Indore: Indore Municipal Corporation’s (IMC) sanitation inspectors will soon be seen making rounds in their wards on eco-friendly battery-operated scooters.

After providing e-cars to its assistant engineer and junior engineer-level employees, the civic body now plans to give e-bikes to sanitation inspectors of all 85 wards to reduce fuel cost.

IMC commissioner Asheesh Singh said that these e-scooters will be bought with help of a private bank that has agreed to fund this project under its corporate social responsibility (CSR) work.

“Providing e-scooters to sanitation inspectors will strengthen our monitoring work on ground, and also help in reducing fuel and vehicle maintenance cost incurred by the corporation, especially during Swachh Survekshan,” Singh told TOI.

The commissioner said that these scooters are expected to cover a distance of at least 65km on single charge, and it would take around four hours to re-charge.

“Our sanitation inspectors will have to move on fields for monitoring purpose, and they are given at least 15-20 litre fuel every month. And giving them e-scooters would not only save fuel expense borne by IMC, but also encourage them to work more efficiently,” he pointed.

Singh said that they also have plans to equip these e-scooters with global positioning system (GPS) which would allow the corporation to track their movement on real-time basis. “This would also promote eco-friendly mode of transport in city,” he added.

The announcement comes nearly four months after Bhopal Municipal Corporation introduced a fleet of 200 electric scooters to monitor its solid waste management operations across the state capital.

The BMC had also proposed to set up solar powered charging stations across city to provide easy charging options for its health inspectors.

—

Smart, Cost-effective & Eco-friendly

- Sanitation inspectors (darogas) of all 85 wards of city will get e-bikes

- E-bikes will run at top speed of 30kmph

- Each bike will have mileage of at least 65km per charge

- These bikes will also have GPS

- Self-start vehicle with drum brake and has at least 3 years of warranty

Title: Parting of ways in Delhi BJP’s calculated move?
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Badals with Amit Shah

JALANDHAR: Even as the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) is claiming that severing of ties with BJP in Delhi elections is only due to its “principled stand” on CAA, sources claimed that the saffron party has taken a calculated risk. Since SAD is facing challenge from within the ‘panthic’ fold, BJP has decided to engage with Sikhs directly in Delhi.

The break up may not have any immediate impact on Punjab as the assembly elections here are still two years away. In addition, their dependence here on each other is more crucial due to voters bases of Sikh and Hindus, to counter the Congress. Both parties were already back to normal within weeks of all the bitterness witnessed in Haryana durign the state assembly polls there in October.

Even on Saturday, when Delhi unit leaders of the Akali Dal, Manjinder Singh Sirsa and Harmeet Singh Kalka, announced that they would not be contesting the state elections, they did not say anything about BJP.

Panthic turf, the core constituency of the Akali Dal, which gave it leverage to negotiate with BJP or with whichever party it joined hands in the past decades, has been slippery for it since Bargari sacrilege and Behbal Kalan firing in 2015. It was mainly due to Sikhs voters turning away from SAD that the party was relegated to third position in Punjab. This handle has slowly been turned by the rivals of the Akali Dal within ‘panthic’ turf, who are also close to BJP, to create serious doubts about the Badals ’ ability to catch Sikh voters in entirety.

Notably, rivals of Parkash Singh Badal family, led by Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa, managed to bring quite a few splinter groups on one platform and held a show of strength in Delhi on Thursday. They gathered under the banner of Safar e Akali Lehar (Journey of Akali movement) and vowed to end Badals’ hegemony on Sikh affairs. The show in Delhi, in which SAD chief Sukhbir Singh Badal was flayed by all speakers, just before the state elections there gave BJP enough headroom to see the element of uncertainty.

During the Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee election in 2017, Delhi unit of the Akali Dal did not use pictures of Badals on its publicity material.

Former Punjab BJP president Shwait Malik, who left the charge just three days back, had gone on record saying that they did not mind Akali Dal taking its own nuanced stand on CAA and it won’t impact their relations.

Till a couple of days back, SAD has been maintaining that it would contest in alliance with BJP and it was only on Saturday they claimed that issue of CAA was a bone of contention. Even Janta Dal (United), with which BJP has alliance in Delhi, has also been taking a position similar to Akali Dal on CAA and NRC.

Title: PMPML bus breaks down with a ‘bang’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Pune: A PMPML bus on Monday suffered a engine snag, leaving close to 80 passengers stranded at Bopdeo ghat.

A passenger said the bus picked up passengers of another bus that had suffered a breakdown en route to Katraj. “As the bus started moving, there was a loud bang from the engine and the driver stopped the bus. Oil leaked from the bus,” the passenger said.

“There was a loud sound from the engine, but it was not a bang. The bus was overloaded. Most buses have a seating capacity for 35 people and another 40% can stand. This bus had more than 80 passengers on board,” the official said. TNN

Title: ITFoK begins with call to recapture public spaces
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Thrissur: Minister for cultural affairs A K Balan inaugurated the 12th edition of International Theatre Festival of Kerala ( ITFoK ) on Monday, with a call to recapture the public spaces that are shrinking with time. Cultural complexes are being built in all 14 districts of the state as part of the effort to expand public spaces, he said.

Balan said land was available in districts for the proposed construction of cultural complexes, which can provide venues for holding theatre workshops and staging plays. The government is making sustained efforts to revive the theatre tradition of the state through innovative experiments. Rural theatres are being set up in different parts of Kerala, he added.

Balan also presented the Ammannur award to theatre critic Shanta Gokhale. The award carries a cash prize of Rs 3 lakh and a citation. A saptha maddala kacheri led by Kalamandalam Unnikrishnan preceded the inaugural function. Sahitya Akademi president Vaisakhan released the festival bulletin at the function which was presided over by the Kerala Sangeetha Nataka Akademi chairperson KPAC Lalitha.

Brazilian play ‘Silver Epidemic’ was the opening play of the 10-day long festival which will showcase 19 plays, including seven from abroad. Seminars on ‘Theatre of Emergency’, ‘Theatre of Migration and Citizenship’ and ‘Secular Space/Secular Act’ have been arranged as part of ITFoK. ‘Imagining communities’ is the theme of this year’s festival. The festival will also feature six plays from Kerala and six from other states.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Encroaching temple, mosque removed from lake bed
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Madras high court

CHENNAI: A temple and a mosque, which were built by encroaching the Konambedu lake , have been demolished as per the instruction of the Madras high court , the Avadi corporation has informed the court. Commercial structures constructed on the water body have also been removed, it said.

The civic body added that a proposal has been sent to the Tamil Nadu Slum Clearance Board to provide alternative accommodation to 17 people who had built dwellings on the lake bed. They have not been evicted. Special government pleader A N Thambidurai made the submission on behalf of the Avadi corporation on the contempt plea moved by Konambedu Village Welfare Association seeking action against the authorities for failing to implement the court orders and remove the encroachments.

He said the slum clearance board has put up construction at Poochi Athipedu near the village and that the 17 encroachers would be accommodated there after removing their dwellings from lake. As to the allegation of illegal extraction of groundwater in the area, the authorities submitted that five private borewells have been sealed and an FIR has been registered against Senthilkumar and Jeyakumar for illegal extraction of groundwater.

Recording the same, a division bench of Justice N Kirubakaran and Justice P Velmurugan noted that even though an FIR was registered on January 14, against two people under five non-bailable sections, reports about further action have not been filed. This apart, the authorities have not given details regarding the allegation that contracts for water supply have been awarded to peple who do not own any vehicle to ferry water.

The court directed the authorities to provide all such information and posted the case for January 22 for further hearing.

Title: Maharashtra: ‘Maths, science terms in English for Marathi texts’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Along with introducing integrated textbooks for various subjects, Maharashtra State Bureau of Textbook Production and Curriculum Research (Balbharti) has also planned to run a pilot to introduce mathematics and science concepts in a bilingual format for vernacular medium students.

For the next academic year, Balbharti plans to print the English equivalent for various concepts in mathematics and environmental science in Marathi textbooks for classes I to V in six divisions of the state board—Pune, Mumbai, Nagpur, Amravati, Nashik and Aurangabad. Palghar is the selected district for Mumbai division. The idea was discussed at a recent meeting of officials from the bureau and the new school education minister, Varsha Gaikwad.

“Students studying mathematics and science in Marathi often have to use English terms in their day-to-day working. For instance, in science, we use terms like table, water cycle, rotation, distance etc and in mathematics we use angle, addition, minus etc. These subjects are taught in English in the higher secondary and higher education levels. Reports, research and references in the subjects are also in English. Students are also not evaluated on the basis of what terms they use but how they can apply the concepts. Hence, it cannot be ruled out that there would be a gap in the theory and practical application of these subjects,” stated a letter on Balbharti website.

Like in integrated textbooks, the bureau has uploaded samples of a maths and EVS textbooks for review. Some teachers said the practice was used in the past for extremely technical terms. The sample has several spelling errors but officials said these would be corrected.

Teachers have appreciated the effort but with caution. “It is a very practical hurdle for students who move to junior college. But this must not be a step towards converting vernacular medium schools into the semi-English format,” said Vilas Parab, a teacher of Balmohan Vidyamandir (Marathi). Shailendra Kumbhar, principal, Shailendra Education Society, Dahisar, said, “The practice must not be done in excess but only for technical terms. The sample has translations of words like ladder, window and even book.”

Title: Parent denied custody must be allowed to talk to child daily: SC
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

NEW DELHI: Holding it to be a part of human rights of a child to get love and affection of both parents who are estranged and locked in matrimonial dispute, the Supreme Court on Monday said the parent denied custody of the child should have the right to talk to him or her for 5-10 minutes every day.

A bench of Justices Deepak Gupta and Aniruddha Bose said most courts while granting custody to one spouse do not pass any orders granting visitation rights to the other spouse.

“A child, especially a child of tender years requires love, affection, protection of both parents... Just because the parents are at war with each other, does not mean that the child should be denied the care, affection, love or protection of any one of the two parents...,” the bench said.

The SC, while adjudicating the custody battle of a US-based NRI couple, said even if custody is given to one parent, the other parent must have sufficient visitation and contact rights. The court said it is only in extreme circumstances that one parent should be denied contact with the child and courts must assign the reason.

“ Unless there are special circumstances to take a different view, the parent denied custody of the child should have the right to talk to his/her child for 5-10 minutes everyday,” the bench said.

The court passed the order on a plea filed by a wife challenging order of the Rajasthan HC which directed her to go back to US to subject herself to court proceedings there on custody of two-and-half year-old daughter. She had left the US with her child despite a US court directing her not to leave the country.

The bench agreed with the contention of husband’s lawyer Prabhjit Jauhar who said it was his wife who initiated proceedings in the US court and the case must be adjudicated by that court. In case she refuses to go, the court directed that she then has to hand over the child to her husband or in-laws before the Register General of HC on February 3.

“In case the child goes to USA with the husband or either of his parents, the husband shall ensure that the child talks to her mother through video calling facilities everyday,” the court said.

Title: Parking at Chennai Central railway station may get costlier
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

CMRL charges Rs 10/hour for bikes and Rs 25/hour for four-wheelers, at least twice what Southern Railway charg... Read More

CHENNAI: Car and bike parking rates at Dr MGR Central (Chennai Central) railway station may be increased, sources in Southern Railway told TOI.

Railway officials initiated a discussion in this regard after Chennai Metro Rail Limited opened its parking facility at the station recently. CMRL charges Rs 10/hour for bikes and Rs 25/hour for four-wheelers, at least twice what Southern Railway charges for parking at the station. The normal car parking rate at Central is Rs 25 for the first two hours, Rs 35 for the next two and Rs 70 for the subsequent two. Bike parking charges are Rs 5 for the first four hours and Rs 10 for up to eight hours.

A slot at the premium car park facility available opposite the Moore Market Complex (MMC) suburban station costs Rs 50 per hour.

Senior officials in Chennai division took up the issue of increasing the rate after CMRL opened its facility last week. One of the proposals is to increase rates for those who park vehicles for a long time, say a week or more. However, nothing has been finalised, sources said.

Chennai divisional railway manager P Mahesh did not respond to a call seeking clarification.

Meanwhile, opinions are divided over the issue. Some officials feel that CMRL offers a covered parking space which would keep bikes and cars safe during rain or during summer.

The parking spots also have proper pavements.

Compared to this, the railway parking lot for bikes and cars is either open or covered with a flimsy tin roof. The security at these lots is also suspect while the lanes inside are not paved. “Those who can afford to pay a higher fee will surely prefer the metro parking,” said a senior official. This will eat into the railway’s revenue, the official said.

However, another section of officials feels that parking rates on railway properties need to be increased as otherwise metro commuters would park on railway property due to cheaper rates.

Title: Telangana: Case against principal for assaulting boy
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Saroornagar police on Monday registered a criminal case against the principal of Mahatma Jyotiba Phule BC Welfare Boys Hostel-cum-School for allegedly assaulting a class 5 student.

Saroornagar police said that though the incident took place on January 4, the case was registered on Monday after the juvenile’s father lodged a police complaint.

Police officials said that the school principal saw the boy on the first floor and lifted him with his ear. The boy suffered scratch injuries because of principal’s nails.

Title: Punjab: Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa to send notice to party colleague
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa

CHANDIGARH: In an intensifying tussle among Congress functionaries in Punjab, rural development minister Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa is going to send a criminal defamation notice to Ashwani Sekhri, a three-time former MLA of the party from Batala. Sekhri had levelled corruption allegations against Bajwa.

Sekhri, also former cabinet minister, had on Sunday alleged during a press conference in Batala that Bajwa and his supporters had indulged in charging hefty commission for allotment of development works there.

Sources close to Bajwa said the rural development minister had asked his counsel to serve a criminal defamation notice upon Sekhri for levelling ‘baseless allegations’ against his own party colleague. Bajwa had said that anyone can verify the work done in Batala by him and he was ready for any probe.

Allegation and counter-allegations between senior Congress functionaries is not new in Gurdaspur district . On January 5 this year, Congress MLAs Fateh Jung Singh Bajwa (Qadian) and Balwinder Singh Laddi ( Sri Hargobindpur ), and Sekhri had held a press conference alleging the minister was interfering in their constituencies.

Title: Mahatma Gandhi was never declared ‘Father of Nation’, reveals RTI reply
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

Hathras resident Agarwal said that the purpose of asking this question was to “get clarity as everyone calls M... Read More

AGRA: Mahatma Gandhi was never accorded the ‘Father of the Nation’ title by Government of India and no rule or ordinance was ever passed in this regard. This was stated by the Union cultural ministry in a response to an RTI query filed by Hathras resident Gaurav Agarwal.

Earlier in 2012, a student of class VI in Lucknow, Aishwarya Parashar, had filed an RTI in this regard and had written to then President Pratibha Patil and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to issue a notification declaring Mahatma Gandhi the 'Father of the Nation'.

The home ministry had then told her that no action was taken on her plea because Article 18 (1) of the Constitution does not permit any titles except education and military ones.

Talking to TOI, Hathras resident Agarwal said that the purpose of asking this question was to “get clarity as everyone calls Mahatma Gandhi the Father of the Nation”.

Recently, a bench comprising Chief Justice SA Bobde and justices BR Gavai and Surya Kant, had observed, “Mahatma Gandhi is the Father of the Nation and people hold him in high esteem, beyond any formal recognition”, while refusing to entertain a PIL seeking conferment of ‘ Bharat Ratna ’ on Mahatma Gandhi.

Anil Dutt Sharma, in his PIL, had sought a direction to the government to give “official decoration” to Mahatma Gandhi to honour him for his contribution to the nation.

Title: Education department to award and reward ‘Bal Rakshaks’
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The get-together of ‘Bal Rakshaks’ was held in the city on Sunday

Title: Families of cops held hostage to water crisis in Aurangabad
Content:
This story is from January 21, 2020

The newly built apartments on the premises of the city police commissionorate

AURANGABAD: The families of serving police personnel, who had moved into the newly constructed flats on the premises of the city police commissionorate, have been facing erratic water supply.

Now, many families are unwilling to continue living on the premises as they do not get regular water supply . They are forced to buy drinking water on a daily basis.

The city police had built smart houses for the staff in multi-storey buildings. There are 10 apartment buildings on the premises and each of these buildings has 28 2BHK flats. The process of allotting the flats was initiated in September 2019.

The storage capacity of the water tank is 5.60 lakh litre and as per the calculation of 1,000 litre/family, the water released by civic body is sufficient for only one day. Currently, there are about 500 families including those of constables, head constables, assistant sub-inspectors, police sub-inspectors and assistant police inspectors residing in these apartments.

Residents said the water supply was normal for the first one month, but things changed drastically soon after. The civic officers ignored the pleas of the senior police officers. The families have been asked to use water judiciously and also store it.

A resident of the B wing said, “We get water only once in five days. It is difficult for us. People want the police to be on duty for 24 hours, but don’t we deserve regular water supply at least.”

She said that due to lack of water, they are struggling with their household work.

A policeman, who is lives in one of the flats, said that for the past several days, he had to go to office without taking a bath.

Residents unanimously said that they are being forced to purchase drinking water. “After getting stressed out on the field, we reach home only to face water woes,” said a head constable.

The women members of the families gathered for a recent haldi-kunku event organised by the deputy commissioner of police (headquarters) Meena Makwana, and expressed their anger before the officer.

When contacted, DCP Makwana first tried hushing up the matter by terming it to be an internal matter. Later, she expressed her helplessness in being able to address the issue.

She told TOI, “After the water supply department engineers did not respond to our requests, the matter has been brought to the notice of the commissioner of police, who is personally following the matter up with the Aurangabad municipal commissioner.”

The officer said the water supply department authorities have asked to adjust the lines of rest of the city, which too, on an average, gets water once in five days.

An officer privy to the issue said that senior police officers including DCP headquarters is upset as the water supply engineer, who is in charge of the area did not bother to answer her phone calls.
